description:
I found it on yelp even it was right across my hotel. But it is not visibly existent from the outside. The Korean restaurants front sign is overwhelming and hiding this gem.
I ordered a latte and 2 macaroons.
Inside it is quiet and there is lots of space to sit or work or study. Decorations are cute.
I loved my little bites and my coffee was perfect!
author: Apple S.

description:
I have mixed feelings about YakiniQ Cafe but I will be back! 

From the outside, it looks pretty nondescript and like nothing special, kind-of run-down. This aesthetic continues when you walk in: there's a bunch of comfy seating but there's bad lighting and it just looks old. 

There was only one person working there when I walked in around 9:45am on a Tuesday morning, but lots of people were at tables and seats reading or working, so it must be a pretty good place to work. Because there was only one person taking orders at the cash register and making drinks and preparing dishes and there was a line, there was a bit of a wait for my drink. I also worked there for about 15 minutes while I finished my drink and dish.

I ordered the Yuzu Honey Tea and Lemon Meringue. I just wanted the tea, but there is a $6 credit card minimum so I added a baked good to my drink order and BAM by total went up from roughly $4.50 to $12. Well okay then. 

The Lemon Meringue was crisp and crunchy (from the meringue), with good but not great flavor that wasn't very strong or lemony. The Yuzu Honey Tea was pricey for what you get but refreshing and flavorful. 

The service could've been much friendlier, but I did feel bad she was working alone and must have felt stress to work faster because there was a line of people. I will be back to try other drinks, but I'll do so with cash on me!!
author: Lizzie S.

description:
This library-like cafe is owned by the same family that owns the bustling Korean BBQ upstairs where I remember eating a whole lotta meat that I was grilling myself on a hubcap. This is the spiritual opposite of that place where young Asians epoxy themselves at tables to stare intensely at their laptop screens. There was no conversation, no music, just the not-so-hushed tones of fingers clicking on keyboards. There were desserts in the display case, but I was interested in getting something warm to drink. Although I was intrigued by the sweet potato latte, I went with the more predictable $4.25 Ginger & Honey Tea (photo: http://bit.ly/2MmEhP2). I sat at a table quietly sipping alone, and it was a soothing balm on an atypically wintry evening. But is that galbi I smell?

TEA - 3 stars...it was fine, just fine
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...shhh...
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...quietly quiet
TOTAL - 3 stars...a moment of peace in J-Town

RELATED - Lost in J-Town? Here's a collection of places I've tried and reviewed: http://bit.ly/2MjfL6j
author: Ed U.

description:
I debated whether or not I should write this review, and it hinged on whether it would be useful to other customers. In the end, I do think my experience can be a useful caution. 

Two key insights: 

1. The cafe does not necessarily open at 9 am despite what the sign outside says or what's on the website/yelp. It opens whenever the person setting up is done setting up. So if you're outside waiting and it's 9 am, and you can clearly see someone inside that can let you in, just keep waiting and try to do something useful with your time. Otherwise, if like me you are looking for a good workday cafe - don't plan on coming as they open. 

2. As a confrontational but reasonable person, I prefer to give feedback in person and not on Yelp. If you are like me and if you have any reasonable feedback to give, do NOT give it in person at this place. Instead, do it on Yelp as it'll save you an unpleasant situation. Today I made the mistake of voicing my feedback on the opening hour. I had gotten to the cafe about 10 minutes early, so just waited outside after seeing the sign outside that says "opens at 9 am...". At 9 am, I could see that the person setting up (the owner I later found out) was almost done but she shot me an annoyed look and just kept bustling around. 9:05 came and she finally opened the door and again gave me annoyed look. I'm not sure what I did to deserve this hostility from the getgo, so I said "Your sign outside says the cafe opens at 9 am, so I was hoping you would let me in at that time." At this point, the owner began a tirade of verbal abuse and things escalated before I knew what was going on. She said things like "You don't have to come here! Why are you even here?" and "Are you that much in a rush??" with an increasingly loud voice, to which I responded "well, I value my time." The response to that was "I open the cafe WHEN I WANT TO OPEN the cafe". After a few minutes of this, to calm things down, I said "Look, I'm sorry. I get your policy now and next time I'll come later." She responded "You should be sorry!" and then I said "well, can I order my latte and sit down to work now?". Her response was "Leave! I am not serving you today." And so I left, still not understanding what had happened. Perhaps she was having a bad day even before I arrived, but I don't understand how anything I said could trigger someone to have that irrationally big of a reaction. 

I did not expect her to apologize or even to change the policy. Maybe I should've just waited indefinitely. But as a customer, I should be able to voice feedback especially if there is a discrepancy between the store's actions and what was communicated to me as store policy, from the door and website. The response could have just been an explanation that that's how things are done there, and I would have been fine with it. However, it is not okay to respond to feedback so uncivilly by blowing up in my face and refusing me service, even as I repeatedly tried to de-escalate the situation. 

From a number of other reviews, it seems others have had similar negative experiences with the owner. Needless to say, I will not be going back there again. And yes, taking to Yelp is probably the best way to voice critique, sadly.
author: Crystal H.

description:
PSA to all who reads this review: THERE IS PEANUT BUTTER IN THE CHICKEN, IN THE BANH MI AND THE CAESAR SALAD. 

I pass along this warning because yes, I meekly sat at allergy tables growing up in elementary school (and met my first crush at one, so let's not downplay these exclusionary experiences). I'm Asian, and I typically know my ingredients in foods/sauces. And maybe I've been far removed from Chicago's JJ Street Thai Food days and this is separation anxiety at its finest (worst). 

Yakini IQ did not put that these items contain nuts on the menu. It said: Thai satay sauce, spring mix, carrots, cucumber, something like that. But if you're ALLERGIC TO NUTS, a sprinkle of nut on a salad makes it a NUT SALAD. A single walnut in the middle of a fruity parfait renders it a WALNUT PARFAIT. To everyone, a grain of nut in a food dish is just a dish that happens to have a nut in it. For people allergic to nuts, nuts are alpha. They're like the quarterbacks of the football team. They get all the attention, not because they have some special God-given right, they get the attention due to the way they operate. Whatever has a nut in it becomes a nut dish. Therefore, every dish that has nuts needs to come with a nut warning. QED. 

So, after a mild allergic reaction, I pointed out to the woman behind the counter that they should really put that the banh mi and the caesar salad contains nuts on the menu. Her reply was, "if you have allergies, you should've asked". I couldn't believe it. You listed cucumber and dijon mustard, pretty inconsequential food items, but not nuts?

I said, "would you mind getting me another dish without nuts in it?" Her response: "we don't really do this, because you should have asked. But we'll do it this time". 

Not warning people out there that there are potential deathly allergens is one thing. An uppity, rude, sassy response, without any sort of apology, or empathy that I just suffered through an allergy is another. I felt extremely disrespected. Maybe I was a dumbass to not check, but that's the thing: I always do. There has not been a single menu in an establishment that I've visited that doesn't points out nuts. It's a pretty catch-all situation in the food and bev industry. 

I said, "you guys should put it on the menu anyway. What's the harm in that? Err on the side of caution." Her response: "if you have this allergy, you should check. We've never had this problem before." It's not like I thought to myself, "what wheel of chance shall I spin today with my horrific allergy? How.... sexy and... dangerous!" It's sooo much work to mention that there's nuts in lieu of people dying, right? What a low quality response. The "we've never had this problem before" response follows the logic of "just because it never happened means it never will". 

So if you guys are reading this, yes, I should have checked. But restaurants don't operate on a "you should ask policy". That is completely unacceptable. Write it on the board! Takes 20 seconds.
author: Celena C.

description:
First-time visit & got confused by the YakiniQ Korean BBQ next door! 
-Great ambiance, good lighting, quiet & peaceful atmosphere. Many are working on their laptops quietly--which is a great work environment.
-Ordered Matcha poundcake w/ icing on top. A bit pricey (6.5 after tax). The cake's texture is a bit dry, but does taste like matcha tea. If the cakes are fresh and moist, it would be a 4-star!

-The store shares a restroom with another facility, and the sink surrounding area is dirty--with dead bugs everywhere. This is the main area of improvement!!! hygiene wise it's a 1-star! 

-Cute furniture, thoughtful decorations, with art pieces on the wall for sale. 
-I like how the tables are designed to be separated from another, which brings some privacy to each table.
author: Jess W.

description:
Not bad but too far from a nomad cafe.
I came here after searching "wifi charge cafe" on Google. YakiniQ Cafe is top hit near my location then. Coffee is around $2.5 and you can't use a credit card unless paying more than $6. There're so many workers and students but seats available to use charge are only 3 or 4. So you can use WiFi(not so fast) here.
Around 4 pm, it has been geting colder.
author: Shun Y.

description:
YakiniQ café was one of the easy places I go to for some good eats and drinks along with free WiFi, not the other Yakiniq which was the Korean BBQ of the left side.  Coming and looking inside this lovely café makes me feel like this was now my second home to settle down and read a newspaper.  Even though there are several houseflies flying in its vicinity, no fly would ever bother me while sitting in any table.  On the left wall was the cabinet filled with tin cans of Harney & Sons.  My aim to purchase in YakiniQ was to try none other than the tea flower.

What makes this tea flower interesting is its lengthy steeping.  How long will it steep to picture perfection?  Depends.  The water in the clear glass mug was very hot, making the tea flower ball expand as quick as possible.  Viola!  After the tea flower sank to the bottom of the glass cup to complete its transformation, its tea color got darker, more bitter, and lukewarm.  Still tasted good; what mattered most was the tea flower transformation.  If I was patient long enough, the tea flower would look more beautiful.

I'm sure there are other cafés out there that are good for tea flower steeping.  YakiniQ was the first.  Customer service turned out good and pleasant with nice working women.  Next time I come here, I be willing to have the same cup and see what happens if I go for seconds.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
After 6+ years of demanding to make a pit stop every single time I'm in the area, I think that urge has disappeared in the depths of the many failed experiences that I have written about.

Friday afternoon, heading into YakiniQ because I was determined to be my sweet potato latte fixin' and it seems like nothing has changed in terms of decor. However, when I was trying to place my order for my latte, the cashier was too pre-occupied with the couple leaving their empty cups and told them that there was a bin near the cash wrap that they NEED to place their finished dinnerwear. Note, no apology was made for this minor distraction.

I placed my order, asked for a to-go cup, got my drink and left. At first sip, I was hoping to get a wave of sweet potato with a dash of sugar, instead, I just got a milky substance with random chunks of questionable root vegetables. No flavor to the drink, and doubted my past experiences with YakiniQ. Maybe I was thinking of a different place that served a delicious sweet potato latte? Couldn't be, because I would be hitting up K-Town every damn winter weekend, getting this drink, instead of yearning for this while I'm in San Francisco.

From my first review until now, a lot has changed in my personal life, but YakiniQ had remained constant, until this year. I guess it's time to wave goodbye to those past memories and move on to other things, like flavored soju.
author: Tom T.

description:
This review is solely for the purpose of the rude staff member I encountered this morning. I don't know her name but she is a white female with an accent. I had arrived and sat down to set up
My station to work before going to get a coffee. Before I could even connect to the WiFi she felt so inclined to walk over to be and ask if I was going to purchase something. I told Her I would but I wanted to set up first. She rolled her eyes and rudely walked away. I was completely annoyed by her and I didn't want her bothering me any further so I went to the front to order my usual coffee and I asked her if she asks everyone if they are going to order something. She said only if they are here for more than 20 minutes, I had just sat down so I was there for less than 5. She proceeded to tell me I had be here for more than 20 which is why she came over. The cafe is not full and I am the only African American woman here.  I hadn't even connected to WiFi yet so here claim of me being here over 20 minutes is false and baseless.  Her prejudice was not appreciated. As I type this I see other people walking in and not ordering immediately and she isn't harassing them. If you are of any brown shade, please be aware that she will harass you.  Do better. She sucks.  The other staff is amazing and this is the only horrible experience I've ever had. If she's here next time, I'll find another cafe.
author: Mercedes W.

description:
Rude, rude, rude! What type of person stares you blank in the face and fails to respond when you say "Hi" or "Thanks" to them? Well, happened to me twice at YakiniQ Cafe - the cashiers would rather ignore me and speak amongst themselves in Russian. They didn't even bother announcing when my order was ready. I guess I'm supposed to check their counter every few minutes? At least treatment was equal - they weren't very friendly to other patrons either. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 

I'm giving two stars for the ambiance, since it seems like a nice place to work - a good number of people were on their laptops. It looked like they were intensely studying. There were also a few couches to hang out on. If I lived nearby and needed a place to work, I'd consider it.

The food, however, was pretty disappointing. I had the sweet potato latte - which was good - but nothing unique if you've had the Korean latte drink mixes before (Woori Market is around the corner - highly recommended). I wonder if they just used a drink mix and added some foam on top. I also had a slice of yuzu pound cake, which was very dry. The yuzu syrup on top was fragrant with a strong citrus punch - such a shame it didn't permeate the entire cake! Certainly a work in progress. It's too bad I tried it, since I would've actually given YakiniQ Cafe 3 stars without it.

It's not a bad place if you'd like to get some work in Japantown - just don't expect friendly service and stay away from the pound cake!
author: Larissa M.

description:
Nice and quiet, seemed good for studying or quiet reading alone. They have art being sold on the walls, which I love to see as well and 

My issue was the ice tea, which we me and my sister ordered when the amazing Pearl Spa next door brought us over because there was a 10 minute wait. BTW - if you have never gone to Pearl's Spa, I highly recommend any of the full exfoliation treatments, simply amazing and owner and staff really step up customer service to the next level.

Anyway - back to the ice tea. It tasted old, so I told the nice clerk I was pretty sure this would be coming back once my sister tried it as well (btw, you should have seen her face when she drank it...although my slip and fall from my chair somewhat distracted her and I both for a second, lol).  When I bright the teas back, the clerk said it was just made yesterday so should be good. That was my biggest problem.

If you are a tea and coffee shop, you really should be making tea fresh everyday...especially if it is not refrigerated the entire time and if it is kept in the service cans. That is gross and you can taste that neglect and oldness in every sip.  :/
author: Amber D.

description:
Very sweet little coffee shop/cafe. Saturday morning and there was only one person working - althought there were only 2 people ahead of us, one of them was ordering 4 coffee drinks. So there was a bit of a wait...but it was fine. Everyone was chill and it's a lovely environment.

I couldn't decide between the sweet potato latte and the lavender latte. Since I'd never had sweet potato, I decided to go with that. Hubby ordered a cappuccino. It is a little pricey. If you want espresso shots in your sweet potato latte, they cost .95 cents each. So for one, that's affordable. But for 2-3, it's not. Think about it - 2-3 shots is what you really need to get that caffeine in you. Anyway, it tasted pretty darn good...but it was pretty darn filling. I think I'd definitely do with lavender next time, if I'm going to order a frou frou coffee drink. Hubby got his cappuccino and a chocolate croissant.

Conversely, their macarons are priced right. If you buy the 6 macaron deal, they come out to about exactly the same as Chantal Guillon pricing, which I find about as affordable a macaron as is out there. Waaaaay better pricing than Bottega Louie (I know - that's LA - but those who are interested in macarons will be interested in this piece of info). Got two Earl Grey, two Pumpkin, and two Kona Coffee and the teen girl said they were amazing (and she's the Bottega Louie fan). 

The lovely woman working all alone was super friendly. It would have been nice to sit and enjoy our drinks but we had some Ichiban Kan shopping to do. Bottom line - really terrific for straightforward coffees and pastries, but pricey for specialty coffee drinks.
author: Laurie H.

description:
Was looking for a nice warm place to talk with friends after work and this spot is opened till 9pm, sweet! Lots of chairs & this spot is definitely like a good study/chill area.

Parking is always meh around Japantown, but theres always 2hour parking/neighborhood parking a few blocks away :).

It was a cold week night and I opted for the sweet potato latte. It was so unique and after reading all the reviews... it did not disappoint. I had high expectations because I love sweet potatoes in general & if you don't like that taste, then do not go for this! It was really good & 10/10 I would order it again lol. My friend had the lavender latte which was really good too, I wouldn't mind ordering that next time (if the sweet potato latte wasn't there.. lol :p). 

Not sure if it was just the day that I went, but the atmosphere was very very dim and everyone was really quiet. Definitely seems more of a 'study environment' type of cafe lol. BUT I would definitely come back for that sweet potato latte though - so good!
author: Melanie T.

description: Came in here as I was walking past because it looked like such a cute cafe and got the caramel milk tea which was SO AMAZING. I loved it so much I went and bought the tea bag they used online right away. Honestly the best non coffee drink I think I've ever had in my life.
author: Tracey O.

description:
I love this coffee shop in the heart of Japantown! 

I always thought that Yakiniku was just the Japanese way to say Korean BBQ (it is, Yaki meaning grilled, and Niku meaning Beef). And that YakiniQ was simply a Japanese/Korean BBQ place. I never realized that next door (actually, downstairs) was this great, spacious coffee shop, YakniQ Cafe! (The two are owned by the same family). 

First, it is spacious! This not one of those cramped chain shops, like the Mermaid or the "PT" place that taught the Mermaid, or the "PHZ" place that likes baristas to mix coffee like Tom Cruise in a movie about bartenders. 

No, it is a quiet, relaxing place, to meet, study, and do your thing. No hard charging, caffeine addicted, wanabees, or hipsters talking loud and trying to cast airs. Nope, a totally different vibe, sort of a quiet humility to it. In that way, it seems very Japanese in energy.   

The decor helps the vibe. Beautiful hardwood floors, antique wood furniture, Japanese paper lantern light fixtures, and walls covered with individual art collections, that rotate periodically with local artists. As you enter, the Left side tables for 4, are for groups to meet and talk, and the right side tables for 2, are set for those laptop geeks, because the only outlets that work are on the right side. In the middle, is a large couch, sort of a lounge area, and behind, a large community table. The back wall is populated with estate sale nick-nacks and tchotchkes to make things interesting, as well as some board games for public sharing. 

The counter is in the front right. They have a bevy of home-made cookies and baked goods, made by the owner herself, Christy. They also have a dozen or so casual food dishes, like sandwiches or salads. They also have ice cream. Of course they have Espresso and other coffee drinks, as well as many types of teas (mostly in bag form), and other refrigerated drinks. 

The staff is friendly, they will bring your food order table side to you, or call out your drink when it is ready. So they are just like the vibe, pretty low key and unobtrusive. It isn't like you will hear them shouting to each other their personal life over the loud music playing, like at some of those Green Mermaid locations I have been. 

I come here and work on my computer, or meet clients for meetings. I have tried many of their food items, and they are delicious, given the lack of a real full kitchen. 

But don't come here! I want this place to have seats or tables when I do! Or if you do, buy something and leave. Don't be a table hog and sit 6 hours on your laptop, nursing 1 drink. C'mon, enjoy the vibe, but share!
author: Wanugee N.

description: All drinks are super tasty and it's an amazing place to study. Free WiFi, quiet ambiance, cute decor. The ONLY reason I took a star away is because of the bathrooms... smell is very unpleasant and not super clean, please please please do something about this! Other than that I love this place!
author: Yolanda G.

description:
Everything looks a little old and dusty inside, and the cc minimum is $6, but the sweet potato latte, eeks!  So good. Can't believe they add simple syrup in also, it was already plenty sweet with just the potato puree.  

There is no size for this particular drink, it's huge, prob 20 oz?  Sharable.  I was full till the late afternoon.  $0.95 to sub almond milk.  Copying it at home and whenever I am in the area will get that frothy goodness.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Baked goods are pretty hit or miss, but what I love is that I can always find a seat.

Which can be difficult when everyone else in San Francisco seems hell-bent on working on their laptops in a cafe on a Sunday morning!  Lots of space, and a large communal table and sofa so I've never had to wait for a seat.  They have some pretty interesting drink offerings, I tried their sweet potato latte and it was super generous on the sweet potato.  I do wish they had used a koguma/Asian sweet potato instead of what tasted like an orange sweet potato/yam.  Other teas and things are pretty solid and they have sandwiches and shaved ice too.  I normally avoid anything from the refrigerated dessert section, but the yuzu pound cake has been consistently good.

Tips and Tricks
-Check out the cute little signs by the cashier for specialty drinks and food
-The front door doesn't close well so the cafe gets a bit drafty on cold days, pack a sweater!
-Open a lot later than most cafes, especially on a Sunday!
author: Jessica L.

description:
The worst service ever by a very rude barista. If she doesn't want to work or be in service then she shouldn't be working there. If I'm paying close to seven dollars for a coffee you would think I could get some friendly service.  Was going to Pearl Spa 
where they actually have friendly and professional service. Stopped by to get coffee and I'll never return.
author: Ina K.

description:
YakiniQ, such a cute name!

So on my way home from Jtown, I decided to stop by for some quick hot drinks and ran across this place. It has a grand space inside, yet was still pretty crowded during weekends.

Got their house made specialty sweet potato latte, which had small pieces of sweet potato inside, interesting! Yet it was a bit too sweet for me, wish they could tune down the sweetness level.

Next time to try: lavender latte.
author: Elaine H.

description:
This cafe is awesome for working / camping out with a laptop. Quiet music, ample seating, free wi-fi, opens LATE, never too crowded. This is one of the main reasons I come here often. 

The coffee is just mediocre and kinda expensive, esp since all drinks only come with one shot! Most other places come with 2 shots by default. Butttt the ginger tea is really yummy with real ginger bits :) 

Few things to note: 
- $6 min for credit card 
- Not too many outlets, particularly on the left side of the store (side away from the cashier) 
- Somehow always cold, so bring a jacket
author: Samantha C.

description:
A friend and I stopped by YakiniQ on a December night to escape the cold and warm ourselves up with a hot drink. I'm glad we picked this cafe--it  was so pleasant to relax in. Very minimalist and chic. 

My friend ordered the root beer float and I got the sweet potato latte. I was hardcore eyeing the baked goods and I didn't end up buying any, but they looked fantastic. Now, the last time I had a sweet potato latte was a year ago, in Korea. YakiniQ's latte was so good, if not better, than some of the ones I had in Korea! It wasn't overly sweet and had small little bits of sweet potato. Super creamy and delicious. At 4.25, it was reasonably priced, especially for the size of the latte. 

They had a bunch of cool items on their menu that I didn't get to try, and I wish I could've gone back to this cafe before my SF trip ended! If I'm in the area again, I will for sure go back. Highly recommend!
author: Saloni D.

description:
I've been coming here every now and then the past few years so I thought to myself, "might as well do a Yelp review". Lolz

Anywho, I stopped by here yesterday in between work shifts just to grab some coffee, but then I saw the macaroons so of course I grabbed a few. (Diet starts tomorrow!) Totally forgot how much everything was but the total came out to around $7 for coffee and 2 macaroons (got the birthday cake and black&white). 

The thing I really like this spot is the ever so relaxing ambiance. Perfect place to study or even take a date (which I've definitely done before). A must go-to if you enjoy cute little cafes, that and macaroons, you must try the macaroons!
author: Nate C.

description: Ugh cute af. Open relatively early/late and great place to study. Only complaint was there was a slightly musty smell along some of the tables closer to the back.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I love this little cafe! It tends to be pretty quiet, so it's a great place to grab a cuppa and read or get some work done. My boyfriend and I occasionally treat ourselves by stopping in for some of the delicious spam musubi (which is reasonably priced compared to the rest of the food items on the menu) and I get an iced coffee. 

The artwork adds to the decor and changes each time we visit. The staff is always friendly. This has become one of my favorite cafes!
author: Sarah B.

description:
I adore YakiniQ Cafe. It's a great place to study - there are a ton of tables, the layout is open and spacious, and there are outlets all along one side. Additionally, the options for drinks are pretty good - I'm a fan of the Yuzu Honey Tea and the Sweet Potato Latte. Their Bingsoo is delicious, and their riceballs are huge (although they don't have too many options for savory food, so I advise you eat a real meal before you get here!)

The only caveat is that they don't have air conditioning, and so it can get a little hot and stuffy. Also, the wifi is slow as balls. But it's always quiet, people are always studying and respectful of their noise volume -- I haven't found anywhere better to get some work done than YakiniQ.
author: Jessie Y.

description:
What boggles my mind is how a city like SF lacks cafes that are open till 10pm. I'm sure there's a demand for wifi during the evenings! Everything seems to shut down around 6 or 7 including on weekdays. 

I was mostly here for a work session, YakiniQ was the only option in the area that was open till 9pm. 

Banh mi - Not exactly authentic banh mi but it's a decent sandwich, I guess...

Definitely skip the macarons, they're the worst ones I've had in SF. It tasted pretty old and stale...

Matcha latte was okay, not the best but atleast the matcha flavor was there.

Spam musubi was better than the banh mi but not mind blowing of course.

Overall if it wasn't for the late night closing, I would've never been a patron.
author: Virginia Y.

description: This is a pretty awesome local coffee shop. Christie, the owner, is super nice! The Korean drinks are awesome too. You get your regular fair such as lattes, teas, espresso but also Yuzu tea, jujube tea, sweet potato lattes, etc. Also you get many homemade baked goods as well such as their fantastic cookies. The wifi can be spotty but otherwise, this is a great place!
author: Jason S.

description: Randomly came across this little shop and instantly fell in love! It's a cute little cafe place, quiet enough to study, and not cramped at all! They have nice baked goods to sell and an assortment of cafe drinks with some additions of Korean menu items (like patbingsoo and iced jujube tea). I tried the iced strawberry Yuzu tea and it was so good! I'm a big fan of citron so this really hit the spot. The decorations of the entire store is really cute as well. Reminds me of one of those dainty Korean cafes.
author: Gina B.

description: A cute café near Japantown but is absolutely packed. Come early as it will be hard to find a seat. The staff was reasonably nice but it does take a while to get your drinks or food. The atmosphere is comfortable and the Wi-Fi was decent. Be prepared for a lot of people there to get a coffee and camp out for hours. Another words turn over for tables is very slow. That's why I've knocked one star off this place. If it was easier to get a nice place to sit down it would definitely be five stars.
author: Robert C.

description:
In the middle of Japan town there is a beautiful place where you can drink coffee in a very nice environment. And the name is YakiniQ!!!
I didn't tried the food so I can't say anything about it.
author: Dani M.

description: I'll explain why I'm giving this place two stars. I spent 38 bucks here on two bahn mi sandwiches and two drinks. Place is spacious and for that reason it's two stars. The lady at the counter made my drink warm instead of cold. No big deal except that instead of remaking it (the sweet potato latte) she dumps ice in it. I actually told her twice that that's not what I ordered and I brought it back after one sip. I don't like warm drinks and she said if you don't like it I'll remake it. But nope, she goes ahead and just dumps ice in it(not the same drink as the cold version) The sandwich is def just a chicken sandwich not even close to bahn mi and not worth 11 bucks. Would def not come back for food or see
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I was up in SF to visit the Chinese Consulate, and knowing that there was going to be a 2+ hour wait, I wanted to find a cafe in the area to get some studying done. When I searched on Yelp, I was confused to see the name YakiniQ Cafe, since that implies meat. Turns out it is just next door to an actual BBQ place, and I assume it is owned by the same people.

The cafe is actually a really nice and large space, and there were lots of people already there getting some work done. It was really nice and quiet and I ended up being quite productive there. The only slight downside is that the lighting can be pretty dim depending on where you are seated, because they don't have large overhead lights, but depend on smaller lights scattered throughout. It isn't so dark that it bothered me, but it might not be the best for your eyes.

I ended up ordering:
+Lavender Latte: at first glance, they clearly don't put as much effort into the artwork, but taste is what really matters. I enjoy that floral "soap" taste of lavender but it might not be for everyone. I'm also not a coffee expert, so I can't confirm the quality.
+3 Macarons (Matcha, Strawberry Champagne, Rose): I feel like similar with the latte, these were not the prettiest and were slightly sloppy, but they were yummy. They had a good texture and chew. I would say the Matcha was the least impressive though.

I was kind of shocked by the prices, but I am also not used to SF prices, so I'm just going to assume this is normal. The prices were not clearly labeled, but I ended up paying $12+ for all of it, so I assumed around $6 for the latte and $2 per macaron.

This cafe ended up being perfect for my needs. It was quite pricey, especially since the presentation was lacking, even a little sloppy. However taste-wise it was good.
author: Helen W.

description: Visited this for the first time even though I've lived in SF for over 2 years now... it's definitely a hidden gem. Love that the place is quiet and there are big tables to study at. The Matcha latte is delicious only very subtly sweet. I also had the banh mi which isn't like a traditional banh mi at all but super delicious nonetheless. I was too full to try dessert but they were very pretty!
author: Liv T.

description:
Interior is beautiful, the spot is hidden away, service was personable. 

WiFi is supper slow

$5 minimum purchase... THEN the software on the register has the audacity to ask for a receipt. I just wanted WiFi and a cup of coffee.
author: Nicholas R.

description: An escape from the chaos, in particular, from the hyper-simulating cafes that "spin the wheel." The calm, warm environment is a place to set your roots for a while... or to just grab a bite and a fix. I had the  quiche (flaky buttery crust, warmed throughout) and expresso with a teaspoon of sweet condensed milk. Great place to focus.
author: Jacob S.

description: I really like the vibe of this place. It is good for studying, or chatting with a close friend (i.e. not overly crowded/loud). Decor is modern; pretty, but not ostentatious. The sandwich I had was very good, as was the mocha. Don't get confused; there is a club to the right of this place, and I think it's affiliated. This is to the left, and very definitely geared towards more calm pursuits.
author: Liz R.

description: Came here to do homework and my online classes, but the wifi is so slow my lesson videos doesn't even load. No point. Unfriendly customer service. Doesn't even answer me when I greet them.
author: Rainie D.

description: Two stars for how wonderfully quiet it was. The music wasn't too loud. I would only return, though, if I had analog work to do. The wifi speed was glacial. (Maybe not the best analogy anymore; I guess it was slower than glacial?) It was impossible to get anything done in the little time that I had allotted. Also, the sweet potato latte was good, but $6 good? Meh, not really. They list it as a "latte" but if you actually want espresso to be added to your latte, that will cost extra. I understand that it might cost a bit extra to make something with what I presume is canned sweet potato (or perhaps even fresh) but it wasn't $6 good (is any latte, really?). I would only return if I happened to be in the neighborhood and happened to have a book on me, since their wifi is too slow to be useful and there aren't many outlets. It was quiet, though, which was pleasantly surprising.
author: Judith D.

description: Cute cafe but definitely too expensive. An Americano only comes with one shot of espresso. Normally it's two. Not here. I was really shocked and told the woman at the cashier "I know it's not your fault, you don't set the prices" Even she knew it was obscene as she said "Thanks for understanding"
author: ZEEBRA W.

description:
Ice tea tasted old and gross. Was informed it was made probably the day before but maybe even a couple days old. Exchanged for ice Americano instead of ice coffee as ice coffee was made the day before as well.

Both my glass and friend's coffee cup had obvious large chips on the rims but didn't stop them from using them. Not sure how anyone could be a fan of their beverages or lack of quality. 

Gross.
author: L D.

description:
Met my gal pals here for a pre-dinner gathering and this place can get crowded on Saturdays.  I read the other reviews and realize it is not really a place for chatting as most people are reading or studying and not socializing.

One of my gal pals picked this place so we sat in the front and chatted.  One friend ordered a iced matcha green tea and said it was ok.  I ordered the honey ginger iced tea as my hay fever has been acting up and I thought it would help with my congestion.  It was really good and has tiny bits of real ginger on the bottom so you can really taste the ginger flavor.  They have a variety of desserts and I ordered the Green tea yuzu macaron and green tea shortbread cookies.  I asked if they made these goodies and the macarons are from a French bakery in San Francisco but the shortbread cookies are made by YakiniQ.  This place is good if you want to come here and have a quiet place to read, use your computer or study
author: Karen W.

description:
Decided to come here since i was in the area. Its has the same name as the korean bbq restaurant but this place is a cafe. Its a cute place. Its a cool place if you want to hang out with your friends or go on your computer

I got the fruits shaved ice since it was a warm day in the city and it sounded cool too. It cost $7.25. I thought it was kinda expensive for a shaved ice with fruits. It had ice cream, red beans, mochi, and fruits on top of the shaved ice. It was hard to eat it since they put a lot of stuffs on the ice. I wasnt if i had to wait until the ice to be melted but luckily my brother who was finish his shaved ice that we had to move the ice cream and few fruit into his cup to make it easier to eat. To me, they put way too much ice in the cup especially with the toppings on top that i couldnt finish eating the ice. Anyways, i thought the fruits shaved ice was not bad

There was one person who was making the food so it takes a while for them to make the food. And there was another person who deals with the cashier.
author: Julie N.

description:
You got plenty of spcae here and it's quiet. A lot of people, including myself, bring their work here. I do need to let you know that tables arent too big, so you might not have enough space if you bring in a lot of other stuff other than your laptop.

I would say, there are better places out there. But if i happened to be in Japantown, this is my #1 choice.
author: Ruby K.

description: I've been to this cafe several times and have had varying experiences, but happened to see a mouse scampering beside one of the walls today and was extremely displeased. The cashier did not seem particularly surprised and I will not be returning...
author: Anthonia O.

description: I met up with my friends to study on a Tuesday at around 1:30pm. Luckily, one of my friends came here a bit earlier to snag a spot at a table. One side of the cafe has tables that can seat 4 people comfortably, while the other side is more for those that have a party of 1 or two. There are couches in the middle of the cafe, and when I got there, the place was pretty crowded, and if my friend didn't come earlier to get a table, we wouldn't have anywhere to sit. The ambiance is very cafe-esque and quaint. There is music playing in the background so the cafe isn't too quiet, but it is quiet enough that we can have conversations without having to yell. I found out that the credit card minimum is $6 so keep that in mind if you wanted just a coffee or just a pastry. I decided to try the lavender latte, and it was delicious!! They do some little latte art on it, and even add a sprinkle of dried lavender on top. I appreciated the dried lavender because it did make the drink smell good, but when I was drinking the latte, some got stuck in my throat and that was unpleasant. Also, I wish the latte was a little hotter, because it was lukewarm when I got it, and it cooled off pretty quickly. I like to drink my hot drinks slowly, but by the time I finished my drink, it was cold. Either than that, the cafe was great and the latte was amazing, and I would definitely come back here to study or read a book!
author: Lisa C.

description: Walked into a very cute cafe. I ordered the iced matcha latte. Worst matcha latte I've ever had and it was very over priced (over $5). It just tasted like matcha powder and milk and it wasn't even mixed well. WiFi was also spotty.
author: Kelsey Y.

description: The cafe, a cozy space for reading and working, serves a large variety of iced and hot drinks. Their many pastries (ask for those house-made) are delicious. They have a great tea selection and a variety of sandwiches and salads I have yet to try. They often create new drinks, but I opt for the yuzu honey tea. Hot or iced, it's great!
author: Carol W.

description:
A surprisingly large cafe in Japantown with a large assortment of 'quirky' furniture and lighting - likely a good place if you're looking to work on your laptop for awhile or meet up with friends.

That being said, the drinks (especially the sweet potato latte) are average, as is the food. I would keep walking, personally.
author: Claire S.

description:
What an adorable little place to chat with friends or spend time alone over coffee/tea and sweets! After dining next door at Waraku, I was craving something quick and sweet. My friend and I stopped by at 8:30pm on a Tuesday and got a couple macaroons each. I got the passion fruit and caramel ones and they were delicious! 

Definitely stop by if you're looking for somewhere with a relaxing and charming atmosphere. Lots of seating.
author: Emma W.

description:
I have a love-hate relationship with the cafe.

What I hate:
- The prices are too high for the quality of the drinks. $3 for a cup of tea served in a paper cup? Furthermore, the tea is just hot water with a basic tea bag. I've also tried a green tea latte that is too watered down, and I make better brewed coffee.
- I got a macaron for $2.50. While it tasted good, the girl handed me one that was cracked. I would rather spend money on some Chantal Guillon macarons for $2.25 each in Hayes Valley.


What I love:
- The interior is spacious, and I get a lot of work done. There are many seats available, and there's a good number of outlets at the right side.
- There's two Japanese grocery stores nearby where I can grab some prepared food and sneakily consume them for dinner at the cafe.
- IT CLOSES AT 10 PM. I think this is the reason why I keep coming back despite the prices and the quality of the drinks. Very few cafes apart from Starbucks stay open this "late." Most close between 5 - 7 pm. I love how I can stay here until 9 PM, and then it's just a 10-minute walk home or a 4-minute bike ride.
author: Erica G.

description:
Cozy and homely cafe that is tucked in Japantown.

It's pleasant to get some productivity out of this place while sipping on their latte specialties.  They have scrumptious pastries and a variety of macarons to choose from.  There are outlets and complimentary wifi.  I enjoyed their potato latte and the tidbits of potato, gave the drink a bit of a texture.  Their green tea match latte is nice if you want to lay off the coffee caffiene.  

With their communal seating in the center, it's a great place to gather and chatter as well.

It's a calming and quaint spot.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Yakiniq is a rare underrated gem in San Francisco that I hope stays off the radar to be honest. Very few places in San Francisco where they encourage camping out with your laptop and getting stuff done. This place will make you feel like you are hanging out at home but all your friends came over to get work done with you. The local art is charming and the sweet potato latte is one of my favorite drinks in the city and one you won't find anywhere else. With peace plaza mall across the street you have ample places to catch a walk in between working sessions but you don't need to leave to eat healthy as their salads are actually quite good!
author: Justin S.

description:
This place is the cutest and they have sweet potato latte like a true Korean coffee shop. (Yay for corea#1!) 

Some of the chairs (like the one I was sitting in) was hella uncomfortable but looked cool so that made up for it, I guess. Fun board games in good condition in the back - including SET!! It's a bit dark for studying but seems like a good location for some ajumma chitchat.
author: Juliana P.

description: Ordered lavender latte, which is a new drink with homemade lavender syrup. Tastes amazing! The cafe is quiet and nice; really good for reading, working, or just hanging out with friends.
author: Tiffany T.

description: Cute cafe. THey open kind of late for coffee but it's a cute, independently owned coffee shop--a good place to hang out and work and have a coffee and a snack.
author: Cynthia T.

description:
I thought about conferring three resentful stars, but then I remembered places other than SF exist and decided two fits reality better. A few positives: The location in J-town and close to several key MUNI lines kinda sorta helps. Their wifi usually hums along at a decent clip. They have a nice room with enough seating and enough space to make pounding out some work conceivable.

But those prices! Dear Lord. I've never seen such a pile of mediocre, mass-produced garbage coffee game, and yet here it's presented as though the gods who invented Blue Bottle and Sightglass had a baby who personally gilded these beverages in gold leaf. $4.75 for a freaking chai latte? That consists of some instant powder and some steamed milk? That's less work than an actual latte. Want almond milk rather than moo juice? Add another dollar, and with tax now you're above 6 bucks for a drink that is resolutely, almost proudly, nothing special. So let's say you want to economize. How about just some plain tea? They have that! It's $3.50, which could almost be reasonable if we were talking about an actual pot of loose leaf tea, enough to keep you going for a while. But wait! This fine recipe calls for a paper cup containing a pre-made industrial tea bag you could buy at any grocery store, filled with hot water! A true revelation. Food prices won't treat you any better.

In all, this is an agreeable enough space, but one pays so much for the privilege that it seems little wonder it's mostly empty except on weekends. This whole debacle is an anomaly of overheated SF real estate and while I might sympathize if the issue is high rent, they're not going to stay open by raising prices to a level that empties the cafe, and we shouldn't put up with it.
author: James D.

description: Service was appalling. 20 minutes to get a bagel with cream cheese and the  lady that put it together handled it with bare hands... btw the service was not slow because it was packed or anything, it was Sunday morning and there were very few people in the store... horrible
author: Jason K.

description: Mainly come here to get some work done. There is almost always some space to sit. Good setup and ambience. Coffee is fine, nothing fancy. I like that they also have board games etc. Brings some character to it.
author: Mohit L.

description: The pastries and cakes are good. Environment was quiet and not a chaotic as Starbucks or any place where startup/engineers hang out in.
author: Arnold V.

description:
Fail......

Being a latte fanatic, I was excited to try the Sweet Potato Latte.(SPL ;) )

It doesn't initially contain espresso but you can add a shot, so I did. My balance was $4.30 or so and they have a $6 card minimum so I also purchased a Green Tea Macaroon.

THE DRINK: Can you give me a drumroll.... Underwhelming. This was probably one of the weakest latte's I have ever experienced-let alone a Yelp Highlight-Worthy drink.
Sweet potato factor? Basically non existent. My drink was so bland. The bottom 1/2 of the drink was a little starchy/potatoey but still boring. Sad face :(

The Macaroon: good flavor. I liked the lemon curd in the middle. I did not like the bits of green tea leaves in the macaroon. It made it gritty to eat.

Overall...... The cafe itself is very cute. I think if I had better service it might've helped the overall experience. Oh well.... On to the next.
author: Michelle C.

description: Perfect place to study. Whenever I have a free time, I usually go to YakiniQ cafe. But it is very hard to get a seat. Sad.
author: Jeehae L.

description:
Great little cafe with good wifi and lots of outlets along one of the walls. Usually gets pretty crowded with people working on laptops during the weekend and can be hard to find a spot- especially near an outlet. They have a delicious iced chai latte, caprese sandwich, and homemade pastries.

Also, it's right next to Bay Jiu-Jitsu so it's perfect for parents to hang out and grab a snack while their kids are in class.
author: Lindsay L.

description: It's a cozy space that encourages patrons to stay awhile, a welcomed change in San Francisco. There are several wooden tables, some which seat 2, others which seat 4, as well as a couch and a long table with benches that seem to provide ample seating. Lighting isn't the best here, particularly for the tables on the edges of the restaurant, which get a bit dark. I had an iced soy latte, which was a tad too sweet, but sufficiently strong.
author: Cici T.

description:
Just came in for a cup of coffee.  Coffee is nothing special, the same sour Indonesian kind that they have at Starbucks or Pete's.  Clerk was a little rude, like I was putting her out or something.  I ordered for here, but she still put it in a paper cup even though I can see the mugs right there.

Place is clean, nice looking, very spacious.  Really quiet. No free WiFi
author: Stan H.

description: Nice cozy interior. A good place to lounge or study. The latte i got didnt have any hints of espresso, so it tasted entirely like warm milk.  Not worth the price I paid.
author: Gerald B.

description: Ok, I never complain but here it goes. I ordered the Americano. It said $3 on the menu. The Japanese lady behind the counter asked for $4.29. Ok, I didn't want to argue. I sat down on a chair to set up my computer. I am a regular and the Russian lady would bring the coffee to my desk. Not this Japanese lady, she just left the coffee on the counter (she was not busy as I was the second customer of the day). Fine, I walked over only to discover that my coffee is in a white paper cup(regular 12 oz cup), and the kicker? It is only half filled. The previous customer was given a ceramic cup. The Japanese lady should have at least asked if I want the coffee to go or not. So I was over charged for a 8oz cup of americano. The most expensive cup of coffee I've ever had in SF and that says something. The ambience of this place is great, that's why I come here often. The service here is hit or miss. Take your chance.
author: Aaron C.

description: This is a great cafe and has really really good macarons. If you read this review and decide to come, PLEASE NOTE: THIS CAFE IS A QUIET WORKSPACE. People come here to do work and not to hold a conversation.  If you do want a conversation that's FINE BUT WHISPER.  Argh. People are super frustrating when they come in and just blab their mouth off.
author: Maxamillion D.

description:
I had a meeting close to Japantown so I decided to get some work done at one of the cafes and this was the one!

I've been here once before a few years ago. It looks the same: spacious, mellow, cozy feeling. Plenty of seating, but seating with an outlet can be tricky when everyone is trying to get their work done too. Once you establish your space, you can get a lot of work done here or at least I did. 

I ordered a honey yuzu tea for myself. It was absolutely delicious! I love tea and this one was warm, comforting, sweet, and brightening because of the citrus. Pieces of sweetened yuzu rind were at the bottom of the cup and I ate them like candy. 

Generally. a good experience with pretty good options for drinks and food and a friendly staff. I'd come back to get work done, but only if it's not too busy!
author: Sofia R.

description: Don't come here for the food, come for the convivial semi co-working aspect of the place, with great fast wi-fi, plenty of outlets and tables arranged almost like you're in the study hall of your school library. Tasty lattes and snacks keep you going -- the sweet potato one is weird but moreish -- and I recommend their amazing macaroons for a sweet and cheap sugar high. Good opening hours, a nice place to chill and a relaxed atmosphere where people don't get to noisy.
author: Zara S.

description: Great atmosphere, perfect decorations, and wide selection of baked goods! Wonderful service too!
author: Milani D.

description: Came here with my bf and a couple of friends. A couple of us ordered drinks. My bf and I were sharing a drink and quietly talking amongst ourselves when we were all very rudely told by one of the staff, "Seats are for paying customers. If you guys only have a few drinks, you should take up less seats." Had the cafe been full, I might have understood that we were taking up room, but it wasn't full. Regardless, it does not excuse the rude attitude.
author: Jay L.

description:
Great location at the heart of Japan town (also means hard to find parking), spacious interior with plenty of tables, Korean style decorations, and a variety of board games. However, drinks are mediocre at best. 

Sweet Potato Latte- delicious! Right amount of sweetness and milky-ness. Definitely can tell the sweet potato flavor in the drink, not overpowered by the sweetness. 

Yuzu tea- Too sweet! And it tasted like something you can make at home from concentrate. 

Iced Matcha Latte- Quite disappointed, the drink is pretty bland. The staff did tell me that the drink is unsweetened, and you will have to add either syrup, honey or brown sugar, which is great because you can adjust your own sweetness level (don't be surprised by how much syrup you have to add). However, the drink is just not 'matcha' enough. It mostly tasted like milk with a little bit of matcha flavor. 

Price is steep for their drinks, about $5 each. It is a great place to sit comfortably and catch up with friends though. I would pass for their drinks here next time, but try their desserts!
author: Karen C.

description:
Tried the sweet potato latte. It was definitely interesting, though probably not my kind of thing. I think it was well made--it had the right consistency and amount of milk, and the latte base flavor balanced well with the sweet potato flavor, neither being too overwhelming. But I found it to be a pretty weird combination. I can see why people would go for it, but I couldn't wrap my head around the starchy and grainy taste. I do recommend the strawberry yuzu tea though--light, refreshing, and great for warm days.

I also got some macarons--pandan, sesame, honey lavender, and green tea yuzu. All were amazing! This isn't the only place for high quality macarons in the city, but I really liked the variety of flavors, especially the more Asian ones. They don't look as great as some other places, but the flavors were all there, the insides were creamy, and the outside biscuits were crispy.
author: Tony D.

description:
The thing that drew us to this cafe was the sign outside stating that it was the "home of the sweet potato latte." Always one for trying strange new foods, my friend and I entered, excited and with high hopes for our interesting new taste bud experience.

Upon entry, we found the cafe to be adorable and spacious, with a cutesy tea shop vibe without being over the top.

We both ordered a sweet potato latte, mine with coffee, hers without. We also got the matcha shortbread, and an earl grey and Rose macaroon. 

I'll start with the good- the macaroons where DELISH! Super creamy, chewy, and sweet, while still allowing the flavor to come through. The shortbread was tasty too- it didn't stand out too much but it was decent.

Unfortunately, those lattes where such a disappointment. After the sign outside,
rave reviews from Yelp, they ended up not being super reminiscent of sweet potato and had a strange grainy texture (which, yes, I realize came from sweet potato. It could have been forgiven if the latte actually tasted like sweet potato). My latte literally just tasted like coffee, my friend's had more of a sweet potato flavor due to the lack of coffee, but it was disappointing overall. 

So, final verdict. Would I go back? Hell yes! This place was adorable and the baked goods were pretty tasty. But next time I go, I'll get a different drink.
author: Lucy C.

description:
The decision to go to YakiniQ started off with an argument about whether YakiniQ was kBBQ or a cafe. (It turned out to be both, right next to each other)

Sweet potato lattes, iced yuzu tea, and macarons in a roomy aesthetic Korean style cafe that even has board games... YakiniQ is thus hipster, divey, and whimsical all at once. Do I need to justify myself any further. 

Here are a few useful tips; I'll leave it at this rather than writing a TL;DR review proclaiming my love for cutesy Asian cafes:
- Macarons are better than La Boulange, but Chantal Guillon is the gold standard
- Sweet potato latte is non-caffeinated 
- Bathroom is in a random location through an exit in the back
- Parking garages nearby have plenty of spots if street parking fails
author: Edna C.

description: Nice and casual. Nice people. Great space. Good for working and meeting up with friends.
author: Mary N.

description:
The ambiance is amazing! Right across from the main Japantown plaza. I tried their sweet potato latte; I love how you can adjust the sweetness level of this. The other places where I've tried the sweet potato latte didn't let me adjust the sweetness and it always become too sweet for me. 

Everyone that was here around 8pm was either studying on their or having a group study session. I came in here with a friend and enjoyed our little chat for an hour or so. We kept our voices low so we wouldn't bother other people but in general, it's not super bad to be talking. The people here with group sessions are also talking so I assume those here studying are fine with that. 

Their decor is so cute; very modern. They have a full shelf in the back just filled with knick knacks and little things to look that. A great place to just end the night with a good cup of coffee or tea.
author: Polly L.

description: I wasn't terribly impressed with the macaroons. The overwhelmingly positive reviews made me expect more.
author: David C.

description: Very rude service I experienced here. The waitress had a sad face and sad tone when took my order. When I found I got black coffee instead of cappuccino, I actually said it was fine and I would take it. But the guy who made the coffee was nice and started to make me Cappuccino. Then the waitress yelled to me, this was what you ordered and you should pay extra money for cappuccino. So I paid the extra cents because I really need to charge my phone immediately . Can't believe I paid 20% tips before I got the coffee.
author: Minmin W.

description:
I will admit I was in Japantown to meet someone for lunch over the Thanksgiving holiday and didn't expect to find this cute coffee shop while walking to my car.  Even though I didn't want coffee they lured me in as their easel out front said they were making sweet potato lattes...SAY WHHHHHATT? So naturally I popped in.

Ambiance: A very large coffee shop with lots of room to sit and hang out or work. Total score: 5/5.

Service: Very friendly staff who took their time to explain their coffees to me. Total score 5/5. 

Price: Right on point for the offering and location. Total score: 5/5

What was ordered:

Sweet Potato Latte $4: Such a unique spin on the classic holiday lattes that are out right now... tasted along the line of a pumpkin latte but definitely not as sweet which I loved. If you are in the area this holiday season it is worth a stop!

Matcha Green Tea Shortbread cookies $4.95: Such a unique spin on shortbread cookies with a light green tea flavor. 

Lavender Shortbread cookies$4.95: Like the above these are a unique spin on classic shortbread cookies however the lavender is so soothing and fresh in this yummy cookie. 

If ever I am back in Japantown I will be stoping in if even just to pick up some of their yummy pastries.
author: Ashley O.

description:
This review is solely for the red bean shaved ice.

Red bean shaved ice (~5) -  Red bean and condensed milk over shaved ice. Pretty self-explanatory. The texture of the red bean was harder than what I am used to. Definitely could've cooked it for a couple minutes longer. It was still tasty though but that's probably because you can't go wrong with condensed wrong. Perfect size for 2 people to share.

They're well-known for their Sweet Potato Latte, which I found decent but not something that I'd crave.
author: Lucy N.

description: Great quiet calm atmosphere to work in. Absolutely loved their Lavender Latte. Lemon Macarons were great too!
author: Monica R.

description:
I liked this place until I found mold on my Apple Tart... The saddest thing was they never apologized me; the manager, Fumiko, kept saying "It's not our fault. The food is from other distributor". 

After I found a big mold on my cake, my husband took and showed it to the manager and the staff at the register, but their reaction was just "oh", received the plate from my husband, and went back to their work. As a former restaurant staff, I would be definitely surprised, or shocked if I found mold on customer's food. I wonder they might had the same situation many times already, and that's why they weren't surprised at all.

Of course, my husband asked for a refund, but the manager refused it at the first time. She accepted to make refund at the end, but her attitude was very rude all the time till I got the refund (just for the moldy cake). When she took my credit card to make the refund, she made me wait 10+ minutes because she was taking new customers' orders under this situation. She also told me "I refunded you just for the cake because other food were good". I almost got paralyzed by hearing what she said. I just couldn't believe she said that after she served a customer a moldy food. I couldn't stop myself asking her whether she understands what she did, and she said "yes".....

As I say, she never apologized me throughout the conversation. 
I gave my contact information, and asked the owner (she said the owner had the responsibility) to call me, but no call yet after 2 days so far. I wouldn't post this review and photo if the owner called and apologized me. I'm sorry but it's too late.

For the food, I think they can buy a extra refrigerator for those raw food on the counter so that they won't get molded. However, I don't know what they can do about those rude, un-humanized staff who don't know how to behave to their customers.

FYI, they were still selling the Apple Tart when we were leaving the place. My husband kindly warned them they should take those down, but they refused saying "it's a different batch". I wonder if they know mold does spread through the air.
author: Shihomi K.

description:
Review solely based on the sweet potato latte which was delicious! At first when j saw the reviews I was skeptical but I needed a drink and i wasn't going to go into the plaza for boba(which is mediocre) or daiso (lines too long). 

Cute cafe to hang out. Lots of space and has a small selection of snacks and drinks. 

I would have ordered some macarons but was on my way to lunch. Next time!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
This is the cutest little coffee shop I've ever seen! When you walk in, it looks like you just walked into someone's kitchen and living room. Fresh baked goods, tables and couches! I wish I lived nearby so that this could be my go-to study spot! 

But here's why I'm giving it 3 stars. I stood at the register for a bit, waiting for the two ladies behind the counter to stop talking. Bleh, minus points already..  And then, I didn't like my drink :( The little hand drawn advertisement at the register of "strawberry yuzu iced tea" looked refreshing and delicious. I asked how she would explain yuzu but she basically just said strawberry purée and yuzu tea... okay thanks... so I took a chance and ordered it anyway. I barely drank half! My second choice was the nutella latte... should've gone with that! 

I would like to come back and eat upstairs at the BBQ spot again so hopefully I can come back to the cafe again also and update my review. I really don't want to leave this cute shop with a measly 3 stars!
author: Ashley C.

description:
My roommate introduced me to this place and I absolutely love the atmosphere of it! It's definitely a nice quiet place to study with a little bit of background noise. 

Ginger Tea: I really liked this drink! If you like ginger, this ones for you! It was like a ginger ale, but Tea instead of soda! 5/5. 
Sweet Potato Latte: I know this is what they're known for, but I'm actually not a huge fan of it. :( I've given it a couple of shots, but it's just not for me. I do loveeee sweet potato, but it didn't really impress me much. I'd say a 3/5.
Green Tea Latte: Your average green tea latte. :) 4/5. 

Headsup, they have very limited tables with outlets in them. 

Btw, the bathroom smells a bit. :P
author: Tiffany J.

description:
We ordered a Sweet Potato Latte with green tea shortbread cookies and a couple of macarons. 

+ Macarons. These were quite tasty! The texture is soft and the amount of filling is perfect. 
+ Green tea shortbread cookies. These are devine! The texture is perfectly soft.. wish I got more.
- Sweet potato latte. This was a bit much. It's too sweet. Don't get me wrong, it's made of real sweet potato - but probably fitting for fall rather than on a mid summers day..

Overall, it's a cute place to sit and get some work done if you're in the area. It gets pretty packed.. Oh and the restroom is GROSS. so gross.
author: Beverly E.

description: This is my go to cafe with my friends!!  I've been here twice but it's a great place to study because we actually get work done along with the drink that we order.  I've tried the sweet potato latte and yuzu strawberry tea.  They were both good!  Their pumpkin bar is so good!  The only part is that it is a small cafe so we usually have to wait for seating but other than that a great place especially the location it's in.  Def will be coming back this semester for more studying here and trying more of their drinks/pastries!
author: Mikayla M.

description:
NEVER EVER AGAIN! I went in today to get some work done before meetings, and this place was nice. I ordered the sweet potato latte, which I will admit was good....then it happened! A BIG A** RAT RAN ACROSS THE FLOOR!

I packed my stuff up and was out of there in less than 1 minute. Thanks but no thanks. NO LATTE is that good!

EWW!
author: Ashlei T.

description: I have a Service Dog and I love coming here. The owner has always been wonderful to us, as well as the staff. Very SD friendly environment. The drinks and sweets are very tasty, my fav is the black bottom cupcake and strawberry yuzu. The atmosphere of the cafe is very quiet, chill and calm, it's a good place to sit and get work done, there's usually a lot of people on their laptops working.
author: Kitt C.

description: I walked in and the place was so cute ... but empty. I soon realized why. Very unfriendly staff. She was even sassy. I really did not want to start my day with sass. Coffee was average and so was the pastry. Won't be back.
author: Vanessa I.

description: Cute little Asian cafe! The couple of times I've been here on a weekend it's been packed. I really like the sweet potato latte as they use bits of real sweet potato to flavor it. Haven't found another place with this flavor of latte yet, so I'd come here just for this drink if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Diana C.

description: I went here back in March 2016 with some friends. I elected to get the Sweet Potato Latte and we as a group found a table and enjoyed our warm drinks and leisurely discussed our plans for the day in Japantown and Chinatown. It was a cute/relaxing cafe and my drink was unique (hard to find here in the states) and yummy. Afterwards I went about my day of adventures ....but then I returned 9-10 hours later to get a Yuzu Tea to-go because it was starting to get chilly in the late evening and this tea warmed me right up and was delicious! As I got to the bottom of the cup I started to get chunks of citron and was pleasantly surprised to know they used real citron slices, DELICIOUS!
author: Tera S.

description:
There cookies and cream cookies are the best thing I have ever tasted in my life.

The sweet potato latte is....interesting.

But damn those cookies and cream cookies are good!
author: Julianna I.

description:
I come here to study, whenever I am in the area. It's usually manageable to get a table during "peak hours."

Things I like about this cafe:
-Very nice ambiance, perfect for studying or conversing while sipping a cup of coffee
-The matcha green tea latte - I order this every time
-Very spacious between the tables, so nobody invades your little bubble
-The hip and cute decor and furniture

Things I don't like:
-The sweet potato latte
-Macarons are okay
-Rude little lady
-Not enough outlets

The reason why I gave this place a 3 star, instead of 4 or 5:
So I came here to study as usual, but I didn't order anything right away because I was waiting for a friend. While I was waiting, I was on my iPad. So the lady comes up to me and says "Are you ready to order?" I said "No, I am waiting for my friend." Then she says "You are using our wifi, order now or get out." I said okay, I will order soon. I tried to find my wallet in my bag, and she just kept standing next to me and kept saying "ORDER NOW." I replied "Don't be rude to me, lady. I said I will order."  And she just kept saying "Order now!"
 /)_- While I understand that in order to use the wifi, I need to order something, that is not the right way to treat your customers. And when I got my coffee, I told her "you know, you were very rude to me, and that is not right." She didn't say anything back -___-

The other guy who works there is really sweet and funny though. 

Sigh, my feels are hurt. Do I want to come back here? I don't know. Maybe after my heart heals hahaha
author: Solongo B.

description: I went for the macaroons and was slightly disappointed. They look incredible and have such fun flavor choices. But at the end of the day, the taste was off. They didn't taste like macaroons and some of them were very bland. If you do go, I'd say the one worth trying would be the Birthday Cake flavor.
author: Simone F.

description:
The sweet potato latte is their specialty--it's an interesting concept, because the taste of mushy, comforting sweet potato goes well with the warm comforting milky latte goodness. Definitely worth giving it a try if you haven't had it before.

The ambiance here is excellent, with interesting furniture (tiny benches, guitars, crayons, wooden horsey's etc) and warm lighting.
author: Henry L.

description:
Staying at the Hotel Kabuki for the night, I noticed great reviews for the nearby YakiniQ Cafe.   "Nearby" is right -- it's literally right across Post Street from the hotel! With all the reviews raving about their Sweet Potato Latte, I wanted to make sure to try it Sunday morning before leaving.

I thought it might be crowded with Sunday brunch visitors, but when we came in at shortly before noon on Sunday, there was no line and plenty of seating available. In fact, being used to Starbucks seating, the available space and layout here just blew me away. An amazing amount of well spaced out seating, combined with a nicely designed interior and free WiFi, makes this a wonderful café to have coffee, sweets and kick back! We have nothing close to it where I live in the far east bay.

I ordered the iced Sweet Potato Latte. First off, be aware, this is not a sweet drink, so if you really like your lattes on the sweet side, you might be disappointed. I suspect the vast majority of the customer base here does not like their coffee overly sweet, and for them this hits the spot.

For me, this latte definitely earns points for uniqueness -- the Sweet Potato taste is quite pronounced. However, it's really not sweet at all, and I do like a decent amount of sweetness for my coffee, so for me (and especially my wife), it fell short.
author: David F.

description:
The sweet potato latte was awesome! Very soothing drink indeed - a little fibrous, but that just proves to me that it's freshly made of real sweet potato. 

Also tried the Yuzu Palmer, which was tea & a yuzu beverage as well, while it was very nice it just made me want to try something that was purely yuzu, as it was the stand out flavor.

Had a Pandan macaron as well, and it tasted great! Pandan always reminds me a bit of pistachio, and this macaron was fresh & had the right amount of chew & cream. The location itself was really relaxing & would've been a great place to do some studying or working.
author: Chelsea C.

description: This is such a cute coffee shop in Japan town. The coffee was amazing & they have wifi but the password they gave me was incorrect & I didn't want to bug them again.
author: Alisa A.

description:
I think this is one of few places that have a very comfortable and homey seating area. The lady who work here is very nice a and attentive. I came over to this place when I visited San Fransisco for the weekend and decided to try this place as recommended by a friend of mine. I orderded the green tea and spam musubi. Such an awesome Snack on a chill day. 

The musubi is perfect in size and very flavorful. The not so sweet green tea balances the savory flavor of the spam musubi. Definitely a must go and hangout place or even reading a book due to its homey ambience.
author: Andreas R.

description: This is a great cafe to study/work in! It creates a comforting space to concentrate - there are tables next to the walls, and a couch in the middle of the room with a bookshelf behind it. Also, their Yuzu tea is REALLY GOOD!
author: Olivia H.

description:
YakiniQ Cafe is located underneath the famed AYCE Korean/Japanese BBQ YakiniQ, and they share the same bathroom. That being said, YakiniQ Cafe is a cute, little Korean style cafe that has delightful decorations and feels cozy and homey. They have amazing drinks, such as their sweet potato latte (which doesn't actually contain coffee-- but still super delicious.) The prices are not too bad unless you get something like an iced strawberry yuzu tea (which I also looove) and they don't take cards unless you order more than $6. :) I have not tried the sandwiches here, but the food can be hit or miss. I ordered spam musubis on two separate occasions, and one time reminded me of home in Hawaii... The other time, the spam was fine but the rice was super over or undercooked. It was hard and dry and was not great :/ 

There's lots of space to study and spread out, so bring your stuff and come study here! It's also very quiet. There aren't many outlets, so I would not bring your laptop. They have a couch you can sit on, and a big communal table for solo customers willing to share space. Otherwise, I really do enjoy YakiniQ as a study place (though find a space with bright lighting! It can get a bit dim at times.) 

I would recommend the sweet potato latte or the iced yuzu tea (with or without strawberry.) You get chunks of sweet potato and yuzu in the options listed above (which means they're making it with great ingredients!)
author: Christa Lei S.

description:
The sweet potato latte is a must for all sweet potato lovers. The flavor is rich yet far from being artificially. The only other place I tried a sweet potato latte in San Francisco was Joy's Place and both were delicious. We also got the green tea shaved ice. It is not the very soft shaved ice (bingsoo) or snow, so the textual was not what I expected. This is regular shaved ice you would expect on your ice cone.

The cafe itself seems like a regular study/work spot. There is not much chattering. The interior design is very comfortably and welcoming, kind of like a large living room! The staff was also friendly.
author: Eva C.

description:
Food is just okay but the space is nice. Outlets only on one wall.
They have assortment of boardgames that you can play.
Quiet enough to study but not so quiet that you feel awkward talking.
author: Michelle K.

description:
While in SF recently, we decided to grab a cold drink at YakiniQ Cafe. I fell in love with the seating area with chairs, tables and nice, comfy couches. After perusing the menu, we ordered a Sweet Potato latte and Nutella latte.

We grabbed the drinks from the counter and comfortably got ourselves seated at one of the tables. The sweet potato drink was a dud; I couldn't taste sweet potatoes and it was tasteless.

Nutella was good!!!
author: Anu M.

description: Such a sweet cafe. If you've lived in Japan you will appreciate the vibe. The staff is cool, the drinks and snacks are tasty, and the music is good. While I've been there I've sat among students studying, teachers meeting, tourists relaxing, girlfriends meeting up and lots of folks reading. Whenever I go to J'town this is my destination. Yoroshiku!
author: D. D.

description:
What a nice little neighborhood hangout. The decor is quirky and fresh and the layout of tables is welcoming to parties of a variety of sizes, from couples to a small group that came to play with some of the offered board games. 

My group of three tried the mint tea, yuzu tea, and the famous sweet potato iced latte. We also snacked on apple pie and "the best macaroons in the city!!" (Claims the SF native I was with)
