The highlight for me was, without a doubt, the rose macaroon. Holy cats! It was worth every calorie ;) the raspberry and chocolate flavors were a close second. The pistachio macaroon was pretty awesome too. The apple pie was delightful and the slice we received was large enough for two people to share.

I'm definitely making a mental note of this place to take my future SF visitors here for a coffee break or sweet tooth snack.
author: Andrea H.

description:
A nice place to spend your afternoon. The rose macarons are really exotic, it feels like you're eating the rose flower, both nice and weird at the same time!
The down side is that they have a very narrow selection of board games with some of them missing parts. So we couldn't find a cool game to play, but they have chess and cards if that's want you're into.
author: Ameneh G.

description:
Surprisingly decent french macarons:
-Fine earl grey with strong fennel/old people flavor if you're into that sort of thing
-Pistachio was okay
-Rose was great, chewy texture and the filling wasn't overly sweet

Others:
-Good matcha shortbread cookies that that actually have distinguishable matcha green tea taste
-Green tea shaved ice was a joke, huge cup of plain crushed ice with a dollop of Mitchell's green tea ice cream on top, some plain mochie, red beans, and a few jellies, offended by this version of "shaved ice"

Atmosphere:
-Nice cutesy atmosphere but too uncomfortably(/repressively?) quiet
author: Tian Q.

description: Good macaroons. The place gets crowded with laptops but it's a nice, cozy and fairly quiet place to read, work, sip and socialize near Japantown.
author: Ebi B.

description:
Cute and spacious Asian style coffee shop :-) a comfortable place to have a chat, study or work over a cup of sweep potato latte. They have a pretty big beverage menu (bunch of special lattes) and good looking desserts.

Sweet potato latte was pretty unique. Can add a shot, or get it without sugar since it is naturally sweet. Got nutella latte the other time, it was pretty good and I found real nutella at the bottom of my cup in the end.

Accepts credit card for $6+. Wifi might not be the fastest, but not a big deal. Big communal table in the middle.
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
Came here for some dessert after my boyfriend's not very successful birthday dinner. Located in Japan Town, YakiniQ is a very cute and modern little cafe shop located next to the YakiniQ dining restaurant. 

My boyfriend ordered the sweet potato latte, which many other Yelpers have recommended, while his sister ordered the green tea latte. Also ordered a few macarons, a cheesecake, and a coffee crumb cake. Everything came out fairly quickly. Lots of small tables for people to sit and study or chat. Music is playing in the background, and it's just a very nice place to sit and chill. 

The sweet potato latte was indeed unique, but it's not for everybody. I like sweet potato, but I wasn't a fan of it in the blended drink form. I could smell the sweet potato and it really tasted legit, but ... just too different than what I am used to. My boyfriend's sister said the green tea latte was good, but nothing special. I believe the cheesecake and coffee crumb cake were also good, but I didn't try them. The macarons were pretty delicious. They're $2.25 each, which is quite pricey as they're a lot smaller than the macarons at 'Lette or Bottega in LA. But they are definitely good and tasty. The outside is soft and crumbly, and the filling is a melt in your mouth tastiness. I read from another review that they are from Phillipe's. I wonder if that's true and if all their desserts are from someplace else. 

I tried the rose, champagne and the passion fruit. All very good. The rose and champagne tasted very similar, except the rose flavor was more prominent than in the champagne one (the champagne macaron tasted like rose basically). The passion fruit was decent and tasted like passion fruit, but I prefer my macarons of a sweeter variety. I like that they have games and cards on the shelves that you can take and borrow. 

It's a very nice place to sit and catch up and eat dessert. It's a little pricey for my taste, but worth the money. I'm not too big of a fan of latte or coffee or tea without the boba, but I believe the drinks are decent. Definitely give this place a try if you're in the area or if you need a place to sit and catch up!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Really cute place in Japantown with plenty of seating. There were a lot of people at the tables studying/working. It's a great cafe to meet and talk with friends too. The service was friendly and quick.

I ordered the iced sweet potato latte ($4) and green tea macaron ($2.50).  It was a $6 minimum to use your credit card. Both were really good and I would definitely get it again. The sweet potato was particularly interesting I had never had a drink like that before. I liked that there were little pieces of sweet potato at the bottom.
author: Linda X.

description:
This place is more like 3.5 stars.

The cafe itself is pretty cute but since my favorite spot in LA called Royal/T decided to close their doors, I just compare all japanese cafes to them. I know it's unfair but that's what I use as my standard.

It appears it's a great place to study since there are enough tables and outlets, and they do have free wifi that is password protected. It's a great place to hang out with friends too to grab a cup of coffee and a bite to eat if you are in the area, and want a place that's pretty laid back.

The reason I think it's more 3.5 stars rather than 4 stars was I wasn't impressed with the coffee and desserts here. I got their popular sweet potato latte and my fiance just got a regular latte. The regular latte was alright...nothing special. We actually were not a fan of the sweet potato latte. It really was a liquified sweet potato. I think I was expecting something smoother and creamier with a hint of sweet potato taste. But I felt like I was just taking a bite into a sweet potato. Also got two macarons and they were fairly good but thought the price of $2.25 each was overpriced. Alot of their desserts I think were overpriced actually....
author: Kristina L.

description:
YakiniQ, home of the sweet potato latte. This cafe has many novelty drinks in addition to a selection of macarons. I say novelty because that's exactly what they are. I could enjoy a couple good sips at most. The sweet potato latte doesn't actually have any coffee. I'm pretty sure it was just a combination of puréed sweet potato with steamed milk. Another new option was the pumpkin latte, which I'm guessing isn't anything close to the pumpkin spice latte from Starbucks. I also tried the nutella latte, another specialty drink served in a bowl with a long spoon. I think the spoon was for scrapping the nutella stuck to the bottom of the bowl. The drinks were more attention-grabbing than impressive. 

There were about eight or so different flavors of macarons, which included: hazelnut, espresso, green tea yuzu, earl grey, rose, pistachio, chocolate, and passion fruit. I tried the green tea yuzu and earl grey. Interesting flavors, but not the best macarons by any stretch. They were very sweet and too chewy. 

The one thing that I really liked about YakiniQ was the atmosphere and interior design. It felt very homey, a cross between someone's really nicely decorated, Ikea-furnished living room and a library. It felt like a good place to study or pump out that thesis paper. The space is large with multiple tables, which makes it great for groups. They also have a number of board games on the back wall to entertain customers. There is a $10 credit card minimum, otherwise cash only.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
This is a nice cafe to spend some time in. The space is quite large and everyone is quite spread out so it does feel like a nice place to sit down and hang out with friends. 
The menu offering is quite large here, from macaroons to shaved ice to sweet potato lattes. Not everything was a hit with me, but I don't expect a place that offers such variety to do so. 
The drinks were what stood out to me. They had a lot of interesting flavours and combinations, I got the sweet potato latte and was not disappointed. 
I also got the shaved ice and the macaroons and they were ok, nothing I would come back for though.
author: Derwei C.

description:
1.5 stars - and that's just for the decent ambiance

The sweet potato latte? AVOID. I'm not even sure why that's their bestseller. If that's the best thing they have, I am not even going to waste my money on the others. People probably only get this because it's unique. Well...go ahead, take your candied yams from Thanksgiving, throw it in a blender, and add milk. There, you just saved yourself ~$4 and won't feel as bad if you have to throw it away because you don't like the idea of drinking liquid candied yam. That's basically what it is.

Macarons? DOUBLE AVOID. Those of you who think this is the best macaron in the city are grossly misguided. Do a search for macarons on Yelp and you will find the true good places. Also, charging $2.25 for crappy macarons is too expensive. It's like...on par with Berkeley Bowl's macarons (that's pretty bad too), but at least Berkeley Bowl's are only $1 each. The macarons here were chewy instead of light and airy (that high quality French feeling in your mouth), and were ridiculously sweet. True French macarons are not like this. However, props to them for the unique flavors: green tea yuzu and pumpkin are two I had. I also had passionfruit and hazelnut.  I wish I didn't order so many...if I had known they were not high quality, I would not have.

The only good thing about this place is the décor and ambiance. Even at that, the place is rather small, and the bathroom is a bit ghetto. I know it's SF and real estate and cleanliness are hard to come by...but the pictures on Yelp make it look much nicer than it actually is.

I'd be willing to try YakiniQ BBQ, but do not ever need to come to this café again. Blargh.
author: Esther Y.

description:
HUGE QUIET SPACE.

i'd love to take my laptop and work here if i could. They have a lot of open space with tables on the sides and a coffee table with a couch in the middle. It's quiet; which is pretty surprising for a cafe but I guess everyone's busy/reading/working? Music is turned down low. Even the staff speaks with a lower voice.

dropped in to just grab a drink while passing through Japan town and had a matcha green tea latte. LOVE how refreshing and light it is for a latte. also perfect amount of sweetness so that I can actually taste the matcha. yum!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I come here when I know I want to be alone to get work done. I want to give this place a higher review since i come so often, but a couple of things prevent me from doing so:

1. Super few outlets. I know they're trying to cut back from using too much energy, but the square feet ratio to the number of outlets is abysmal. Only one side of the cafe has any outlets, and the tables with outlets are super small. It's hard to spread out and get work done with a table that I can barely keep my elbows on. That side is also kind of dark, so unless you're working on just your computer, I wouldn't sit there. All of the larger tables do not have outlets, so bring your laptop charged or don't bring it at all. 

2. The prices are a bit higher than regular cafes...and I wouldn't mind if their food and drinks weren't so hit or miss or not worth it because you don't get as much product as you would at other places. Their coffees and espressos aren't too bad. I actually quite like their yuzu drinks and I'm a fan of their sweet potato drinks (though they're not for everyone). But $6+ for a slice of cake is kind of ridiculous especially when they're not super special. The macarons are good though, and those are expensive no matter where you go so that's okay.

Those are my two biggest gripes to be honest. Otherwise this is a solid #3 on my list of cafes to work at since they're so far and few in San Francisco that really remind me of an Korean style cafe.
author: Alison M.

description: A nice place to talk to friends...lots of tables and seating. I tried Peppermint Mocha Latte, Sweet Potato Latte and Yuzu Honey Tea. The peppermint mocha was alright, it tastes like candy canes...sweet potato latte had real sweet potatoes, so that was pretty good for being real and not powder. Yuzu honey tea, I haven't had it in a long time. The tea probably came from a jar but it was delicious! Now I'm thinking about buying a jar of that and drinking it all the time.
author: Kylie L.

description:
I guess it's an okay café. I mean, you get to have some quiet time and there's usually not a lot of people that come to hang around here. The café is really quiet compared to coffee chains like Peet's and Starbucks. I ordered a brownie and hot chocolate and it was SO GOOD. The hot chocolate was steamy and it filled my face with happiness. The brownie was not too sweet and not too bland, so it was just right. 

Also, there's a stack of magazines and books in the corner near where the beverages are made and where the cashier stands. They have to be kept in the café, though.

If you need to use the bathroom, it's in the very back of the café and you will need to turn left and that's where the men's and women's bathrooms are.
author: Yuuki T.

description: Great service. Nice coffee. Quite and warm place. This place is perfect for people who wanna work or study during the day.
author: Nnan C.

description: The desserts are way too sweet and the Red bean shaved ice is Terrible! It's not a drink, instead a big bowl of PLAIN ice with poor amount of red beans on top of it
author: Monica X.

description:
I love this place! It's a cute place to hang out at. If I am working on something, I like coming here to get a cup of coffee and a little pastry or salad while I do my work. This is a pretty popular place, so it's possible you won't be able to find a seat.

One time, I came here with a friend. We found a piece of hair in our salad, which was pretty disgusting. We told the cafe about it, and they didn't do anything. They just said sorry, and they didn't offer us anything else, like a new salad... which is why I only give this place three stars. It's also a little pricey...

Just watch for any hair in your food, and you'll be good to go! *Note the sarcasm.
author: Dee F.

description:
Sweet Potato Latte!!! You will not believe how delish!!! Sipping heaven!! This place is hidden and huge! Very cute decor!! Quiet spacious, cute snacks and treats. I will never come to J town without getting a latte
Run don't walk yum!!
author: Cecilia D.

description:
OK MINUS ONE GIANT STAR BECAUSE LITTLE LADY MANNING THE REGISTER IS RUDE AF. 

Other than that I love this place!

Came here on a Friday afternoon to do some work, and I really dig the quiet ambiance and vibe this place has.  It's super spacious and dimly lit and people always range from super quiet to hushed talking.  I ordered an iced coffee with almond milk, but they have a huge selection of drinks as well as a ton of food to choose from. The macaroons were pretty large and looked so yummy but I didn't end up getting any.  

RULES (according to tiny paper signs taped all over the register)
They are cash only under $6.
You need to be a customer to use the wifi. Otherwise it is top secret and no one will tell you.
You can only use the outlets for 1 hour. 

Even though I am not a big fan of the attitude the woman had, I feel like she knows here place is awesome and that people will still come here no matter how big of a **** she is being to them hahahah I actually overheard her talking to one of her friends that came in and she suddenly became all friendly and happy and talkative, what a 180 from what I experienced.  So it's only a front guys, she does have a heart. 

I will definitely be back if I am ever in the area to do some work though. This place is great for that.
author: Christina L.

description: the new cashiers are very unprofessional!!,  maybe they don't like their job, owners need to be get some new people there
author: Mason C.

description: A nice little cute shop right in Japan Town and next to the all you can eat Korean bbq buffet. I love the decor of this cafe. A nice place to just relax and study. I would definitely recommend their iced strawberry yuzu tea. The drink is so refreshing and delicious. There are some yuzu peels in the drink but it didn't bother me. It actually tastes good. I would sometimes go here while I wait in line for the Korean bbq.
author: Peter N.

description: drinks are below average when it comes to taste. the place looks great. SERVICE SUCKS!!!! (Ukranian Girl) is sooooo RUDE!
author: Janvier J.

description: relaxed vibes all around, very spacious, quiet cafe to do some work on a weekend or read a book. There are about 10 tables and a nice couch setup in the middle. Snacks/coffee are great -- I had the lavender cookies. If I lived in SF this would probably be my go-to!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Cute place and pretty good service. The specialty drinks are on the very sweet side. 

One note, if you're coming here to do some work:
- make sure your battery's fully charged. Only a few outlets along the walls and they're very hard to come by.
- wifi can get very slow
author: Esther K.

description:
They are not JAPANESE here. I see reviews saying how the Japanese Cafe are, but they're not Japanese. 

Customer service lacks here. I don't know if this is cultural or a snobby worker?  Not very responsive when you are talking to them.  Just go, and you will see right away. 

DO NOT get shaved ice. I wanted my money back. I ordered greentea shaved ice and the only thing that was greentea was tiny teeny greentea ice cream. Pathetic and unbelievable. 

The coffee was normal but I just don't see why i would come back here.
author: Jorge T.

description:
Upon walking into this cafe, you are greeted with a sea of calmness. The decor, lighting, and set up are so inviting, and it's easy to feel at home here. And it's great to get work done here. 

There are a lot of creative and yummy sounding drinks and snacks here, but I opted for the sweet potato latte. It really tasted like sweet potatoes! And I love the fact that you could get your drinks made with soy or almond milk, but the cost is a little steep ($0.75).

The workers are also super friendly.
author: Rachel H.

description:
We walked in this quaint little coffee shop right after a heavy meal next door (YakiniQ BBQ), and let me tell you -- I STILL managed to make room for a deliciously hot sweet potato latte w/ a lavender infused truffle on the side ~

Granted it's not the most loaded afterthought, should've seen my "caveman" feast beforehand..for a second there I thought I needed help walking back to my car! However, the sweet and warm aroma of this charming and picturesque sister-shop simply couldn't be ignored by all of my senses. 

Decked-out, hip, cozy, inviting, and trendy, the mismatched interior welcomes the offbeat persona and diversity from its guests, who are as unique and charismatic as the décor portrays. 

Great selection of drinks, pastries, and sweets! Awesome place to kick back during any lazy afternoon.
author: Kurt C.

description:
My personal favorite coffee shop/study spot in the city. The staff is very pleasant and likes to get to know their customers. Plays light music, a mix of acoustic covers of top 40 songs and classical music. Great place to catch up with an old friend over coffee (or a sweet potato latte) or catch up on your reading/studying.

Note: you may not have access to a wall charger on busy times like the weekends/some weekday evenings. There is technically an "hour limit" to a table next to an power outlet, if you don't mind asking a stranger to evacuate their seat for you and then receive occasional death glares from them for the rest of the day
author: Frank L.

description:
This place is so beautiful, a place I could sit forever. It's like how you hope by being near beautiful things, some of the loveliness will rub off by proximity. It's spacious and not too bright, but certainly fine for extended reading time.  

The macarons were excellent - especially the earl grey + yuzu. The flavors were subtly pronounced. 
The cassis macaron was really pretty, but I thought it was a little too sweet to taste the cassis flavor.
author: Lydia N.

description:
It felt more like study hall or a library. Anything above a whisper felt disruptive so we left immediately after finishing up the shaved ice because quite frankly, it felt uncomfortable. I found the entitled complaints about the free wifi signal or lack of sufficient outlets comical as if this cafe is required to provide a study hall like environment. But once you step in, everyone is on laptops (mostly by themselves) or in their books so the ambiance make it a bit difficult for someone who is not here to work but dropped by to catch up with a friend. 

The shaved ice was well-made and was a nice cold treat. I wished the ice had a finer shave but that's my own personal preference. They had a decent selection of other goodies/pastries. I haven't had a chance to have their sweet potato latte but will do should I choose to drop by next time.  I loved that they offer yuzu tea. Delicious. 

Both employees (owners?) were attentive, hard working and friendly.
author: Esther A.

description: Stopped in on a rainy sun afternoon and got a delicious cup of ginger honey tea. Almost every seat in the cafe was taken by ppl on their laptops or reading books. Environment was very cozy and warm especially on a rainy day. Will come back to try their other drinks and baked goods.
author: Yin H.

description:
Love it here! such a cute little coffee shop mixed with snacks and good drinks, it might take a little while to order, but their drinks are delicious.

Its such a cute and quaint place to study or just chat with friends.

I've been here on multiple occasions and enjoyed it every time.
author: Kristin I.

description:
YakiniQ Cafe is chill, homey. 

On any given sunny Sunday afternoon, you'd find the place light up in just the perfect proportions of natural sunlight and indoor incandescent. The assortment of furniture old, new, vintage, and colorful makes this place feel just like how mom used to make em.

The coffee is, at best, average according to the citywide SF standards. However, in comparison to the other coffee places around Japantown, the coffee here can be considered pure awesome. 

Unfortunately, the WiFi is very slow. I don't blame them though - I'm sure there's someone downloading stuff when they shouldn't be.
author: Don L.

description:
This place is really quiet and mellow. You'll catch a lot of people reading and or studying here. It's right across the street from the Japantown mall and fairly close to downtown. 

My favorite thing about this cafe, is the Sweet Potato latte! It's so good! It tastes and smells just like the holidays. There's really nothing like it. I've yet to find a latte to top it! They serve it iced as well. But I suggest ordering it hot. They also have a good amount of baked goods to snack on. I usually order my Sweet Potato Latte with green tea shortbread cookies, or a couple of macarons. All of which are really good. I haven't tried their food yet. But I definitely will try when I have time.
author: Claudia A.

description: Almost immediately walked back out because the counter girl was so rude. Greeted her with a "hi,  how are you?"  and received a stiff "tired"  no smile,  no "how can I help you?"  Just an angry stare. Got through the ordering process and she became more open and I tried to be more open to a different personality. Yuzu poundcake was delicious and iced soy latte was good. Cozy place.
author: Romina L.

description:
YakiniQ Cafe is the place to go to escape the cold winds when it gets late at night in Japantown. This cozy little cafe is home of the quaint, vintage, tea-party-like feng shui with their mismatched furniture and colorful pieces. This place is popular so it's always kinda full and it isn't too spacious either... but come on in and order yourself a delicious treat to keep yourself warm! 

Their hot item is the Sweet Potato Latte which pretty much tastes like liquid sweet potato. It's good but I don't think it like AMAZING. It's a little thick and starchy compared to a regular latte. It's worth the taste if you want to try something novel. Otherwise my go-to favorite would be a regular chai latte :)

Lots of fun desserts to choose from if you've got a sweet tooth. The few times I've stopped by here was either after kbbq (so completely full) or before dinner (trying to save space!) so I haven't gotten to try anything off their dessert menu yet!

Pros:
-cute place to study if you can snag a table
-fun menu, fun treats!
author: Grace J.

description:
This place is a great environment to work on homework, because it's as quiet as a library. 

The dessert tastes good, but I prefer going somewhere because it's expensive and comes in small portions. Other than that it's pretty darn good.
author: Hina W.

description:
Very misleading, because Yakiniku 焼き肉 is in many ways, Japanese approach to Korean BBQ (over charcoal). And they don't serve animal protein here. So FOBenese dude was like WTF at first.

But it is a coffee house first and foremost with a range of desserts and drink. The offerings definitely tilt more towards the American/Western side, with not much in the way of fusion or Asian (although certainly one or two influences...like green tea this, matcha that).

It seems like a nice place to hang out, or camp/study like what a lot of "students" appear to be doing.

The yuzu honey tea isn't terribly different than the Korean yuzu citron honey jam drinks you can get at most Hong Kong cafes (or Cooking Papa for that matter) or stuff from Chinese/Korean supermarkets that you can make at home. But to their credit it is less sugary sweet, and a tad smoother in finish.

The mango mousse cake is pretty decent....somewhat close to Sheng Kee or Sogo Bakery versions, maybe a tad thicker in consistency... but it is a whooooooooping $7. 

But otherwise...not quite my style. 

Anyone up for lining up for 2+ hours at 85C bakery otherwise? :-o 

I kid.
author: Ken K.

description:
It has so much potential to be a great cafe for work, it's a shame that it just didn't work out right.

Cons: 
- not enough power outlets
- the wifi is quite slow and unstable
- food and drink are overpriced

That's enough reason to keep me from coming back to this place even though I live just a few blocks away. 

If you don't plan to work there, I guess it's decent, but the service is a bit cold, and there are better coffee shops nearby.

(woah I sound like a jerk, I'm sorry)
author: Rachel Z.

description:
My new favorite study spot and cafe :]!

These are my criteria for study / work spots: 

(1) Atmosphere? Yakini Q is such a cute cafe! I love how the chairs are all mismatched. It looks like a living room which makes it an extra comfy space. When I went on a Friday, there were quite a few people studying and working on their laptops and grabbing coffee and socializing.

(2) Wifi? Wifi is free and password protected. I was there for about 3 hours yesterday and no one gave me the stink eye.

(3) Caffeine? Apparently, Yakini has really great and creative drinks. Yelpers seem to love their sweet potato latte, for instance. Since I had already had my morning tea and didn't get to the cafe until the afternoon, I skipped out on a drink, but they are apparently very tasty.

(4) Lots of seats and outlets? Yakini offers an assortment of seating arrangements - a couch, a large communal table, some tables that can seat 4, and some tables for 2. Only the tables on one side of the cafe have outlets. This was a bummer because I had to leave when my laptop ran out of batteries and all the outlet seats were full!

(5) Food? Yakini offers a lot of cute cakes and desserts. I overheard a patron telling the lady at the counter that the cake he ate was one of the best that he's ever had, and the woman told him that the desserts are made in house. Yakini also offers onigiri (rice balls), sandwiches, salads, and spam masubi. I had the "banh mi" (see picture), which was about $9 and came with a small side salad. It was a tasty enough sandwich, with tender chicken (with some sort of glaze - teriyaki maybe?), cucumber, lettuce, carrots, mayo, and chili sauce. It was tasty!
author: Eileen E.

description:
FOOD:

Came here with a friend and split the shaved ice and sweet potato latte. The shaved ice was HUGE, but the toppings were scarce, so we were left with a considerable pile of ice at the end. We asked for more condensed milk, since it was so scarce, but they said it would cost extra. It wasn't really special, but it was a nice treat.

As for the sweet potato latte, it literally tasted like liquid sweet potatoes. There was a ton of foam on the top and chunks at the bottom and I wasn't really a fan so I didn't even finish it.

They had a bunch of macarons and other baked goods that I wanted to try, but we just ate lunch somewhere else so I was too full. 

SERVICE: 

Despite the mediocre food, the cafe itself is super cute! They have a ton of classic books and games to keep you entertained, though you can't take anything home, which makes sense, but then you need to go back to read the book.

There is plenty of seating of all types; tables, couches, benches, galore! 

Also, they have fun artwork on the walls that make the room feel homey.
author: Erika S.

description:
I've never actually eaten their food, but I've had one or two teas here and blah blah blah blah that's not the point. The point is that I love this place's ambiance for hanging out with friends either as a destination in itself or, as is most often, a waypoint between two other events.

Everything about this place goes together just right: the wall decorations, the blank wall space, the trinkets on the shelves, the trinkets not on the shelves, the board games, the curated music, the choice of lighting and furniture, the inviting aromas, the colors, and the kind if demure manner of the staff.

That's all I'm going to say. I'm keeping it cozy, just like the unified experience that is YakiniQ. I'm also keeping this review small in reflection of the fact that I don't wholeheartedly want to review this place because part of me would rather keep YakiniQ among my friends and the present clientele.
author: Dan B.

description:
I always come here when stopping by Japantown for anything; not only is the interior super charming and cute, with a really vintage-country feel, but the food and drinks are really excellent. They specialize in a sweet potato latte, which I've tried and is definitely different, but my personal favorite is their yuzu honey tea. It's like a really good lemonade but better.

There's also free wifi and plenty of tables and couches for studying and hanging out, and there's a collection of books and board games to keep you entertained as well. Definitely a gem that deserves it's slightly-hidden feel.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Drinks = good
Macaron = delicious (and they were worth every red cent!!!!) 
Prices = moderate.

I'll have to come back here and try more stuff...:D
author: Fannie S.

description:
YakiniQ is super cute! A great place to study or enjoy a cup of coffee with a friend. The place itself is spacious, relatively quiet and clean, and it's conducive to productivity.

Some menu items are a bit pricey. Drinks are reasonable, but the pastry items are overpriced. $2.50 for a macaron? Still got one anyways, and it was good, but not $2.50  good.
author: Suji C.

description: The fool that I was, I was in Jtown and yelped the nearest 4-star coffee shop. I was led to this place and ordered the Matcha (spelled "Macha") latte which was devoid of any hint or taste of green tea matcha (although the only indication that it was matcha was the green color). Simply put, it tasted like glorified hot milk with the semblance of green food coloring. The latte was also pricier than the far better and authentic matcha latte's I have had in SF.  This place just falls short of being a hype. To add salt to the wound, as there were no seats available in the cafe, I sat near the waiting area near the cash register in hopes of scoring a seat later on.  But, alas, the stern cashier lady asked me to leave as I was not allowed to "camp" in the seats near the door after paying for the expensive "Macha" latte (where was I supposed to sit and do my work?). Hence, I respectfully left. I hope no one ever goes through that again.
author: Savio C.

description:
For all the CPA's out there I admire you, and if you are on track to getting one I feel ya my friend you are not alone. 

It's a sh** ton of studying for an exam, therefore, I NEED a place to study outside my sleep-inducing home. A friend recommended YakiniQ.

Came in on Tuesday at around 4, and it was pretty full. IMPORTANT: the ONLY outlets are on the right side of the store where the 2-top tables are. So if you need to use your laptop a lot this might not be the right place. 

Location: next to the Yakini restaurant. It was windy and they had no sign in the street so I got a little confused. Close to japan town so it's generally hard to find parking.

Ambiance: open space. Comfy. Nice, artsy decor. They sell the paints in the wall. Props for helping local artists :) 

Food: lots of option ranging from sandwiches to pastries.

Fruit tart $6.95: expensive @.@. Although the fruit was really fresh and ripe  ( mine had grapes, figs, raspberries), the filling was dry. For the price, it wasn't worth it. 

Spam musubi $2.75: Cheap, tasty. They serve the soy sauce on the side.

Drinks:

Sweet potato latte $3.5: really tasty. It actually tastes like sweet potato, and even has pieces of it. A bit chunky. Must try if you like different. 

YuZu honey tea ~$3.75 SO good. It was so flavorful and made feel so cozy. Best I've had. 

All in all a nice cozy place to study. Apparently it attracts people that speak really loud, or maybe it was just that day. Anyways, bring your earphones. And if you are one of those people, please be considerate and talk at low to moderate voice levels. Students really appreciate your kind cooperation. 

Peace.
author: Mily W.

description:
Beautiful  place and relaxed  environment. 
I love my hot chocolate.  The staff are wonderful
people.
author: Adrian S.

description:
Things I didn't like about this cafe were :
They serve all drinks in paper cups. 
Pastry I ordered was stale.
Things I liked were: 
Nice big place with a lot of tables.
Music was classical and soft.
author: Charles S.

description:
Trying to keep it short and sweet since I'm supposed to be in San Jose in an hour but I'm sitting here writing this review instead-

+ Adorable/cool/quirky decor! I love their choice of cute mismatched furniture and art. It gives the cafe a cozy, home-y feel without being drab or tacky.
+ The drinks. I just tried their iced mint mocha (with an extra shot of espresso) and I'm impressed with how smooth it tastes. I also appreciate how even though I can definitely taste the mint and chocolate flavors in the mocha, they don't overwhelm the taste of the coffee. A lot of cafes' mochas taste strongly of powdered chocolate, but not YakiniQ's!
+ The macarons. I just tried the earl grey tea macaron and think I found God?? STRONG earl grey tea taste, which I adore. Wow. Next time I'm getting five.
+ The service!!! Everyone that works here is super friendly and nice as well as efficient - you can tell they love their jobs. Steve and Sammi are especially great!
author: Katherine V.

description: Good place to study, but it only has outlets on one side of the cafe. The pastries and macarons they have are ok but nothing spectacular.
author: Johanna T.

description:
Absolutely love, love, love this place!

We came in thinking that YakiniQ BBQ was open at 4, when they really opened at 5 so we decided to stop in and get something to drink.

THERE IS SO MUCH TO CHOOSE FROM. Oh god I was overwhelmed.  I had given up coffee drinks for more than a week, but their menu was too good to resist!  My  boyfriend and I got the peppermint mocha with an extra shot of espresso as well as a couple macaroons.  So good, so good.

By the way this is definitely the study spot.  All the tables were filled with students and macbooks.  Crazy.

Japantown isn't usually a destination for us, but if we're ever around the area, we're definitely coming back!
author: Eleanor E.

description:
Cute little cafe, some pastries on display. A little dark inside, but I guess it gives more of a lounge effect. I ordered an iced yuzu tea. It wasn't good. I've had better instant tea from home, and it sure wasn't worth $4 for the little cup. 

Yuzu Tea:
http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=SrDNzW2fZFNnl_rrcX5pAQ&userid=ZctVNNz-eQUZQzsU9qhQBQ
author: Kayla R.

description:
YakiniQ Cafe is in SF Japantown on Post St, not in the Malls.  Tried their Sweet Potato Latte $3.50 with tax $3.80.  It's nice looking in a mug, but I'm just not a fan of drinking something with lots of bits of sweet potato, no coffee taste, though it sounded interesting to me.

Next time I'll get the Hazelnut Latte or Almond Latte $3.95.  

Cozy place with a bunch of tables/chairs.  Some books & games if you want to do that.

Many desserts: pies, French macarons, cookies looked good.

Credit card minimum $10 to use.  Had to pay Cash.
author: Ann L.

description: Sweet potato latte was decent enough. Picked up a pandan, earl grey, honey lavender, and green tea macaroon which were really tasty. However, the service is extremely poor. I ended up drinking my latte in the cafe and witnessed three of five potential patrons walk out. As soon as they walked in the barista would yell, "Can you wait? I can't help you I'm busy making food. You can leave if you don't want to wait. Don't wait for me." I don't why I opted to wait. Not likely to come back as barista is blatantly rude.
author: Thao V.

description:
YakiniQ Cafe has the potential to be a top tier cafe in Japantown. The cookies were 2 star at best and were incredibly bland. The pound cake with marmalade was nothing I would recommend nor order again. The teas come in tea bags and there is no Hochi cha in a Japanese cafe. 

I lived in Japan and know how special Japanese cafes can be with their sweets. I think the staff should be more focused on their quality and be more Japanese in their cooking. The cafe is always full and the free internet is helpful for those doing work or enjoying their cafe time.
author: Greg O.

description:
Red bean on the shave ice too sweet.

Spacious.

Slow wifi (~3 Mbps).
author: Inigo M.

description:
This is a cute little bakery in Japan town. I didn't eat any of their pastries... Which looked delicious. I just stuck with a simple bagel and cream cheese. But I did order a latte which was one of the best I've ever had! 

They have free wifi and a nice cosy lounge area if you want to get some work find or catch up with a friend.
author: Toni J.

description: This cafe has a relaxing atmosphere and sweet coffee drinks. I'm giving this place one star because of the customer service. I ordered a matcha tiramisu which tasted like sour milk. It wasn't a big deal, and I asked (really nicely!) to exchange it for another dessert. The cashier didn't believe me and (get this) took a taste of the dessert right in front of me! She said it was supposed to taste sour because of the "cheese" and flatly refused to offer any exchange (or refund). It was bewildering. I still can't believe the cashier ate my dessert in front of me.
author: SF Customer S.

description: The service suck like shit. The Attitude is so bad. I won't spend money here forever! FOREVER!
author: Zhenkai M.

description:
I've come here a few times, and I have to say 3.5 stars...but not enough to round up to a 4.

The place itself is cute. Mismatched furniture, very open spaces. I feel like I'm able to work here without having people crowd all up in my business. The problems? That people actually spread out. Forreals. If you are a table of 2, seated INDIVIDUALLY at TWO tables for TWO (think about it...one each), BEGONE. For. Real. I see you leaning over and chatting with each other. You even pushed the tables together more so you can chat. Good for you. Next time get a larger table, or squeeze onto one table. Its people like you that ruin it for the rest of us. Also...the WiFi.

I, am a self-admitted PC person. I don't understand Macs, nor do I want to. I'm a professional, damnit. I don't want to be a hipster or artsy. I want a computer to compute. That's it. Now, that being said...the wifi here seems to suck for PC's. I've been here twice with a computer, with 2 different laptops. One was old. One was brand new. And they BOTH had problems with logging onto their wifi. It took nearly 30 minutes for my computer to finally get connected. I'm not sure if its because their wifi is overburdened, or if its a PC thing. No one else, that I saw, had this problem. Then again, I felt like I was in a sea of Macs, and their judging eyes made me avert mine. Its ok, if it came down to a duel, I'm sure I could kick their butts. Physically that is. If we did an art-off, I concede.

Oh. Right. The food. Ha. Most recently, I've been getting teas here (I know, I'm a coffee nut too). The green tea latte...is kind of grainy. Really weird. The teas are good, but its just a teabag and hot water, so not really a good reflection of the place itself.
author: Lily W.

description:
Awesome place...quiet, good drinks and food, spacious, quiet!

Was looking for a quick spot to rest near Japan Town and found this place. Amazing.
author: Edward S.

description:
YakiniQ Cafe is a quaint change of pace in J town. once housing a korean Q place, it now is a cafe featuring french influenced pastries, cakes, macaroons (2.95), pies,  lattes, expressos, etc. 

music: french.singing

decor: nice seating. tasteful art on walls, low mysterious lighting. 

pour: organic smooth brew (2.18)
-smooth light roast, mellow

drips: 
-didn't have much time to check out YakiniQ (only minutes on the meter,
meter people already ticketing at 10 a.m in the morn!)
-delightful service by j associate in french looking short page hair cut. (sweet smile).
-definitely will return when the meter maids are not looking/watching.
author: Victor G.

description:
One of the many places I revisit frequently in San Francisco. I'm a big fan of Japantown and I often visit YakiniQ after lunch. Other times - I really enjoy just sitting at YakiniQ and work on things. The ambiance is very adorable and the coffees are quite spot on. For a while they had these delicious peanut butter cookie sandwiches - I adore and miss those. 

Tried the "sweet potato latte" once - not really my thing. Worth a try though.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Love this cafe! It reminds me so much of Seoul/Tokyo cafes and I really like the drink menu and the pastries. Always nice to get a latte and a cake here. The staff is also very helpful and very nice. 

The only bad part-- it's always packed! It's a cute cafe and it's quiet, so I get that it's a great spot to get work done. However, it makes it hard for people who really just want to get a coffee and pastry to come here since there's no where to sit. It'd be great if people could use the couches or the large table because sometimes you'll find people camped out at the smaller tables for hours. 

Also- the bathroom is pretty gross. It shares one with YakiniQ upstairs and trust me, it doesn't match the cute and clean decor of the cafe.
author: Yuri K.

description:
I walked into YakiniQ and was pleasantly surprised by their awesome decor. There were people studying under cool hanging lights&lamps and there were board games like Stratego on the shelves. This looked like a great place to study.

But as soon as I cracked open my textbook, I realized that the cool dim ambience wasn't too cool for studying. Without a hanging lamp over my table, it was very difficult to read. So I asked the barista to pop up some lights for me, but he said they had to keep the other lights off during the day time.

They charge $4.50 for a latte and $8.49 for a grilled cheese so I know they're not trying to dim the lights to cut costs. It's cool if they're trying to maintain that dim ambiance, but I don't think it's worth it if they're messing up their customer's vision.

I'll come back to play Stratego though, but maybe I'll bring my own flashlight or something.
author: Ringo M.

description:
I used to come here religiously and I have been coming for many years, where I would spend hours. One of the reasons I really liked this cafe was because they were one of the rare cafes that did NOT play music! Well, I don't know when this started, but recently they have been playing loud, rowdy music I really don't like (it's definitely not japanese). Another reason why I liked it here is because they are authentically japanese... There is less of an authentic feel nowadays, so maybe they changed management. 

Re drinks, they have original cafes and teas, like the famous sweet potato latte.
author: C. C.

description: The only reason why we stopped here was that we wanted to get something quick and easy.  Atmosphere is kind of strange.  There were two Japanese customers who were speaking to a barista in Japanese.  I thought that was rather rude.      I'm sure those ladies can speak English.  The caramel latte was ok but I ordered the double shots and charged me for double shots but I didn't taste the double shots.  Scone was very buttery.  My son ordered a bear claw, it was ok.  For a local no name cafe, price point is a bit high.
author: Amanda W.

description:
Somehow every time I walk in here, my inner little-cutesy-asian-girl cries out. If I could, I would live here. It has the chic mish-mashed interior conducive of settling in... with a good read? convos? laptop work? Do it all here. The place also has board games, books, quirky chotchkies.  Not to mention a picturesque selection of patisserie delights. I wish I had more time to try something from their display case. I feel like giving an extra star to a place that boasts a nice variety of macarons. 

HONEY YUZU TEA- we got one hot and one cold. If I could describe sunshine, this tea would be it. In reality it's just a marmalade stirred in water, but I find this sugary citrus drank completely irresistible!
author: Jenny H.

description:
The cutest cafe ever! 

Pros
board games to play
relaxing setting
cute decor
variety of snack choices
prime location in japantown

Cons
pricey drinks
semi slow service
author: Kelly C.

description: Sweet potato latte is not bad, though i wouldn't go out of my way for. Got the pandan, yuzu green tea, and rose macaroons which were all not bad (fav was pandan).  Min spend of $6 for credit card so come with cash or leave with a few sweets to enjoy.
author: Ben M.

description:
It's always a tough time to write a review when the drinks are relatively good, but the service is lacking. I had the sweet potato latte, which I think was fantastic - but, every time I think of going back, the only thing I remember is, "But the people who work there are kind of mean."

Usually, this doesn't mean I won't go back to a place. Most boba places have crap service anyway, but I'm just there to get a drink and go. However, this strikes me as the sort of place where you should feel welcomed. Everything looks extremely tasty, but when I order, I always feel like I'm bothering them.

If you don't care for service, come for the food. Does this review sound whiny? Yes, yes it does. But a good cafe, restaurant, and business in general should never make a customer feel like they're troubling the staff. I'm glad I had the sweet potato latte, but I'd rather take my business to a place that focuses on hiring people who know what they're doing in terms of customer service.
author: Robbin A.

description:
I have been slacking! My apologies! 

YakiniQ (the cafe that is, there is also a restaurant or a bar that is right next to it. I haven't eaten there yet! Will soon!) is my study spot in little Japantown in SF. I love how it is right next to the cute shops and and center in Japantown. It is convenient if you want to do a little browsing after an intense session of the LSATS or GMATS. 

There are plenty of seats with semi great lighting (only on the seats that are on the left when you walk in. The other ares can be a little dark. There aren't that many outlets so use your time very wisely. Although they have plenty of seats, it does get busy since it is a really good place to get work done. Quiet, roomy, coffee bar, snacks and a mini kitchen. The food does take awhile to come out so order early. 

The one thing I enjoy most is the ambiance. It is very modern and designed for adults to get werk done! (no dirty thoughts pleasee... ). It is not a tapex where there is a rush of high school kids who want boba and popcorn chicken or a starbucks where the strong pungent or espresso stays on your hair. There is record playing classical music and whispers among the chatters because they have the know that there are folks that studying. 

Food is decent. I only tried the spam musubi ( ~3.75) 

I will come back here more often if I live in the area!
author: Phuong V.

description:
$7 for a fuking small shaved ice , and add condensed milk for 0.75 cents extra.
Worst shaved ice ever
author: Shen C.

description:
They have board games (and jenga!). My friends and I were waiting to eat at YakiniQ BBQ and we got to see a live one-man guitar show where a fob sang beautiful music.

I've had a latte here too, and that's good as well. But mostly, yay for having a place to wait while waiting for BBQ... extra points for having games!
author: Michelle K.

description:
YakiniQute!
This cafe is very pleasant: nice music, good tea and snacks, plenty of seating, lots of asians, and perfectly neat and clean.

It's spacious and good for individuals or small groups. There are various chairs and tables for working, reading, or lounging. There's a chess set and other board games as well as a small tray of crayons. There's also a corner with a retro record player, acoustic guitar, and cassio keyboard -- which thankfully no one ever plays.

The baked goods and sandwiches are yummy. Their lavender dark chocolate truffles are delicious! And they have my favorite tea brand, Harney & Sons.

My only complaint is how precious few outlets are available. In fact, I'm finding the time to write my first SF Yelp review since moving here 6 months ago all because I've been waiting *an hour* to plug in my battery-less '06 ibook. And by write I mean write, with a pen in my hand on a piece of paper. So perhaps this is master Q's zen way of forcing some unplugged quiet time into my life.
author: Kristen T.

description:
Best place to order a Sweet Potato Latte (espresso not included). Lovely art and design; perfect for reading a book or working on your next project. Lunch and desserts are also available, though there are not many gluten-free options.

Friendly staff and service. Right across from Hotel Kabuki and Japantown.

I'll be going back next time I stay in Japantown!
author: Esmerelda B.

description:
4.95$ for Affogato is a ripped off. They give me only half scoop ice-cream; just two bites and i'm done with it. It taste good, but the amount of ice-cream and price are not reasonable.

I recommend blue bottle coffee for Affogato. Just the same price, but I enjoy it better.
author: Chalisa B.

description:
This place is really cute and reminded me of the little coffee shops in Korea! The drinks and food are pretty good, and if you have a sweet tooth the macaroons are solid:) Internet is good here, but only the seats on the right side have power cords.

The place is a good, quiet place to relax, get some reading or internet browsing done, or even just play a board game since they have a few lined up in the back. This is my go-to spot when I'm working remotely and don't have any calls I need to join or speak on!
author: Nancy W.

description: Adorable cafe - pretty quiet and laid back - good for reading or working on your laptop. Limitations include wifi access for one hour and $6 credit card minimum. Love the open seating. Feels like being in someone's living room/kitchen. I usually stop in for a sweet treat - macaron or cake slice with the sweet potato latte.
author: Elaine W.

description: Sweet potato latte! Unique and Delish!  A cute little cafe with pastries and small bites... and wifi!
author: Laura H.

description:
This cafe would be a 5 star study/work place if there were more outlets and better wifi. The coffee is nothing to write home about, there's plenty of other shops in the city if you want a great cup of coffee but with this said, this is a good spot for more novel drinks and there's a nice assortment of sweet and savory treats! My matcha latte was pretty watery but still refreshing for what it was. My ham/cheese croissant was very good, perfectly flaky and warmed up.

But really, might want to consider upgrading your internet, it's pretty frustrating to be working and getting kicked off the Internet or it being super slow. It'd be worth it since it's such a popular place to work and study. Ditto for outlets or extension cords, I'm about to leave because there's no outlets for me to use....
author: Christine K.

description: A very cool cafe...very good coffee, nice music, a very friendly barista, and best of all, a cafe that feels like a living room of your house....this was my first visit here, and I am very impressed...it's also not too crowded, so easy to get seating, read a book, get online, chit chat, whatever...and lots of restaurants nearby, since Japantown is across the street...
author: Raj D.

description: An affordable lunch in Japantown, $9 sandwich with salad. Comfortably funky coffeeshop with mismatched chairs, piles of boardgames, lots of wood, nice lighting. Cold drink case. Nutella lattes.
author: Marshall E.

description:
It's pretty good. I was in japantown and wanted a cafe to sit and relax at - this one came up as #1 on the list so why not~. The cafe gives off a very cozy and homey feel. There's seating enough for 35ish people inside without being too crowded.

The minus is mostly for the price of the  sweet potato latte, $4.10?, which i think is super expensive for what it looks like it's made from. Another minus star for the cashier guy who was rushing me - let me order at my pace whether that takes 2 or 6minutes of looking at the menu jeez. 

But if i'm ever back in the area, i'll give it another go.
author: Sarah K.

description:
This is such a cute little cafe. It is a nice place to come and enjoy a drink with a friend. They have board games and also random trinkets and books for you to kill some time. The place is big and spacious and has a bathroom in the back. 

My only issue is that my drink was too sweet. I didn't like it. 

I would like to come back and try their other drinks or desserts.
author: Sarah C.

description: Love the ambience here and the coffee is superb. Great place to work, plenty of outlets, and free wifi (yay!) people rave about  the bakery goods and sweets. I got a earl grey macaroon, it's so rare to find tea infused desserts in the states so it's definitely a plus.
author: Claire Y.

description:
Another cafe full of people studying on a Saturday night.  Clearly this is the place to be seen studying.  This poses a problem for the rest of us coming here to enjoy a drink and sweets together with the company of friends when you can't find a place to sit!!

Anyway this was the first time I'd ever heard of a sweet potato latte.  What an interesting creation.  Definitely recommend to give it a try.  Tried the earl grey macaron as well.  Macaron shell and texture was great but I just wasn't a big fan of the early grey flavour though i'm normally not an earl grey tea drinker anyway.
author: Angela Y.

description: i think this is the cutest cafe i've been to in sf. great selection of coffees, tea, desserts, and light lunch options. it's quiet and inviting, and the staff is so nice!  caught up with a gf over matcha latte with skim milk, and was delicious and comfy and home-y. loveee. prices are on the heftier side - $4.75 for latte. meeps. ha.
author: Christina L.

description:
Like other reviewers have mentioned, the staff here is really amazing at being rude. 

I moved one chair and a male staff member came over and yelled at me, infront of the whole cafe. I then got up and asked the next time, as I had 5 people at a table for 4, if I could please move one empty chair to the end of the table, and he told me I could leave if I touch anything else. 

The ginger tea is okay, the salads are fine, but it's nothing you can't get elsewhere. The prep time for the food items is pretty slow (10+ minutes for a salad). The decor is great and it's clean and cute inside, but it's overpriced for what you get.

The sign says they close at 9, but at 8pm the same male employee went into full on mean teacher mode and began flickering the lights on and off and then yelling to the whole cafe that they are closing early, and we had 10 minutes to close our laptops and get out. It was patronizing and rude. 

I won't be going back, or recommending it to others.
author: Laura J.

description:
This is a cute, quiet cafe in Japantown. I bought the Almond Latte and my boyfriend had the Nutella Latte. The Nutella latte was delicious! I got the almond latte with almond extract and it was delicious as well! 

They staff was super friendly and made my drinks very quickly.
author: Gail M.

description:
The sweet potato latte is absolutely delicious. I'm a huge sweet potato fan so drinking this as a latte was a huge plus. Since there's a $10 minimum charge on credit cards, I had to order enough to make the cut so I got the spam masubi which was nothing out of the ordinary or special. It gave me a quick fill in time for my real dinner. I also got macarons and was content with my flavors. They will deliver the food to you but you'll have to grab your latte at the counter when they call your name. 

I wish there were more outlets and tables. One wall has outlets while the other wall's outlets are taped up. Im assuming there's a reason for this and they dont want patrons staying there all day taking up space which is understandable.  I liked that they had books and games you could borrow for the time being.
author: Jeena L.

description: I love coming to YakiniQ during the day when I have work to get done. The wifi is good and some of the drinks are great. The environment is why I come to visit and the owner is really nice. Is it expensive but I consider it worth it to stop in for a few hours. The sweet potato latte, lavender latte, and yuzu tea are good. $6 minimum for credit card use so bring cash if you only want a $4-5 drink only and don't want to end up having to buy something else.
author: Dee C.

description: What's a Sweet potatoe late? Try it here. Very good and not what I was expecting. This spot has cute desserts and fun flavors. Green tea shortbread. Cookies with Oreo chuncks instead of chocolate chips. Assortment of french pastries. Macarons. Tarts. Cake. Coffee. Tea. Esspreso.  A calm atmosphere in low lighting and friendly service with a smile.
author: Charlene K.

description:
As much as I like the atmosphere and how quite this cafe is, the drink and food qualities can be better. One time, I had diarrhea after having a sweet potato latte and a slice of quiche there. Those were to two things I had on that day before heading to the bathroom... 

I would also agreed with the reviews about the customer service / attitude. This is very important for any business, especially when it comes to the hospitality industry.
author: Lianna D.

description:
Adorable little café in Japantown. I walked by many times before and saw their post about Sweet Potato Latte. Tonight, I found the time to walk-in. To my surprise, the place is huge and roomie and so cute inside. They have free Wi-Fi and sell lots of cakes and pastries. So cute. And the seating is comfortable and cute. Lots of mismatched chairs, but it certainly works well for the place. And lots of artwork related to LATTE.

We grabbed a cup of the Sweet Potato Latte (no caffeine) and a cup of the Yuzu Honey Tea (no caffeine). If I wasn't overly full, I would have went and tried their other snacks such as their macaroons and matcha shortbread. That will be for my next trip.

Sweet Potato Latte was very foamy and very light. You can tell it was light because the large cup weighed like air. I think they may have put Sweet Potato puree in the milk. It was a bit sweet for my taste. But definitely very creative and for Sweet Potato Lovers, would be a definitely big hit. But I am not Sweet Potato lover, so this was only a so-so for me.

Yuzu Honey Tea was very fragrantly. I could smell the citrus fruit Yuzu when I opened the lid. The Yuzu was tasty, but the honey was too much for me.

Overall, the drinks were only so-so for me. But I really like the ambience and the vibe and the cuteness of this place. If I am looking for a relaxing coffee place to write my papers or quiet time, I wouldn't hesitate to come back and hang out at this place for peace and quiet.
author: Janice T.

description:
Came here on a Saturday afternoon to get some work done. The place was full except the couches. There aren't much plugs near the tables except the ones on the east wall.

It's an cafe with many different types of coffee. They got cake, ice cream and even macarons.

The iced green tea latte (double shot) was alright and the macaroons were decent.

They have wifi (extremely slow though) here so I recommend coming here for a nice studying/work environment. Just remember that there are limited amount of seats near a socket.

I'm giving in 4 stars for the ambiance, drinks and dessert.
author: Brian L.

description:
One of my favorite cafes in the city! SO cute :) I love going here to read and pass the time.  Great for studying because there are many outlets.. 

Try the nutella latte!
author: Erin D.

description:
I was walking down the street with a chill in my bones, and I stopped dead in my tracks when I saw the sign advertising YakiniQ's sweet potato latte. Can you imagine anything more comforting and cozy on a cold SF evening than that? Well, I couldn't, so I walked right in, and ordered one straight away. I couldn't resist ordering a couple of their macarons as well, though all of their dessert selections looked so incredible it was hard not to order everything!

The interior of the place is really quiet because it looks to be mostly a study/working cafe. I love places like this, where the customers are encouraged to make themselves comfortable and stay for a long time. The one thing I thought was kind of lame were the people who brought in their own drinks and food. I understand the whole starving student thing but if you're going to take up a whole table (and there aren't very many of them), you could at least buy a little something from the business that's providing it for you. 

Other than that, I was completely charmed by the funky, eclectic decor and the young, friendly staff. It felt like one of those fake cafes in movies that you claim don't exist in real life... well they do!
author: Christina P.

description: Pretty good place to sit and chat or even do homework. Their matcha latte is pretty good. Their iced yuzu tea is good too.
author: Kin S.

description:
Somewhat expensive so-so food and ok coffee, sort of like at an airport. Don't move the tables.

Ambiance is nicely decorated study hall filled with students. Don't move the tables. It's a pretty unique scene.

OMG!!!

DON'T MOVE THE TABLES!!!
author: Chuck G.

description:
I came here with my roommates after dinner. We wanted to sit down at some cute cafe and hangout, so Yelp led us to this place... and this cafe was exactly what we were looking for! We managed to find street parking right outside, but I would assume that parking around this cafe would be a pain during the day.

We ordered a green tea shaved ice with fruits... but it was okay... I had better tasting shaved ice before, so I probably wouldn't order it here ever again. I asked for extra condensed milk, and one of the workers gave me some on the side so yay! My roommate got a sweet potato latte... but I wouldn't recommend it... half of the mug is foam.

Although I wouldn't come back here for the food, I want to come back here to study some day! It would be inconvenient to come here with a group to study because this place has some rules (listed on the counter but I don't remember them from the top of my head)... something about one wifi password per table or something like that. WAIT DON'T QUOTE ME ON IT lol. Just go check out the rules.
author: Annie S.

description:
This is such an amazing cafe.  Really comfortable seating and chill, spacious atmosphere.  My friend and I poufed ourselves down on the couch and read our book club book.  :) I love that they have such a great selection of non-caffeinated hot drinks.  The pastries here looked to-die-for -- macarons and eclairs, apple pie, banana crumb cake, spam musubi, bread pudding and fruit tarts.  They were ridiculously expensive ($6.50 for an eclair) but look fantastic.  I would definitely come back all the time if I lived near Japantown.

My friend's ginger tea was incredible, as well as my coffee eclair.


---- DRINKS ----

Sweet Potato Latte: 3 stars
I love sweet potatoes (they fed my country during WW2!) but the sweet potato latte was not up my alley.

Yuzu Honey Tea: 4.5 stars

Ginger Honey Tea: 4.5 stars

Jujube Tea: 4 stars
Red dates with honey

Iced Yuzu Tea: 3.5 stars
Refreshing but a little watered down.

Iced Chai: 4.5 stars
Yummy.


---- FOOD ----

Matcha Pound Cake: 4.5 stars
The best of their baked goods so far

Tuna Salad Onigiri: 3.75 stars
Deceptively simple but yummy and a big filling portion.

Opera Cake: 3.5 stars
Coffee cream and cake topped with chocolate, but a bit too dense for my taste.

Bread Pudding: 3 stars
Not very sweet, pretty average. Cold so they have to heat it up for you. This would probably taste good with a milky hot drink, instead of the yuzu tea.

Pistachio Macaron: 2 stars
Good flavour, but texture is soggy and soft instead of crisp and soft.

Ham and Cheese Croissant: 2 stars
author: Letitia L.

description:
Came here during a day of exploring Japantown for the Japan Day Festival (6/23/12). The cafe has a really cute, cozy interior with tables and comfy seats. There's nice artwork on the walls and big paper lanterns hanging from the ceiling. Very zen, could see myself studying or doing some reading here! 

What I ordered:
- Sweet Potato Latte ($4): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/rCpCBeWQ8NNI_q6kq6JlQQ?select=POW1s2chJ_zI88KBStBZhw#rNygWUOUEz0rvoLRS8Mywg

I was trying to decide between the matcha latte or the sweet potato one, but in the end, figured that the sweet potato latte was more unique and therefore, more worth trying. Seriously, I've never seen any other cafe concoct this drink! There was lots of foam at the top, which I liked since I was able to sip the cooler foam and hot latte underneath together. The flavor tasted unmistakably of sweet potato and was what I would imagine blending sweet potatoes would taste like. Definitely very unique and interesting! They also sell some cakes and many different kinds of macarons, but they looked a little pricey.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Crappy service with a horrible barista. Spilled coffee and dropped cookies, she looked at me and did not bother to offer napkins even though she saw that coffee was all over my sleeves and also did not offer to replace the cookies. Instead left it on the counter and expected me to take it. First time here and will never come back.

Oh and special note to the owner- maybe you need to read the reviews you have on yelp..unfortunately for you there are more than one negative review about the poor service.. maybe the issue isn't
the fact that I dropped my cookies on the floor which you so graciously pointed out as i walked out of your establishment but more of the lack of service and attentiveness your staff has.  But after reading other reviews, seems to be the trend here.
author: Vix W.

description:
Sweet potato latte yummmmmm. This is my favorite coffee shop in the city, like previously stated, the sweet potato latte is the thing to  get. They are definitely known for it, its sweet, (not too sweet), frothy and I just found out they can make it iced also. What!!!! its not to overly complicated and its just the right amount of sweet potato taste.. 
they also have pasties, they have this banana coffee cake!!! gahhhhhh! nice and crumbly, not dry at all. 
over all this place is somewhere you could come and study, not be bothered or enjoy the silent ambience. its an open area with plenty of chairs and tables, (not that many outlets) and a comfy couch.
author: Lorena G.

description:
The Sweet Potato latte was a must each time I'm near the area, but quality has gone down and consistently lacking flavor the past few trips (All to go). 
This happened last months, few weeks back and last week when we visited. While I appreciate the barista's effort to fill the order as soon as she can, i'd appreciate it more if we could get the same portions for our drinks. One cup was literally 3/5 filled to the top. The other cup, while filled to the top, was lacking flavor. It didn't taste like sweet potato at all, but more of steamed milk. 
From now on, never order the same drink as your companions or else you might get uneven portion.
author: Kevin N Edna P.

description:
Something Zen-ish about this place (and I write this with all due cultural points)

It's quiet and calming.  They also have a full espresso bar which can dish out pretty good espresso drinks.  

At times it can crowded but nevertheless it still maintains it's calming atmosphere.    

This has also been my LSAT stronghold for the past couple of weeks. 

My only quibble about this place is their credit card minimum.  So you're either SOL if you don't have cash OR you have to buy $15 worth of something (macarons in my case)  to justify a small latte.   

Takeaway: check it out!  great place to meet people or intense studying.    

Oh and they have Macarons.  yum
author: Geo D.

description:
Disappointing experience, came here in the morning as I stayed right across at the Hotel Kabuki.

So not customer service oriented.

Got my order wrong and because I paid my credit card (wouldn't take Amex too), wanted cash. Tax evasionist!

With my order change I effectively overpaid and cashier made it seem like they were doing me a favor.

Wow.

Sweet potatoe latte overrated.

INteresting wanna-be Japanese cafe with a mismatched name.
author: Warren W.

description:
Service is everything. I usually don't and have never yet so this is my first time writing a bad review. I'm at 9%battery and I'm still writing a shitty review on this place so you know this is important. Why The place deserves a star ? Well the place itself is clean and spacious.

 However the service is HORRIBLE. I came in, sat down and settled myself along with my belongings. I asked for a wifi password and one of the cashier said wifi is only for customers which made sense. I thought the restaurant and cafe were together and she said no.  Well thanks for being friendly with such a positive attitude...I purchased a tea and she just told me to grab the can and handed to her...very rudely. 

After my purchase this is what she said to me "just to let you know the cafe and restaurant are two different place." Thanks for letting me know again, dear girl cashier, I do not need to be told twice. When the drink was ready I went up to her and all she pointed and said your drink is over there, not a thank you or a smile....Honestly I have never been to a cafe with such rude cashier.

 I feel very disrespected even as customer. I rather spend my money else where. At least I would feel good about it. 
And Just because I asked for wifi doesn't mean I wasn't going to be a customer but now you know for sure I ain't coming back. 

AIN'T COMING BACK. So all my dear friends, I highly DO NOT recommend this place.
author: Letitia Z.

description: Absolutely the best place to study and grab a matcha latte. I have been going to YakiniQ Cafe for the past four years. Each time I'm able to enjoy the ambiance of this adorable cafe. Kudos to the owner as she is always super friendly and has the best interior designing taste.
author: Rocio S.

description:
3.5 stars overall. 5 stars for the cutesy interior, 3 stars for the hot latte drinks. 

YakiniQ cafe has a good amount of tables to sit and study. It's pretty quiet so this probably wouldn't be the best cafe to catch up with old friends.  Most customers are students working on their laptops cramming away. There's some sketchbooks in the middle table, which people are able to draw in and are really entertaining to look thru.

Last weekend, my friends and I came in here for sweet potato lattes and nutella lattes. The sweet potato lattes are like liquid gold! Anyone who loves nutella would enjoy the taste of the nutella latte. They also have a variety of pastries, such as pies and macarons.

At over 4 dollars, I received a small paper cup of nutella latte filled with foam that wasn't even filled to the top.  The visit before, I also received a cup full of foam so I couldn't walk away suckered for the second time but this time, in addition to a cup of mainly foam, my cup wasn't even topped off.  I haaaate foam so I went back and asked for the foam to be taken out and filled with more milk. The worker seemed like she knew she hadn't made enough milk but was careless and was hoping I wouldn't notice.  She had someone else steam more milk.... which she then made more foam and poured it into my already foam filled cup... I hate being picky so I walked away suckered once again.  If I wanted a cappucino, I would've ordered one.  For a small latte, $4+ is a little steep.
author: Cheryl Q.

description:
It's Oh So Quiet...Shhh...

Mi amiga was craving hot chocolate after our movie so I checked on Yelp & found this place nearby. Walking in, I definitely notice that it's a really simply cute cafe filled with people totally super quiet focused on their books/laptops sippin' on yummy drinks or munchin' on sweets. They had a good variety of lovely desserts & drinks to choose from. Mi amiga got the hot chocolate of course, but later she wished she got the caramel milk tea instead. Next time! Then I got the caramel latte which was yummy! Her hot chocolate's latte art was much cooler looking than mine; the latte art on my latte was not that exciting. 

This place definitely has the cozy relaxing vibe to it. Perfect place for studying or reading. It's pretty spacey with a variety of different chairs, couches, & tables around.  We both felt that like we're in a library & trying to keep really quiet while talking. Definitely would come back if I'm in the area. :)
author: Amy C.

description: This cafe shop is definitely an excellent place for working, reading, and studying. There are plenty of sits and the cafe shop is spacious. However, the waitresses were SO NOISY. They kept talking with a high volume that each person in different spots could hear their dialogue. I don't mind people talking in the cafe shop, but when everyone was doing their own work Quietly, it should take others into consideration. If just ignored the situation I just mentioned above, this place is absolutely worth visiting.
author: Kate W.

description:
I love coming here to work. They have free wifi, and friendly staff. Although they have a lot of power outlets, they have covered up the ones at the bigger tables. So basically, there are small tables if you want to plug in.

I am slowly working my way through the menu here. The pastries are good. I have to say that, although the sweet potato latte was good, I won't order it again. It was like drinking sweet potato. Good for a few sips but the. It's just too much. 

The coffee in general is good though. It's cute that they serve their lattes in a bowl (like a cafe au lait), and they have a decent tea selection. And their cakes are so pretty and the macrons are delicious. 

$10 minimun on credit cards.
author: Mariko F.

description:
I have been here multiple times and really love this cafe.  There's a certain way this cafe flows that really keeps me coming back.  Usually, there's an open table and the service is great.

However, I had to ding this place after my experience during the Ramen Noodle/J-Pop festival a few weekends ago.  Granted, it was a busy time for every business, with tens of thousands of people visiting Japantown.

Area businesses were swamped and YakiniQ was no exception.  However, I can't even begin to describe the terrible service and attitudes that my friend and I received from the staff on the second day of the festival.  The entire staff looked like they were run ragged by the crush of people, but they decided to take it out on customers.

To start, the cashier was surly and short when we were ordering coffee and food.  The person prepping the drinks was unaccomodating, short on patience, and glib when answering questions.  While waiting for drinks, she very rudely scolded us for standing near the counter and demanded that we step away while she prepared drinks.  

To top it off, when when my friend asked for a lid for her to-go food box, there was a look of disgust from both the coffee and food preparers.

Any business in their right mind would see a street festival as an incredible opportunity to put their best foot forward and to woo new customers.  Instead, the cafe was understaffed and the staff took their frustrations out on customers.  Basically, this cafe lacks respect for their customers and an understanding of what good customer service means.

I felt badly for them and their situation that weekend.  But to be frank, I'll gladly take my business elsewhere if I'm such a burden to them.
author: Bobby L.

description:
Cute!
Quiet!
Service and space is airy, kind, and relaxing.
Get the sweet potato or green tea lattes and bring a good book. :D
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Great coffee and they sell my favorite macarons from Philippe's. Philippe's used to be a bakery in SOMA that I would religiously visit every week but they changed owners and so when I stumbled across this cafe and saw the macarons, I instantly knew Philippe's macarons found a new home!

The only thing about this place is it's very quiet in there. I was actually in there trying to do some work but it felt more like a library than a place where you can hang out with friends to talk and catch up.
author: Betty C.

description:
Lovely little cafe in Japantown. From the outside you see just a little door and chalk board. Inside it is big and completely relaxing. The atmosphere in here was what I loved the most. Completely relaxed and peaceful. There were students dotted around, talking in whispers so as to not disturb the peaceful atmosphere and people just enjoying a coffee, either alone with a book or with a friend. 

I had a chai tea latte (as good as Starbucks but way cheaper) and my boyfriend tried their sweet potato latte which he enjoyed.
