description: Not sure about how good the Macaroons are but one thing I am sure of is, I will never spend a dime in this place.  I drove an hour to this place on Sat. was going to order some sandwiches and Macaroons to go but the staff has a s*itty attitude.  When asked what kind of sandwich do they serve, she said "no lunch, this is a cafe, you know?"  Wow, someone stepped on your toe or something?  To whoever worked on 11/15 around noon behind the counter, here is a clue: you better get your sh*t straight.  Even if you are the owner, there is no need to show your sh*t face to the customers.  You can take your Macaroons and shove them up to where the sun don't shine.  I will make sure that no one i know ever go to your store.  You are welcome
author: Ed Q.

description: Came here for the Sweet Potato Latte its not all what I expected~but oh well~ Chill atmosphere cozy seating~Little too pricey for the product they are putting out~But what the hell come here and try it yourself.
author: Duke Of Frisco X.

description: The sweet potato latte is very good! The place needs some music in my opinion. It's a little woo quiet...just my personal opinion.
author: Nicole H.

description:
Take a note: Sweet potato latte. 

Made of real sweet potato puree, this was a delicious warm drink to order for another  city day under a heavy blanket of fog. I used "warm" because I think it could've been steamed hotter so the drink would last longer sitting out. It took me probably less than 3 minutes to finish it all and it tasted more like room temperature towards the end.

YakiniQ was such a quiet, clean, and spacious place to get your studying on, but even with the number of tables out, not one was available in the middle of a weekday afternoon. They were set up in a dining-style way where it appeared to be one  person/party per table. I just wish there were more communal tables.
author: Bets Y.

description:
This cafe is an awesome place to hang out with friends.
A hip, art-inspired interior and dim light makes a casual and fun atmosphere.

They have a sweet potato latte that is worth a try, and when I don't get that, I like to get their hot chocolate.

A large variety of pastries and desserts.

Free wi-fi for the studious ones. They have board games too.
author: Alfred L.

description:
Cute spot. Cool place to hangout. Good desserts. French Macarons were just so-so. Reason for the low rating is because the guy that was helping us was kind of a douche. We asked what flavor he recommends for the Macarons, and his art ass replied with, "well its different for every person." No shit, Sherlock. But I still wanna know what YOU recommend. And when we were about to pay, we asked to pay with part cash and the rest on the card. And he replies with, "Well its a lot easier for ME if you just pay everything with your card." Really???
Note: good customer service will take you and this place a lot further buddy.
author: Lauren A.

description:
Update: 4 stars now that the jenga playing people are gone. It's quiet now.

I came here because a previous reviewer had said it was quiet as a library and a good place to study. As luck would have it, two groups of people were playing jenga the first time I visited. Try studying with the sounds crashing wooden tiles every 20 min. and tell me what you think.

What confuses me is that the cafe provides the jenga-- when your establishment has a quiet/soothing vibe going on, why jenga?? Guess they are trying to appeal to many people and keep it lively but this was too much.

Lights over most tables are dim and "atmospheric." I prefer my study spaces to be very well lit.

The lemon meringue tart was overpriced and obviously made from tart shells... But I couldn't bring myself to pay $6 for onigiri I could make at home. $5-6 minimum for card.

Might try another day, another time, but probably not for me.
author: Tiffany K.

description: Don't get the Yuzu Palmer or their Honey Ice tea!! Watered down & expensive. Their macarons are sold $2.25 each (Rip off) I can head to Chantal for a dozen for $22 or a single macaron for ~$1.50.
author: R V.

description:
YakiniQ is so peaceful. And I probably break that up by loudly tapping away on my paper working on class after class after class, haha. But it's my current cafe of choice, which says a lot given how much I go to cafes (like, every day). You will get your work done here. In fact, if you stop going on facebook, you'll even get ahead. I was here two weekends ago and finished double as much as I had planned on!

I love how the owners make it intimate. The ambiance is very clean and has just the right amount of kitsch. The owner announces 15 minutes before closing time and thanks us for their business -- every night.

The desserts are meh (not a huge fan of macaroons, but others seem to like them, the cookie is very crisp, which is not my style). I would order something more interesting, but the prices are expensive.

Nonetheless, the coffee's good and I like the ability to order green tea/mocha or just a simple americano. I thought the pumpkin thing was a bit weird, for the record, but whatever. No complaints.

Minus a star because 10 dollars is a lot for a minimum. I understand, small biz, etc. But not even a debit option?

Enough griping. Go there and get some inner peace soon!
author: Asaf K.

description: A great cafe! I loved my sweet potato latte. The cafe is very large and seats are spaced out so you feel like you have a lot of room to relax or work. There are games in the back. The staff were really friendly and happy. I loved it!
author: Bla B.

description: I don't love this place anymore. The last two times I can for dessert I got OLD canned fruit. For prices this high they could stand to make sure customers get fresh fruit. I barely tolerated that they served canned food to begin with!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
I am hooked on the sweet potato latte. I'm talking about riding the Geary bus to J-town after work from SoMa hooked. At first I was hesitant, but it's not too sweet, quite rich, and very interesting. Get one next time you're scoring $1 goodies at Daiso or browsing Kinokuniya - your taste buds will dance obon and do karate kicks in your mouth.

PS: Shave ice with fruit, ice cream, and mochi/azuki beans!!!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
After visiting Japantown so many times in the past, I never knew YakiniQ Cafe existed! It wasn't until the GF and I were walking around on a rainy day, did we stumble upon such a glorious cafe!

It's actually a bigger cafe that it looks, with ample seating, a quiet atmosphere for studying, and loads of goodies to choose from on their menu. It's pretty cool how their menu spans from coffee and lattes, to macaroons and other desserts, to onigiri and banh mi.

After spending a good 5-10mins starring at the menu, we opted for the sweet potato latte (iced) and a couple of their macaroons (passion fruit and matcha green tea).

Their sweet potato latte was amazing! Very smooth, with lots of bits of sweet potato. Glad they didn't just use a powder and create a mundane smoothie-like drink. I bet it tastes even better warm, but I guess I was just in a chilly mood that day. :)

Their macaroons are ok. I'd say that their matcha green tea flavor was a lot better than the passion fruit. It was a bit more concentrated than the passion fruit.

Overall, this is an amazing place in the heart of SF Japantown. A great place to hang out, get some work done, or just to grab a solid drink!
author: Kevin J.

description:
YakiniQ has the best French macarons I've ever had!  They're delicious and I make a point to stop and get a couple whenever I'm in the neighborhood.  Love 'em!  I also like the atmosphere here, the decor is simple and nice, and even though it's always crowded whenever I visit, it's always quiet and peaceful.  A solid 4 star rating :)

Minus 1 star just because it can be rather expensive, and also because I can never seem to find a seat when I'm there!  Though I guess that's not entirely their fault.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Cute little cafe! 

I got the famous Hot Sweet Potato Latte. The staff were very friendly and helpful! There were a lot of chairs but some of them were hard so if you're looking for a place to kick back and read a book this might not be it. However, they have free wi-fi and really wide tables so it's a great place to get some work done! 

The sweet potato latte was creamy and thick. You could taste small potato chunks in it. It didn't really taste like a latte though, I couldn't taste the espresso. It was really good though! Until I got to the bottom and larger pieces of stringy potato skin started coming out of the cup cover. Those were a bit unsavoury. I'd probably order it again but I would just be more careful as I reach the bottom of the cup. 

They also had a gluten-free chocolate cake that looked really good!
author: Stacey L.

description:
Sweet potato latte is their special. its pretty good for something different, but I don't know if I'm crazy over it. 

Really chill place. VERY QUIET. even when there's a lot of people inside. Great place to study or do some work. 

Pastries look so good, but I haven't tried it yet. Green tea latte is a little bland.

Milk tea latte, is just Earl Grey Tea latte. I had other ideas what it was going to be but yeah. A little disappointed.
author: Erica L.

description:
Service was friendly. 
The price was a bit high. A tiny cheesecake was $6. My macaron was $2.50 each.
Wifi very slow. In some cases to the point of non-functional. But that's ok, I go there to read anyway.
Their Macaron was delicious - the blackberry (or blueberry?) macaron has a multi-layer of flavors of sweets and fruit. The rose macaron was good too.
The sweet potato latte was a fun experience. I like the taste, but I wish they have a small cup size.
Sadly, they fall short of my most important assessment of a cafe - coffee. I had their Americano. Shockingly, it has no flavor - I mean it literally. I was drinking brown color water. Top 3 worst Americano experience ever. Don't go for the espresso drinks. Go there for the sweets and specialty drink (or tea, you can't mess up tea, I think).
author: Amy C.

description: This is a wonderful coffee shop, with a comfortable and peaceful atmosphere. There's limited access to electric plugs, and the tables are not to be moved! My Chai was absolutely perfect. I was lured in because of other reviews saying that the place seemed too quiet. I can happily report that it is quiet here! The perfect spot to escape for just a moment of peace. It's also very clean here, I get the impression that many of the patrons treat the place as their own, which explains the tidiness despite the fact that the place is full of patrons.
author: Kara L.

description:
I'm currently in a macaron obsession and, so far, this is my favorite place to get them.

I love that it's open later than other bakeries that sell macarons (they all close at like 5 or 6 pm) so it's more accessible for me to fuel my addiction. Rose macarons are my favorite.

I haven't had anything else here and I usually just grab macrons and leave, but you should definitely come here at least for the macarons.
author: Nhathy N.

description: The space is really cute. It's a good place to hang out, or get some work done. The desserts are generally pretty good. The drinks on the other hand, have generally been mediocre. My most recent drink was an iced chai latte which tasted pretty close to straight up milk. When I asked for some more chai, even just a little, I was told no because apparently they charge for that.... I generally understand charging for extras, but if that's how they normally make a chai latte they're doing it wrong. I would like to give this place 4 star because I like it here, but the drinks just aren't worth it.
author: Diana C.

description: this spot is pretty cool. i came here from the roomies recommendation. i'm not a huge sweet potato lover, but i decided to come try the sweet potato latte. my thoughts after the first sip... meh. i'm not blown away. it had chunks of sweet potato in it. how weird, i thought. anyway, at least i can say i tried it. the french macarons... i'm always a sucker for those damn things. i must say... it was pretty darn tasty! btw, $10 min if you choose to use card.
author: Ann T.

description:
Love, love, LOVE YakiniQ!

I first came here just looking for a place to relax, snack, and be productive, and YakiniQ has provided one of the best spaces I've experienced for such doings.  The cafe has a decent amount of plugs scattered around, though not quite enough for everyone to be able to charge their electronics (I believe they have three 2-plug wall sockets on the wall with the 4-person tables, and 2 along the other side), but the ambiance is to die for.

Even at their most crowded, the chatter in the cafe doesn't overwhelm, and the floor-ceiling book/display-case on the back wall is filled with games that customers can play with, and random knickknacks that just add to the unique aura.

Also, the menu is divine -- the PumpkinQ Latte is my favorite.  It's a cousin of the Sweet Potato Latte and, though it's definitely just as creamy, it's nowhere near as gritty, which I thoroughly appreciate.

Their Turkey sandwiches and the Macaroons are divine, and I'm a big fan of their Yuzu Honey Tea, and their Yuzu-Palmer.  Well, I'm a sucker for Yuzu-anything, really, so I guess it's not a surprise that I'm a huge fan.

And the shaved ice, and ice cream... What's there NOT to love?

Also, there's something awesome about the music either coming from their vinyl player in the corner, or from an ipod/iphone that varies between Deadmau5, Hikaru Utada, Maaya Sakamoto, and Jack Johnson. :D
author: Emilynne A.

description:
I love this place! It also happened to be right across the street from my hotel, Hotel Kabuki. Walking in brought me back to the cute Seoul/Tokyo cafes I went to last summer. I was blown away by the cuteness and the amount of seating they had. I ordered a sweet potato latte because uhh...where else could you get a sweet potato latte? It wasn't too sweet and you could taste the sweet potato. So good! 

I also ordered the salted caramel macaroon...wasn't expecting much but it was AMAZING. The buttercream inside was light and airy with a swirl of caramel..DELISH.

Free wi-fi. I had the couch all to myself, the one thing I didn't notice was the amount of outlets they had. I think there were only a handful in various corners of the cafe but luckily it wasn't that crowded. 

They have an assortment of sweet cakes and mousse as well as a few savory items like sandwiches, baked breads, etc.

Gotta come here again!
author: Mai H.

description: Very delicious sweet potato latte with soy milk.  Found it when I happened to be in the neighborhood, but I will come back. Apparently, sweet potato latte is something from Korea.  The place is very cute inside too, and quiet.
author: Meredith G.

description: Had the best service by a lovely girl named Sammi! Welcomed me with a great smile and really made my day with her exceptional service! Definitely coming back! The drinks was absolutely delicious!
author: Ben R.

description:
I really shouldn't be writing reviews that makes one of my favorite spots even more busy... but I can't help it.  They run a tight ship and offer unique drinks with menu of accompanying desserts and snacks.  I go for the standard cup of coffee most of the time, but will occasionally go with the chai or vanilla latte.  Lighting is comfortable.  The tables are clean.  Internet access.  Games such as chess/scrabble/jenga are available.    And the walls are decorated with unique artwork.  That's all I need to stay productive.

Self promoting plug --- If you are a programmer, go there more often!  I'm looking to discuss startup projects.  Would like to meet you!
author: Randall L.

description:
HORRIBLE SERVICE! I moved two tables of two together because we had four people. The male blonde hair staff came up to me and said "what do you think you're doing?" I said, "we have four people." He goes, "We don't like it when you guys join tables together like that." We got pissed and just left. We were going to order a lot of drinks and food but decided not to because of his attitude. 

Definitely not going back if that guy still works there. Might consider if he leaves.
author: Denise C.

description:
A welcomed rare find in the neighborhood! 

Great space - filled with cozy set tables and comfy couches with soothing background music, it's suitable for chatting with friends, working away on laptops, catching up reads, (or playing board games - thought I saw some...)

Wide menu - from eats to drinks, they cover a wide variety; I've not yet had any of the sweets/savories, but they sure do offer many from known third parties. Thoroughly enjoyed the sweet potato latte (try it!). But not so much the watery Americano.

Late(r) hours - this is the cherry on top of this gem; unlike all the other cafes in town (other than in NB), this may be the only cafe that stays open past 10PM!

Take-Away: This cafe won my nomination at glance of its hours and then my vote at sip of the sweet potato latte.
author: Carol K.

description:
FIrst and foremost: PLEASE GET MORE ELECTRICAL OUTLETS.

Other than that, it's a cool little place to come and study. They sell food and pastries along with Japanese inspired cafe drinks. Not much of a tea selection from what I remember though. I'd come back or use this place as a meeting ground. However, come expecting a younger crowd. My last visit had a lot of teenyboppers who could become intolerable to some.
author: Paul B.

description:
If I had gone to college in the city, this would definitely be one of my favorite study spots. The place is well lit and has the look and feel of one's own living room! It's quiet with the occasional cries of the latte machines--nothing headphones can't drain out. 

I tried their famous sweet potato latte which isn't as good as I thought it'd be. I think they took the whole concept too literal as it is basically a cup of mashed sweet potatoes with some liquid. Meh. Way too starchy and thick for my taste. I'll be back to try their other drinks though!
author: Brian M.

description:
I can see why Yakini has good Yelp ratings.
Immediately you are greeted by fun, hanging letters at the door. Once into the cafe, a wealth of options is before you. Thank god this isn't just another coffee place; YQ satisfies my desire for tea, apple cider or hot chocolate!

Had great service, the table set-ups were cute - would come back here again in a heartbeat!

(Just FYI - $10 credit card minimum, bring cash)
author: Rachel R.

description:
I really want to give this place a high rating base on their decoration and the comfort environment. Though the bad sides really outweighted the good sides. 

Good sides: comfort place with free wifi.

Bad sides: the coffee I ordered Is below mediocre. 
The wifi gets slow sometimes
Parking is ridiculous.

I think i will come again in the future , to give them another try on another to see if that could change my opinion about this place. Other than that, 4 stars for the environment and 2 stars for their drinks
author: Wai C.

description: Super cute cafe!!  You can get pastries and desserts here and even macarons from Patisserie Phillipe!  We came here to get macarons for a friend because we were attending a party and I really wanted to try the sweet potato latte!  Be careful because I totally burnt my tongue on the first sip!  It was scorching hot.  I got it to go because we were on our way to a party, and even after a couple hours it was still pretty hot!  It was really good though.  It was sweet but not overly teeth hurting sweet.  Would definitely come here if I lived i the city and just chill.
author: Kymberli C.

description:
Great macarons that are apparently from Patisserie Philippe, good space fo study or go for a little chat, and the only place in SF that I know that do the sweet potato latte.  This latte is rather heavy, but so worth it!!!!!!

warms me up on a chilly day
author: Jane K.

description:
Nice little home-y place you can come in to some homework done. Sometimes its a little too warm and cozy inside that you want to take a nap instead. 

I tried their Sweet Potato Latte multiple times, and i loved it. Personally I prefer the cold one over the hot. Its really refreshing and you can taste the little bits of sweet potato in the drink. Their Yuzu tea is also good. I do feel the price little high but its all worth it in the end.
author: Jonathan K.

description: Worst experience ever. Wifi doesn't work and the owner basically just said she doesn't care. Bad service. Don't come!
author: Qiushi Y.

description:
quaint little cafe, well-lit. although it's not huge, the tables are spaced far enough apart.
free wifi for customers (yay!) and their sweet potato lattes are so comforting!
author: Susy C.

description:
As expressed by a Korean friend, "this place reminds me of cafes in Korea." I will completely take her word for it. I always favor places that are successful at accurate replications because they are saving me the price of a plane ticket. Thanks!

It was Saturday night. A girlfriend and I had finished dinner not far from YakiniQ. We agreed to make a quick stop here for coffee and dessert, but we ended up staying for two hours to attempt at a 1500 piece puzzle. (Yes, we were kidding ourselves.) In terms of desserts, our favorite small bites were the matcha shortbread cookies and green tea shaved ice (which we defaulted on when we learned they were out of a certain flavor of Tara ice cream).

Additional reason I love this cafe: they are open late! I am one of those people who can have coffee around the clock and it doesn't affect my sleep in the least. Lucky me.
author: Lily T.

description:
This is my go-to spot whenever I am in Japantown for a meeting - I can come here knowing I can get a delicious pick-me-up like their chai soy lattes, vanilla latte, and green tea latte. 

Most recently I got famous, special Sweet Potato Latte- perfect on a cold rainy day. It does get on the very-sweet side near the end. Very thick drink with real pureed sweet potato. Reminds me of the adorable Korean cafes in LA. 

This place is very spacious with tables set far apart making it a great study spot- it's always very quiet here. The baristas here are super-welcoming and have contagious smiles. Very cute whimsical decor and paintings hanging on the wall. Mismatch, but clean and new, furniture gives it character and chic-ness. The front of the cafe is lined with beautiful, overpriced desserts: cakes, pastries, and macarons!

This place just makes me happy.
author: Eva H.

description:
Too too adorable.

European inspired decor with mismatched chic furniture. Ikea strung paper lantern lights. Warm and welcoming atmosphere perfect for conversation and study. It is a small getaway from the outside. 

Drinks: Sweet potato latte! Miss this drink sorely from my Korea travels. It's typically a seasonal drink similar to pumpkin lattes. If you like baked sweet potatoes this is its close cousin. Ginger tea is a refreshing cold drink if the weather is warm.

Noise: About 60% - 70% of the people are working/studying quietly. Always one or two tables where people are catching up. Nothing a pair of earbuds cannot fix.

Outlet: Only one side of the wall has outlets. During peak hours you might hafta negotiate to recharge.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Nice big space. Cool location in Japantown which needs more cafes. The Sweet Potato latte is to die for! And the staff was friendly.
author: Josh H.

description:
I was meeting a friend here and accidentally went upstairs to the Korean BBQ restaurant with the same name. Make sure  you stay on the ground level.

Very cozy home feel place. Super comfy chairs and set up. I got a Chicken Banh Mee (Vietnamese sandwich) which was amazingly tasty and very different from way these are traditionally made. Also comes with a side salad. My friend got a shaved ice which they used fresh fruits and had nice presentation.

The cashier was sweet and welcoming. Great place to hang out and talk. Lots of open space to spread out your stuff if needed.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Sweet Potato Latte...These 3 words totally got my attention when I searched for a cafe with free wi-fi near Japantown.  

I was intrigued to try this drink when I read it on one of the tips, so I packed up my bag with my laptop and sketchbook. 

So, here I come!  =P

I walk on Post St. quite often and I would have never seen this place because it is tucked in between all of these Asian restaurants, but when you see that "black chalkboard" that reads..."Home of the Sweet Potato Latte."  Then, you're in the right place.  

I tried their Sweet Potato Latte as an iced drink because the weather has been pretty warm and sunny for SF.  
      -When you take your first sip, you'll get bits of sweet potato.  It's a nice texture and you can definitely taste the slight sweetness. 
     -They served it in a pretty tall glass and it was worth the $4. 
     -I loved the drink because it wasn't too weird, sweet or bland.  
 
Sweet Potato Iced Latte was a light and delicious cold beverage that makes you smile!

{Perks}
-Quiet atmosphere, not overwhelmingly crowded like Starbucks 
-Clean, vintage-like decor, borderline of shabby chic
-Lots of tables and chairs to relax and/or to study 
-Plenty of Outlets :D (I'm always looking for one.) 
-Free wi-fi (Solid connection even though there are a lot of laptops)
-Open till 10PM during the weekdays
-Staff is SUPER friendly.  

Next time, I'm going to get a baked good along with my drink, especially the macrons and cakes.  

I'm happy to say that I found a great cafe that serves quality drinks and goodies.  

Happy Yelping!
author: Deborah C.

description:
A friend of mine spoke of a sweet potato latte. "Surely you jest!" I said. "I do not jest, and don't call me Shirley."

Such a thing does exist, and it can be found at YakiniQ Cafe. It's a rather large cafe space with lots of different seating options--tables, conversation groups. If I lived in the area, it's just the sort of place I would go to regularly to get a little work done. We ordered the aforementioned sweet potato lattes, as well as the rose macarons, and neither disappointed other than them being too sweet as a pairing. If I find myself in Japantown looking for a place to cool my heels for a bit, I will definitely go back to YakiniQ.
author: Jen D.

description:
Sweet potato latte? Okay!

I've been here twice, once to try the latte, second to try the ice cream. This is a really cute open space and a good place to study. There are a good selection of food, sweets and drinks.

I was actually trying to find somewhere to eat lunch when I zoned in on the sweet potato latte. My thoughts "I have to try it."  This drink is very interesting and it's exactly like eating sweet potato in liquid form. It tasted more like a sweet potato soup, but it was light and airy in texture. It's very comforting and definitely something I want to drink on a cold rainy day.

Ice cream was good. I just can't justify paying over 5 dollars on a small scoop of ice cream here though.
author: Jenny M.

description:
We were looking for a tea house to take our out-of-town guests to after dinner and I yelped YakiniQ.  I was unsure what it would be like but I was pleasantly surprised.  From the ambience, to the staff, to the tasty treats, this place was a hidden gem in SF - it makes me want to explore Japantown even more!  The only thing missing was some healthier options like gluten or dairy-free cookies and cakes.  

I envision going back someday after some amazing sushi so we can sip tea and play scrabble!  Super cute place.
author: D P.

description:
The matcha latte was okay, could've used a bit of sugar/sweetening and the milk felt a bit flat if that makes any sense. A very one dimensional taste. My cousin had no comment on her vanilla latte. 


The wifi was wonky too! My cousin and I were trying to get online but it kept saying that the network didn't work. When my cousin finally got on, her computer warned her that someone was trying to use her IP address. Not YakiniQ's fault, I know, but the wifi experience overall. 

The baked good/pastries looked great and the Financier cake was tasty - very rich but it was meant to be eaten with tea so I can see how well it mixes with black tea. 

Service is very friendly though. Spaces fill up fast so test your luck or come at odd hours!
author: Christal Y.

description:
I know what you're up to, cafe. You think that if I stumble downstairs from your bbq sister next door looking for shelter to while away my hour-long wait, you can lure me with a sweet potato latte, which speaks to the heart of every Korean, and then if I sit in your shop ooh-ing and aah-ing at all of the cute until my name is called, I will not notice until it's too late that I can't fully assault the meatmeatmeat privileges of AYCE because I have a rich beverage holding court inside my tummy, pursing its lips, crossing its arms and giving me a "you got played" side-eye.

I know this is your schtick, cafe, and damn if I don't fall for it every time.

I don't really know why I like YakiniQ Cafe so much-- can we all agree that it's completely overpriced (read: it's priced as if it were a cafe in Seoul, which, for all of its cheap and wonderful eats, charges disproportionately high prices for non-alcoholic beverages) and, honestly, that its offerings are not particularly over-the-top tasty? But I still love this cafe so much; maybe because not many places yet offer sweet potato lattes year-round in the Bay Area, or because it's such a brightly-lit, cheerful, quiet-but-still-upbeat oasis from the general gloom that lingers over that area of the city, or maybe because one night, while sequestered here in queue for a particularly late barbecue jaunt, the manager and the barista announced closing time with a harmonica and a rhyme and a little bit of my heart melted into my sweet potato latte.

Yeah, I can't really put a finger on what it is that attracts me to this place. It's a host of contradictions, quietly but assertively Asian in a ^ ^ way, intimate but open, convivial but private. Walk into YakiniQ Cafe at any given time and literally every customer looks happy. It may not be the cheapest or even the best, but this rabbit-hole has me entertaining a different curiosity each time, and that alone is worth something.
author: Nuri K.

description:
After my latest visit, I have to up my rating to a 5.  The service is fantastic!  The girls at the counter are super sweet and helpful, so that definitely contributed.  I ordered their famous sweet potato latte, which is seriously like drinking a liquid, creamy sweet potato.  Yum!  I also bought their homemade lemon-iced butter cookies.  These were definitely buttery and perfectly soft.  A subtle lemon icing which had a nice balance between sweet and tart topped it off nicely.  

My boyfriend ordered their hot apple cider and a slice of apple pie.  I sampled both items, and boy, it was apple goodness!  The cider is delicious and the crust on the apple pie was buttery and baked to the right texture and crispness.  

Everything else also looked so tempting, so I'm planning on coming back again and again!  Things that caught my eye while waiting: macarons, black and white, napoleon, and creme brulee.  Until next time, YakiniQ!
author: Can C.

description:
Sweet potato latte was really good.  I asked for a decaf version and the guy says, there's no caf in it.  I think it's made with sweet potato puree and milk.  There are other non-traditional drinks on the menu which I'd like to go back and try.

They have a good selection of pastries and desserts, but some of them are really pricey.  It's over $7 for a piece of cake and the macarons are $2.25 each.  I tried rose and earl grey flavor and LOVED the earl grey.  The rose one tasted like eating soap because of the fragrance.  BUT, I will say that the consistency and texture of the macarons is the best I've had in the city.
author: Irene C.

description:
I never even realized this place existed for the longest time until I searched up cafes to study at. It's tucked under the under the all you can eat Korean bbq restaurant of the same name. In fact, they even share the same bathrooms. But I'm glad I found it. It's a very cute Asian cafe, the trendy kinds you see in Japan and Korea a lot. It's decently quiet, has a variety of drinks and food, plenty of outlets, and free wifi.

There are lots of places to sit with many different types of tables and chairs. They don't really match, but it adds to the cuteness of it all.  Lighting could be a little brighter for studying, but it's meant to be a cafe so it sets the mood. There are also board games if you want to sit and hang out with friends.

The pastries are okay. Normal cafe stuff, I'm assuming made elsewhere. I also got their famous sweet potato latte. It was just OK, I would have preferred it to be a little smoother, didn't like the little nubs of potato floating around. Also could've used some spice or sweetness or something. It was a somewhat flat, dull taste. 

Overall, a decent place to study or to hang out. I want to try some more of their other drinks and foods too.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
I went in with a friend searching for dessert and coffee after lunch. The interior was somewhat spacy and comforting for anyone to either have a conversation or to simply work on their laptops on any assignments. I assumed so many people have heard of this cafe since every seats and tables were occupied. Anyway, there were a wide array of pastries, cookies, and pies at the table; french macaroons, princess cakes, and tiramisus in the display fridge; and a whole wall menu full of drinks and other snacks for us to order. Definitely too many choices for us to decide what to order, but we managed to order...

Friend had
A slice of princess cake, an Italian soda, and an Iced Jujube Tea with honey
I had
A tiramisu, an Earl Grey French Macaroon, a Soy Latte and an Iced Jujube Tea with honey

The princess cake and tiramisu were moist and delicious although to me being a cheapy, I found price to be a bit more than other cake shops, but nonetheless it was very enjoyable.

The soy latte was alright. If you plan to sit in the cafe, they'll serve your lattes in a bowl-like cup without a handle. I drank my latte as if I was drinking soup from a bowl without spoons.

Both my friend and I enjoyed the iced jujube tea. The cashier recommended us to order it iced since it was more refreshing that way. It's a bit too sweet, but with the ice in the drink, you could possibly let it melt a bit to blend in with the drink itself.

Finally, we did get a couch/sofa/loveseat to ourselves. They had a table where people placed down their business cards. A scrapbook was there for us customers to draw/doodle/write anything in our minds. Gotta say, these artists should be discovered :)

...and I forgot to mention you can use your credit card for purchases over $10.
author: Kim L.

description:
Great atmosphere, a nice place to hang out.  It's just.... kind of PRICEY!  I'm never going to forget paying app. $7 for a piece of cake.  If I think about the cakes back in Korea's cafes, I guess the price is around the same level.  But still.  Ouch.  The macarons are around $2 for one too.  Try Chantal Guillon on Hayes and Octavia for the macarons.  :/ it's 1.50 each and they don't tax you.

If you're just crashing for wifi, get a coffee and save yourself.
author: Hyun S.

description:
Great cafe for a quiet working environment.

BUT, when they served me a tiramisu cake, it was extremely soggy and gross. I told the older lady and she said, "oh, you are a piece already? Sorry, we can't do anything about it."

- first off, how could anyone know how bad it was without trying it

- secondly, wouldn't the right thing be to take the cake back and offer something else?
author: Stephen U.

description:
3.5 Stars. 

I'm originally from LA and I often frequent cafes to do work and study since it's such a great environment with tables, chairs, food, and drinks! Everything I need in one place! 

I found YakiniQ by accident, but was super surprised by how cute the decor is and how it's so simple and spacious.  I also love the dim lighting that just creates a homey vibe!  There's also free wifi at this place, which makes it the ideal studying spot for me, with the exception of... 

Pricing:  The pricing is a bit much for what they offer. For a slice of cake it's $7.50-$8 bucks and for drinks this really ranges.  The cakes that I've had thus far have been delicious though, but I just feel like its a little much for a SLICE of cake? Oh wells, its worth it for the ambiance.

Outlets: This is the main reason why I need to drop a star.  The last two times that I've been here there have been no seats available on the right side where there are outlets.  There are also outlets on the left side with the bigger tables, however, the cafe blocked them ALL out. Why would they do this? I don't know, but I don't like it and I find it a bit inconvienent that they have available seating that can be filled with customers, but they are not because they blocked out all the outlets.  

This was perhaps really frustrating after driving out to the city to try and do some work and looking for parking.  Thank goodness I didn't order food before checking the availability of outlets first.

Overall, I love this place, it's cute and the cakes are good too, but I wish that there were more outlets :( I'll come again crossing my fingers outlets will be opened up.


PS.  they are suppose to be home of the sweet potate latte, I got this, but it was terrible :( stick with something more normal!
author: Suzie B.

description:
It is really nice in here!

Everything is so picturesque and cute -- I think this is my favorite place in J-Town to lounge!  The waiters were very friendly and remembered us from last time, over 3 months ago! This is definitely a cool place to kick it and chill with friends. I would visit more often if I lived in the City.
author: Mike C.

description: Never again. The yuzu Palmer was not as good and it went up in price. It costs more than Starbucks! I'm going to make my own at home. Not enough seats and people basically park there all day. So if you're not early enough you're sol
author: Vanessa K.

description: Most adorable cafe ever with the best drinks and snacks. Don't think the sweet potato latte comes with a shot though.  Crayons, board games, art, wifi, charming bric a brac
author: Christina H.

description:
I can't get enough of this hidden coffeeshop in Japantown.  It stands out among the rest of the old places that have been around the mall forever.  The staff and owners are so friendly and welcoming, it's hard not to love this place.  

The woman I saw behind the counter said she bakes half of the items that are offered, and having personally sampled most, I can tell you they are quite good.  There was even a gluten-free, dairy-free option, which was delicious.  

The treats range in price, some higher than others.  But a spam musubi there is a deal, considering how good it is.  The juju drinks are also really interesting, if not chunky in texture.  It's an acquired taste, I believe.

Comfortable seating, wifi, and a large, quiet space where people respect the noise level make this the perfect oasis from the weirdly antiquated Japantown.  LOVE.
author: Kristina K.

description:
Went here with my sister last week as we were both in the mood for something to drink after walking uphill all day. I ordered the iced sweet potato latte, she ordered the iced jujube tea.

The iced sweet potato latte tasted EXACTLY like sweet potato... It was pretty interesting, but I probably wouldn't order it again given the chance. It was very fibrous, but not too sweet.

The iced jujube tea was also just alright. The first sip tasted very, very sweet, but it also tasted just like jujube. It reminded me a bit of drinking sweet syrup, but after awhile we grew accustomed to it (or maybe the ice just melted and diluted the taste a bit).

Didn't get a chance to try any of the desserts as most of them seemed a bit expensive (around $7 to $10 for a small cake) for our budget. The desserts did, however, look very pretty. They also had a few cookies, scones, and macarons for sale, but we didn't feel like trying those either.
author: Audrey D.

description:
This is my go to spot to study, read or just chill out in Japantown. It's quite honestly one of the only cafes there, but even if there were 10 others, I would probably go here because it is amazing! 

The vibe is really chill and its easy to get a lot of work done there without too many distractions. They do place what sounds like Korean pop and covers of popular American songs which are surprisingly really good, but the volume is kept low so its not disturbing. 

The food is great, but a bit overpriced and hence the 4 star rating. You should try their Tiramisu, brownies and the organic ice cream. 

Overall a great cafe.
author: Rahul N.

description:
Wow, this is my favorite new cafe. Tucked away from the usual annoying suspects you find in most neighborhood cafes.

1st the decor is simple but very welcoming.

2nd the tables are large enough for a book and a laptop. and your not squeezed next to the other tables.

3rd the music is fun but, not so intrusive.

4th the coffee is great but slightly pricey

5th they have some good food like Bunh Mee.

6th it's in Japantown.

7th no annoying hipster with better than thou attitude(so far).

8th free-wifi with purchase.

Although I want to see this place do well; I really hope the high maintenance, pushy, vocally obnoxious San Franciscans I have to endure elsewhere don't find this place.
author: Anthony M.

description: This is one of my favorite cafe's in San Francisco. They make good coffee and latte. I always get their vanilla latte. It is a good place to unwind after a hectic pace in San Francisco. Free wifi and they have some reading material also. They are in the Japan town neighborhood in San Francisco.
author: Raman S.

description:
I love this cute cafe that's right across the street from where i work.  
Lots of selection of coffee and desserts. 

I normally come here for their steamed soy milk with vanilla flavored on my lunch break.  Yes, my small cup of soy milk does added up pretty expensive for to go but I usually don't mind because it's my quick fix since I'm cutting back on coffee.  I'm taking a star off because today I asked for the same order and I got charge $4.50 for it ... but the lady that made my steamed soy milk forgot my vanilla syrup that I "paid" for it...  Since it happened only this time, I'll get over it. But next time when I pick up, I'll double check with the staff before walking back to work....
author: Selina L.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised by this cafe in the middle of Japantown after reading several conflicted reviews. 

*Ambience (5/5): it's definitely a nice, soothing, and somewhat creative environment here if you want to get some studying done. The only I have to complain about is that the large tables don't have outlets. The background music they play is also quite good. Definitely a good place to get some work done. 
*Food/drinks (4/5): I tried the earl grey macaron and mocha. I would say, the macaron is definitely not very authentic but the do have some interesting Asian flavors. The macaron is a bit dense and doesn't have the light fluffy texture. The mocha I would say is quite good. It's like a hot chocolate almost. However, I do think it's pretty pricey here. The macaron was $2.25 and mocha was ~$4. 

Overall, on a weekday, this place is not too crowded with enough space for study.
author: Joyce B.

description:
Love this place!!

The negatives first: they don't have too many outlets and the banh mi sandwich is not authentic in any way and pretty overpriced but whatever you're getting it from a cafe.  What can you expect?

The positives:  Spacious! Clean! Cute!  Okay, calming down now, it really is a great space to get some work done or chat it up with friends.  Their drinks come in really tall glasses and are delicious (I got some chocolate mint thing - and mint is my heaven so it was great).  I want to try the green tea frap or whatever it is next time.  Also, they play great music.  Got some She & Him, Phoenix, Bag Raiders, etc. 

Will definitely be coming back
author: Christine B.

description: So my friend was telling me about this place because her sister said it was pretty nice and cute inside. I was super excited to give this place a try and i ended up loving it. This place is starting out to be one of my favorite cafes.  I will usually park in the garage across the street and not have to worry about parking.  The service here is always great, we are always greeted and we are never rushed when deciding what to order. I've tried the sweet potato latte and it was ok to me. I've had the Yuzu Honey Tea, which to me tasted like something I can get at an Asian Market. But their cappuccino and mocha are pretty good.  It might be hard to find a place it sit at times, but you can sit and wait for a table when one opens up.  I love the ambiance of the place, its feels classy and relax here.   I've love their macaron selection here, my favorite is the earl grey and cassis macarons, I get sad when they run out.  Their tiramisu and espresso chocolate mousse cakes are ok.  The espresso chocolate mousse cake is so cute. It was in a shape of a tea cup. It was almost too cute for me to eat it.  Overall, I love this place, I need to try their Tara's Organic ice cream here next time.
author: Belinda C.

description: Pick a chair, they have short chairs, wooden chairs, table chairs, sofa chairs.  The place was crowded for a Sunday afternoon.  If you are into sweets and baked goods, they have something for you to choose:  coffee, ice coffee, teas, flavored drinks, shaved ice, Ice cream, macaroons, french pastries, home made pies, and other pastries.  I had to try the sweet potato latte.  For some reason I thought it was sweet potato coffee.  I didn't taste any coffee.  It was more like sweet potato with frothy hot milk.  The surprise is there were two chunky sweet potato inside.  It was good quality sweet potato (the red kind).  Even though I requested less sugar, it was still too sweet for me.  Maybe they forgot my request.  Only in Japantown, you see two ladies in kimonos sipping tea.  Cool.
author: Helen L.

description: Love the atmosphere of the place. Delicious pastries and great drink selection; got the drink they are known for which is the sweet potato latte (SPL), good flavor and not too sweet but I think Joy's Place SPL is better. Yuzu pound cake was delicious. Staff could be friendlier though but all in all a great place to study or have coffee with friends.
author: Casandra R.

description:
Oh YakiniQ cafe!

YakiniQ (BBQ in Korean) is off the chains!  So upstairs is Korean BBQ restaurant and downstairs is their really cool cafe.

My friend and I ordered the sweet potato latte and got a princess cake, YUM!!!!

*Sweet Potato Latte - has no espresso in it, it's steamed milk with mashed sweet potatos, really awesome!!!

*Princess Cake - fondant with moist almond goodness inside, definitely a cake to share, rich, but bordering too sweet.  

The location is great, nicely laid out, roomy with table's and a coffee house setting, I even got a chance to teach my friend how to play chess here.  The last time I came here, there was a book club having an intense conversation on the lastest read they had.

YakiniQ Cafe you ARE the BUSINESS!!!
author: Edrian D.

description: Nice cafe! My friend and I had a good time there. The music, the people, the coffee and tea... I enjoyed almost everything there. I'll be back definitely!
author: Ruo W.

description: Most amazing french macaroons, but also ridiculously expensive. This is possibly the most I've paid for macaroons-- $2.45 each!
author: Peggy L.

description: This is hands down my favorite cafe in the city.  I've blown so much money here to caffeinate myself while plugging away at applications, but I don't regret a single cent.  The sweet potato latte and the winter special pumpkin latte are of course my favorites for cold weather, but the green tea really warms you up as well.  The seating area is quiet, and the seats and tables are far enough apart, so it is perfect for studying and working and being productive in general.  Love this place!
author: Tracey L.

description: It looks kinda small from the outside but once you go in you'll see the place is pretty big and there are ~10 tables with 4 seats. I had sweet potato latte, which was okay. It would've been better if it was little bit hotter. Overall, I'd say it's a quite and cozy cafe.
author: Evan L.

description:
Although it looks like a little bit of a hole in the wall, this cafe has a great ambiance and is actually quite expansive inside with plenty of seating room and studying space.

The drinks are delicious, their coffee and espresso drinks are highly recommended but I recommend the Yuzu Honey Tea which is non-caffeinated but the perfect thing to keep you warm on a freezing cold San Francisco summer day.

The staff is welcoming and friendly, they were very kind and although there is a $10 minimum for credit card purchases they didn't give me a hassle about not having enough cash and ran my card for just my tea anyway.

I highly recommend this cafe and will be returning anytime I'm in the area.
author: Tom L.

description:
Sweet potato latte was yummy and creative!  The dessert selection was also very enticing.  Too bad I didn't feel like stuffing myself more after a good brunch.  

This is a cute cafe that is spacious and bright.  Minus one star for the flakey wifi access.  We wanted to get some work done, so it was a little disappointing that I could not get a reliable connection that wouldn't drop.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
One of my close friends took me here for a catch up sesh. It's such a cozy and friendly ambiance  for doing that but I see a lot of people come here when they have to hit the books too. It's definitely a pretty stress free environment and beats studying in the library for sure.It feels like one of the quaint cafes that i visited in Korea this summer! I love it!!!   

Their goguma (sweet potato)  latte had me at first sip. I had a lot of those in korea and this one is comparable, perhaps even better than those. It was perfect balance of smoothness with frothiness  and you could definitely taste the sweet potato. It was ground pretty well and no major chunks were found. 

We also tried the earl grey and pistachio macaroons. They  were delicious though they kind of tasted similar. They went perfectly with my latte.

Feeling a very sweet tooth today we also decided to get a seasonal fruit patbingsoo ( korean shaved ice) as well. This was delicious. It is topped with vanilla ice-cream, strawberries, kiwi, banana, condensed milk and red bean. The best part of course was the mochi balls on top. 

I will definitely be back here to visit whether to study or just to chillax with a homey.

 Its earned a spot in my heart! :)
author: Sharon Y.

description:
Was expecting a Japanese meat bar but instead found a Korean style cafe!
A bit pricey but I definitely enjoyed this place ^^

Had the yuzu iced tea and was perfect as I waited for an appointment in the area. The staff is friendly and the ambiance is perfect for lounging around and studying in ones work. 

Sadly much of my time spent here was spent frantically researching an upcoming hairstyle choice :(

Anyways good tea, pastry, staff, vibe. Check it out!
author: Daniel K.

description:
YakiniQ Cafe is the cafe on the ground floor of YakiniQ KBBQ. They have everything a cafe has from coffee to free wifi. There's plenty of seats with tables on the inside. Most of the tables are two seaters, but there are a few for around four people. Then there's the couch area in the middle of the room for bigger groups. Their wifi is a bit spiffy where it sometimes disappears for a few seconds and comes back after. It's pretty quiet inside which makes this a nice place to go and study or for quiet time.

The desserts are great! Flour-less chocolate cake is very artistically pleasing and tastes nice. It's literally a tiny chocolate cup filled with chocolate cream with mixed berries on top. The macaroons are expensive, but delicious!. It's definitely a most try if you're here.

The drink: Mocha tasted pretty good. Supposedly, they use TCHO chocolate for their mocha from what they advertise. The Sweet potato latte tastes exactly what it sounds. These two drinks were pretty good overall.
author: Steven B.

description:
Great cafe - best in the neighborhood.

It's got it all: super nice folks behind the bar; quaint atmosphere with each table having different chairs and a comfy couch; and fabulous baked goods (courtesy of Patisserie Philippe, try the macaroons which are incredible).

So run down here and "yak" it up with friends.
author: David A.

description:
Ginger honey tea!!!! 

Please spend a couple of hours here.. play some jenga and enjoy the drinks... the Ambience 

To get access to the Wifi, you have to buy something.
author: Abhi M.

description:
This place is like a beautifully curated vintage furniture store that happens to serve equally charming cafe goods. A huge welcome when you're stuck in the Starbucks routine.

When you walk inside, one of the first things you'll notice are the unique accents, like a small tree or mismatched chairs or a branch (tastefully placed, of course). Koreans seem to have a real knack for designing pretty places. 

It's easy to spend a few hours in here getting lost in a good book or likewise, in the world of Facebook and Gmail. The nice part is you can get a perfectly crusty quiche lorraine or a frothy sweet potato latte to accompany you in whatever task you're taking on.

I found the owner and her employees to be extremely hospitable and friendly. They also let us use the space for one of the SF Int'l Asian American Film Fest workshops, which meant we completely uprooted the feng shui of their furniture layout for a few hours. No matter. They were gracious about and helped us rearrange everything afterwards.

Remember to bring cash when you visit, unless you plan on spending more than $10! Free wifi too.
author: liz c.

description:
SF was sorely in need of a k-cafe -- as an LA refugee, I felt something missing inside after losing access to cute decorations and $7 lattes. But the prices here are nothing compared to Yellow House or Loft -- half as much; it's almost unheard of! 

Workers are really nice. And, as has been said, none of the general "cafe cast."
author: Steven B.

description:
I love coming here to study/work.  They have large tables so you can spread out and the entire place is pretty well lit.  

I only had their chicken salad sandwich which was very good!  They also have Might Leaf tea which is a +1 in my book!  Their coffee is not great, but it does the job.  

The people are extremely nice and sweet.  They have wifi (I haven't really used it) but my friends say it's pretty spotty.
author: S R.

description:
I was really craving some macarons and I was in Japantown and quickly yelped and YakiniQ came up. 

It's a small little cafe, a bit on the pricier side, but very cozy and comfortable. Each macaron was 2.25, which I thought was quite expensive because the infamous Bottega Louie in SoCal is 1.50 a piece. 

I asked for recommendations and ended up picking out the earl grey, hazelnut, yuzu green tea, and pistachio flavored macarons. 

I am a huge fan of sweets, but I don't like things that taste like sugar with no flavor. The only macaron flavored I like was hazelnut, but I am biased because I think anything hazelnut flavored is good. I was a bit disappointed because the macarons were way too sweet for my liking and I felt like I was swallowing sugar and butter down my throat. Gross!

Not quite sure if I would come back....maybe to try their lattes but definitely not macarons again!
author: Laura L.

description: Went here as part of an Edible Excursion tour and was introduced to sweet potato latte.  Oh my goodness, it so works.  The cafe is quite comfortable with a large table in the middle.  I have to admit, I probably would've passed this place up if walking down the street, and am so glad I was introduced to this cafe.  Everything else looks so good and I plan to be back.  Wonderful and friendly staff.  Beautiful artwork on the walls.  Go in and try the sweet potato latte which does NOT have espresso in it, but they did say espresso can be added.
author: Yvette M.

description:
Expensive, but spacious with unintrusive music, pretty good lighting, not too crowded - there were at least a few empty tables pretty much the entire time we were there studying, but I'm not sure if that's because it's relatively new.

They have a good sweet potato latte (I've never had one before but it was tasty and hot!) and my friend liked his yuzu palmer. Their baked goods also looked very tasty, and a lot of people were getting shaved Ice. 

Free wifi and ample outlets along the walls make this a great study spot, even if the drinks are a bit on the expensive side.
author: Kathleen L.

description: I never knew this place was here! One of the best hidden finds I found this week. The interior is designed to feel like a home. I ordered the Napolean and the filling was so creamy and yummy and the puff pastry was flaky and crunchy, not soggy. So good!
author: Karen T.

description: Baristas are the most friendly I've ever dealt with by far in SF; reminds me of my home coffee shops in Seattle. Great drink, great decor, cool little trinkets left around too that adds to the atmosphere
author: Stefan M.

description:
Amazing cafe! The drinks/food are so delicious. Everything is made with high quality ingredients and tastes amazing, that is why they are a little pricey. Stop complaining about the prices, they are a new business, so cut them some slack and help their small business grow. You can't get quality for cheap...and everything they put out is quality. The owner is so sweet and so are all the workers. The decor is beautiful, so well put together. The lighting is just perfect, it gives it a warm glow. The music is at the right volume. There are games to play and books to read while you are there.

Try the macarons, cupcakes, tara's ice cream, sandwiches, flatbread...it's all delicious!
Sweet potato latte, hazelnut latte, mochas, iced yuzu...hot chocolate! SO GOOD!
author: Gato P.

description: My bf and I found this cute little cafe when we were looking for coffee around Japantown. I'm so glad we decided to walk in! I loved the decor and environment of this place. It's a great spot for studying/working since it's nice, quiet, and spacious. I ordered my usual iced vanilla latte and I really enjoyed it! My bf got their jujube tea that was a bit too sweet. I really want to try their sweet potato latte and pastries next time.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
we found the CUTEST cafe in japantown with really nice owners. 
It's times like these that I wish I had enough of a mastery of prose to accurately describe the interior and vibe of this cafe, but you seriously just have to go for yourselves and see it in person to do it any justice. It is soo soooo cute, I could stay here for hours on end. The vibe instantly lifts your mood when you walk into its bright embrace. Their handwritten signs and menus are darling and makes you feel at home, their assortment of desserts is vast and delectable, and the interior decoration is really calming, spacious, and peaceful. There are nice big wooden tables, lots of hanging paper lanterns, chairs that don't match and yet are all comfortable, and LOTS OF DESSERTS. omg all these caffeinated and non-caffeinated drinks and delicious MACARONS. omgggg. While a bit larger than the average macaron, they are the perfect delicate texture, with just the right amount of fluffiness, just the right amount of chewiness, and packed full of robust flavors. 
There's cute art, a cherry blossom plant (well, branches in a big vase) and the music is peaceful. I cannot get over this place!
Comes fully equipped with outlets and free wifi, you cannot go wrong.

warning: minimum of $10 purchase to use credit card.
author: Tuwie N.

description:
Came here with some friends on a Saturday after walking around SF all day... 
If you're looking for a place to have a conversation and enjoy some light snacks, come here! 
The inside is pretty spacious and clean, with some minimal wall decorations and a eclectic mix of chairs and tables laid out. There's people working away on laptops at some tables while others are chatting away while enjoying drinks. 

I got the yuzu honey tea while another friend got the jujube honey tea... ohmydeargoodness, they're both amazing! The yuzu tea was citrusy and sweet, but not overbearing so and is pretty fragrant. Couple that with rose and passionfruit macarons and some nice conversation, a girl can stay there forever.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Love this little place.  It is a bit of a hike from where I am, but that doesn't matter.  It is very light and open, and great tables to work at.  

The iced tea comes in a super tall glass, which is fun.  I had their caprese sandwich and loved it.  Can't wait to try some desserts though.  

Finally, the ladies who work here are soooo friendly!  Haven't had such good customer service in ages :)
author: Cara M.

description:
We need more Asian style cafes here in SF!

I absolutely love this place! I don't think there really is another cafe in SF that is like this and if you do, TELL ME BITCH! No really. The workers here are very nice and friendly. The coffee and desserts here are pretty good! If you want to try something different then get the sweet potato latte, not a typical drink you can find at any other cafe. The ambiance was really nice and modern. Good place to study! They were playing some Utada Hikaru songs when I was there!

 Docked a star off because the wifi would disconnect every now and then and would sometimes be extremely slow. The food and drinks here are pretty expensive so I wouldn't buy anything here unless I am staying there and utilizing this establishment. But other than that I LOVE this place! Oh and there is a $10 minimum if you want to pay with a credit card.

EDIT: It gets crowded here on the weekends QUICK. Not cool. Especially people there like me stay in there for like FOREVER. F.O.R.E.V.E.R.
author: Simon L.

description:
On opening day I came to this cafe only to greet a friend but when I walked in to this place I said to myself. WOW! the environment was a bit empty but it was beautiful, all the tables near the wall had it's own halo of light and there is even a couch in the middle of the room with stools and chairs for a party of friends. You can even have a study group of 6 or 8 go there because behind the couch they have a rectangular dinner table for larger parties or as I said, study groups.'

They have a decent variety of drinks, deserts, baked pastries and etc. I especially like their Chai latte iced or hot. If I recall correctly the first time I tried chai Latte was at YakiniQ cafe on opening day and boy did it leave a beautiful lasting impression. Now every time I go there is just to get a cup of iced or warm chai latte. 

The Environment is very nice everyone is silent and not too loud. In fact it's silent enough for you to hear the classical music that they play play on a fairly low volume which in my opinion is very relaxing.

Unfortunately I love fairly far away, 1-2 hours to get there by Muni from balboa park station (*sad face*) but If it was any closer I would go there daily. I will come again soon Ms. Manager (I forgot your name)

I'd HIGHLY RECOMMEND going there. The manager remembers me even when I haven't gone there for a month. The servers are very nice, environment is relaxing and quite, the room is bright and it feels as if the sun is right above you. Come down to Japan town and Try them out I doubt that you'd regret it.

It's so good I would write a Review this long!
author: Ben L.

description:
This place is awesome for quiet studying.  The background music is just at a low hum, it's super clean and spacious with lots of desk space.  They also serve shaved ice with fruit, which I have not seen around in SF.  The owner is very nice as well, I didn't like the sandwich I was having so she changed it to something else to make me a happy costumer.  

If you drive to this cafe, you find residential parking around the corner which is good for 2 hours.
author: christina s.

description: I like the amount of seating in this cafe, but not enough outlets to go around, only one available, I believe. Very friendly servers and I loved the apple cider so much I ordered twice in one seating. We also tried some matcha and lavender shortbreads that we loved too.
author: May G.

description:
Super fob.  Super cute.

YakiniQ has a cute atmosphere, large tables, and plenty of space (and outlets).  The WIFI works, but cuts out randomly sometimes.  Patience-- it will come back.  The coffee is rather weak (per Korean/Asian style...), not not particularly cheap.  The food is expensive ($2.25 for a french macaron?! eek!), but it's a nice place to sit.  Expect to see groups of old Asian women or men chatting it up at tables next to you.

It can get cold, as they almost always have the door open.  Read: breeeezy fosheezy!

Last thing: If there is a Cherry Blossom parade going through town, you WILL hear crazy Asian ladies screaming atop floats.  But then again, we're in San Francisco . . .
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
I love the clean open space feel of this cafe. The service friendly, patrons well mannered, and good selection of food and drinks.
We had the famous sweet potato mocha, white mocha, regular coffee and some macaroons. The rose and passion fruit were our favorite. I'm curious to try more things there. Check this place out!
author: K S.

description:
Awesome! Awesome!! Awesome!!!
YakiniQ, you makes my day wonderful and perfect!

If you are crazy about macaroons like me, you will have to try and love the macaroons from here!!!!

The pastry chef does the perfect job on making macaroons! $2.25/piece
Isn't it a lil too pricy? Not at all~ it really worth every pennies. 

These macaroons are the best in SF. I have tried all the sweet/bakery shop in SF for macaroons. Believe me, these are the best!!!

so flavorful, taste nature and full of delicate aroma. nothing taste like artificial...
the best favor will be earl grey tea, rose, and pistachio!!
author: JustinE Y.

description:
Such a cute, cozy, comfortable coffee house. couches, awesome wall decor/paintings, all of elements are great to look at the space.

Great variety of dessert menu, sandwiches, breads and sweet things!!! MY favorite is Sweet potato Latte!!!;)

They provided free internet!!!!
Love love love this coffee place :)
author: jessica c.

description: Only tried the sweet potato latte and it was AMAZING!!
author: Crystal W.

description:
I started coming to this cafe literally the week it opened. I was on a stroll through Japantown, saw a chalkboard sign, and ventured inside. The lady at the front was really friendly and explained they had just opened.

I know there's been some comments on the slowness of the service, and I do agree sometimes that it can take a little bit of time. However, I think we all need to take a few minutes to breathe and stop acting like every second of our time is really that important. 

Sit down. They'll bring the drink to you in an awesome Euro-style bowl. If you get cider, they'll throw a stick of cinnamon in it. They have an eclectic mix of chairs and tables. There's a ton a space to spread out, and it's got that super clean Asian feel to it.

They've also got macaroons, ice cream, and sandwiches. And there's free wifi. Patronize! 

P.S. Also, bring cash, because there is a $10 minimum and even though I hate credit card minimums, I still overlook it for the greater good.
author: Terry H.

description:
We went on a Sunday afternoon. This place is clean and spacious, and feels pretty comfortable if you want to be alone or with a small group, and everyone is minding their own business. All of their pastries are on display and look tasty, and just slightly more expensive than you'd hope, but it's fun to hang out for a while so it's worth the price. 

The only thing we ordered was the green tea shave ice. It is a pile of shaved ice with simple syrup that you can't really taste, a scoop of green tea ice cream, azuki beans, and canned fruit salad. The ice was relatively coarse, not fine and fluffy, so by the time you're halfway through eating it, it has melted to form larger lumps and resembles crushed ice rather than shaved ice. The green tea ice cream is great. The beans are also decent. The fruit salad is weird but seems to be a common feature in Asian shave ice. When I ordered, I asked if they could leave the fruit off and the cashier looked at me funny, so I decided to try it. Not terrible but it would be better without the fruit.
author: Kelly B.

description:
This is a relatively new cafe place in Japan town. This is definitely the best cafe in Japan town. I love the interior of the place. It makes me feel cozy almost as I'm at home. If you want to get some work done, bring your books and laptop. They provide free wi-fi, bright lighting, and clean & quiet environment. There's no better cafe for the campers. There are plenty of tables and sofas and you can make yourself home here. 
This place serves coffee & tea, macarons, cakes, ice creams, quiche, scone, & etc. They have a great selection of tea, including Mighty Tea Leaf & Harney & Sons, amazing macarons, Tara's Organic Ice Cream (amazing), and possibly one of the best affogatos in town (Espresso poured over a scoup of vanilla ice cream). 
And to really make it a 5 star cafe, they have the friendliest staff ever. They work to keep the place clean and to bring out your orders promptly. Some people might say that there is nothing special about this place and that they do not have their own specialties in coffee, or bakeries, so they do not deserve any special remarks. That might be true in some sense, but think again, they do everything that a cafe should do and does it better. Give this place a try and you'll know what I mean. 
Lastly, this place is not that well known now because it is fairly new. That means that this place is not that packed as other cafes in Fillmore are. Take advantage of that now, because in a few months, simply by word of mouth, it's going to be a popular place among cafe campers.
author: Matt L.

description: In SF for a short visit and wanted to try this place out. Right across of the hotel I am staying at. Love the Matcha latte and sweet potato latte. Tried the earl grey, hazelnut, and green tea macaroons, love them all. Nice customer service, the guy that  made my first drink in the morning remembered me when I returned in the afternoon. Tomorrow, I think I'm going to try their lunch :)
author: Joe C.

description:
I absolutely love this place!  I heard about YakiniQ Cafe through a friend who works in Japantown.  Otherwise, I don't think I would have known that it existed.  

Ambiance: I would give the atmosphere a 5/5 rating.  The Cafe is small yet spacious enough to do work, or lounge around.  There are many paintings on the wall that are so unique and beautiful.  The music is cute as well-- very relaxing. 

Service:  5/5 The cashier was very friendly when I first walked in.  I asked her about different teas, and she was able to tell me the description of each, and gave suggestions to my liking.

Price:  It's a bit on the pricey side, so I don't think I'll be able to go here on a regular basis.  To give an example, I paid $4.25 for a tea with lemon in it.  Yes, I would have to agree that the tea was delicious and refreshing, but for $4.25 is pushing it.  

Overall:  You have to come here if you're in Japantown!  I can't wait to go back... but first I have to find a job :p
author: Alisha L.

description: The food is good; it's not super sweet. The staff is also friendly. The interior is simple. If you're looking for a place to study, this would be a great place. It's a nice quiet place to just sit and work. I feel bad chatting with my friend here, so we just got our drinks and food, ate them and left.
author: Stacy C.

description: During our week-long stay in San Francisco we started each day with coffee or tea from YakiniQ cafe. Friendly service, good coffee and pleasant atmosphere. Try their sweet potato latte! Good pastries, too.
author: Jack And Barbra D.

description:
We were in the area and wanted some coffee - this place looked SO Japanese and as a bunch of somewhat recently returned exchange students from Japan, we decided to go in. 

The two girls behind the counter were very sweet, but sweet jesus they were SLOW. It took almost 15 minutes for us to get our drinks and food (food was cake/cookies, so it's not like they had to bake anything before it got to us - they pulled it out of the case and then waited til our drinks were ready to serve it). 

When the drinks were done, we had to go BEHIND the counter to pick them up, which struck me as really weird/not so hygenic. I'm a former barista (over 4 years), and I found that to be a turn off.

The seating situation here sucked - all of the large, four person tables were taken up by students who had ALL of their stuff all over the tables. As a group of 3, we had to wait like vultures to grab a seat at the large couch in the middle of the cafe. This may have been because the Cherry Blossom festival was that day - so I can't accurately tell if this is par for the course or not. 

The people who sat there before us did not bus their own table, nor did anyone else we saw while we were there. The staff didn't seem to notice, or care - they were not very busy behind the bar. I notice this stuff as it used to be a major job task when I was a coffee girl. 

The food and drinks were pretty pricey - I don't know if that's typical for cafes in San Francisco or not, so I can't really award or take away points for that. I liked my strawberry italian soda, my compatriots didn't like their green tea lattes very much. The tiramisu was too heavy and was soaked in way too much rum (I guess that's not a complaint for some people? hehe).

On the upside, their iced drinks are served in GIANT glasses - very cute. They don't serve royal milk tea here, which seems bizarre for an Asian cafe. 

The cafe shares a bathroom with a Korean bbq restaurant, and it was kind of dingy. Also no paper towels, so we had to raid the men's bathroom for some. The hallway between the restaurant, bathroom, and cafe had a bunch of water all over the floor that looked stagnant!!

$10 minimum for credit cards if you're curious!
author: Natasha T.

description: This is one of my favorite places to hang out when I want a quiet, relaxed setting. Even though it is usually crowded, I always find a seat. Most people are enjoying the Wifi while they sip their coffee or tea. The pastries/desserts are delicious, too!
author: Eve F.

description:
Cute place. I've had the sweet potato latte, which was pretty good. I can see why people like it.  They use sweet potato puree and the drink is caffeine-free, so I usually order it in the evening when I stop by to kill some time. 

The strawberry yuzu drink (I think it's seasonal) is amazing. It's tied for my favorite non-alcoholic drink in the bay area. It's so good. It's so goooood. Get it iced.
author: Annie K.

description: Quite a nice place for study and chill out with friends. Serene and have lotta laptop plugs. And the cashier's attitude is not good. A bit aggressive.
author: Nathaniel K.

description:
I wish this place would open later because it's really nice to relax here in the evenings with a drink and a macaron or dessert. It's so nice to have an option for some evenings instead of a bar. We've been here a few times where a full cafe had to be kicked out at closing time.
I'm not a macaron expert but theirs are not overly sweet with good chewiness, also their tiramisu is pretty rich and delicious. I thought their pastries and desserts were quite good quality.
It is annoying when singles with their laptops take over a full table for hours, and I can understand from the business owner's perspective how that turns away other customers on busy nights. Maybe they could have a rule that the big table in the middle is for laptop users, so it would force these lonely hearts to have chance encounters with eachother, instead of sitting by themselves at a table each? Then put one powerbar right in the middle.
I think it's harsh to consider this business rude for not giving you a wifi password if you haven't purchased anything yet.
author: Dire S.

description:
This place is super girly and cute. Great for studying although not if you have to use the internet a lot, at least my internet connection kept on dropping. 

It is a pretty big open space with cute tables and chairs around the outside of the room, a very large group table and a couch in the middle of the room. I suppose the middle area would be great for study groups and such, but when I went it, it was absurdly quiet, I didn't feel like i could make any noise, let alone talk to someone or talk on the phone... but I guess that could be a good thing if you are looking for some serious study time. 

The coffee was decent and the quiche I had was pretty good too, but it is not a place i would seek out just for the food.
author: Rona Y.

description: I had their dessert (chocolate round ball thing) and it was yummmmm. I don't remember much about their tea or anything else. It was a nice place to lounge or study. Everybody seemed nice enough. There are board games in the back and some other activities. Relatively quiet place. Wifi provided for free. I'd probably come back but nothing I'd specifically come back for except for the atmosphere.
author: Vicki T.

description: Tasty banh mi, but please put more meat in the sandwich. Felt a little stiffed for the $8.95.
author: Genevieve R.

description:
Epic shaved ice for lunch. Thai chicken sandwich for dessert.

My how things have changed. Growing up flavored ice meant ice and syrup. At YakiniQ it means ice, fruit slices, marshmallows an ice cream. A meal. Enjoy this and your iPhones kids, we didn't have it this good.

Left me barely hungry for my Thai chicken on a baguette. Was good to rally. Delicious chunks of chicken, sweet chili sauce, salad on the side.

Make sure to leave room for the main course.
author: Jason B.

description:
Holy Cr@!p! this place is totally amazing!

It was love at first sight. Everything about it is a fusion of Japanese and a modern American cafe and bakery. The ambiance is clean, modern, quiet (but probably not for long when word gets out though).

Its a great place to work.

But.... the best thing is the pastries are absolutely amazing! My favorite so far is the 2 inch by 2 inch sea salt brownie. I didnt know so much love could be packed into such a tiny space. There is no way to describe it but Ill try- its rich, creamy, silky, very chocolaty and salty too. Just come and get 1 or 5 and you'll see.
