I dont know how they managed to make it so great. I am envisioning little Zen Buddhist Brownies meditating on being super delicious for about a week before being placed out for sale.

Anyways five stars at least!
author: Seth M.

description: This is my favorite little cafe in Japantown. I especially like the flower blossom yea that is great oh and they have musubis too! Perfect little snacks. There's free wifi too which is perf. Come in and read a book or work on your laptop for a couple hours.
author: Elliott A.

description: Really nice place to spend time at. I ordered the sweet potato latte as many reviewers suggested. Latte implies coffee or espresso served with steamed milk. This is why I was surprised to find the sweet potato latte without a taste of coffee, espresso, or caffeine. Tasty drink for a coffee alternative. There was definite taste of sweet potato. I did see the barista scoop in chunks of real sweet potato into the drink. This is not sweet like syrup or sugar. Nice, but I still prefer coffee latte.
author: Jenny F.

description:
You're a bitch if you don't give this place 5 stars.  There is absolutely nothing wrong with this place.  The coffee and drinks are good.  The spot is well designed and has such a good vibe to the place.

Other than that, the girls that work there are so cute and dreamy.
author: Kenny C.

description: Love the sweet potato latte here. Its a nice a place to chill with a small group of friends. I would recommend trying he sweet potato latte or the Nutella latte.
author: Simon L.

description:
The environment at this cafe is like 5 stars...it's very beautiful and trendy. I love all the interesting and different chairs. However, the bakery or dessert selection is lacking. While we were enjoying our drinks, a group of 5 people came in and looked at the desserts and simply left without ordering anything. I feel if they actually had some desserts that were special than it would really help their business.

Our iced caramel latte was really good served in a nice tall glass...which was about 3 stars. However, my friend said their hot soy latte was about 2 stars because she couldn't taste the soy or espresso. 

So although the environment is really good, due to the poor dessert selection, the not so good soy latte, and the okay iced latte I would probably rank this place an overall 3 stars.
author: Jerod Y.

description: Great place to study with ample space! The Sweet potato latte was pretty yummy, not too sweet, but could use a tinnnyy bit more flavor, coming from a background of sweet potato latte expertise from KTown in LA and the Motherland itself. The macaron's are a bit pricey compared to other places, but they were very well made. I only wish there were more outlets on the left side of the wall next to the bigger tables. There is lots of space so you don't feet cramped while studying or chatting with friends. It's decently quiet with some ambient music and white noise, which I enjoy.
author: Alex R.

description: The atmosphere was awesome, and coffee great.  My boyfriend ordered a macaroon, which I didn't think would be good, but it was divine! Loved it - we got a pumpkin one.  We also had a ham and cheese croissant which was delicious, but really, how can you screw up a croissant? Cute place!
author: Gwen J.

description:
I came here on a late Friday night looking for a cafe with free wifi to get some work done [thankyou yelp for a great find!]. Once I walked in, I heard Korean chattering away and fell immediately in love with the cafe. I was probably influenced with my current obsession with kdramas, but nonetheless, the space is modern, pleasing, comfortable and clean. There are large tables for work and couches for lounging. 

I love how our drinks and desserts were served to us at our table. I had an Americano served in a HUGE cup I could barely wrap my palms around ($2.75). My friends ordered the sweet potato latte, mocha, tiramisu and macrons which I also tried a taste.

tiramisu - I love how the cake is really soaked in espresso. Becareful of the cocoa powder getting onto your papers/laptop if you're multitasking.

macrons - Maybe I'm used to Paulette's so I thought the macrons here were amateurish. The caps weren't smooth and the flavors aren't intensely developed.

I can't wait to stroll over to this cafe on the weekends and lounge!! I also love the random music selection which plays korean, japanese, american songs.

side note - I was sitting towards the back of the cafe which leads to the restroom in a separated area in the far back. It turns out the restroom area is connected to the restaurant upstairs. Being it was a Friday night, the  upstairs crowd was so noisy that you're able to hear the from inside the cafe.
author: Mindy C.

description: Delicious deserts and drinks, plenty of tables to work from, fast wifi and friendly staff. This is one of my favorite spots to spend the afternoon working.
author: Daniel V.

description: What's going on here?  How did I miss this place? This is the sweetest little place ever!  Not even sure how a friend and I stumbled in here looking for a place to sit with a laptop and work on a little project.  But, there it was.  Fancy Jasmine tea for two.  Little snacks galore.  They friendly folks will refill your tea pot with hot water.  Spent hours in here working, chatting, drinking tea, and eating cookies and cake.  Glorious good vibes abound!
author: David S.

description:
An awesome cafe for studying, or getting any sort of work done!--spacious, free wireless, and well lighted. Friendly staff, great desserts, a clean, bright interior, and the couch are definite pluses too. 

I wish there were more cafes like this in SF!
author: Eugene H.

description:
this is one of my favorite cafes in the city! make sure to come early to grab a seat or else be ready for a wait!

the place is pretty large for a cafe and can seat anywhere between 30-50 people. the ambiance is really nice with dim lighting (but not too dim), nice decorations, excellent table space, and great selection of drinks. i got the green tea and some macaroons, which was delicious!

one of the strange things, tho, is that the bathroom is downstairs and is shared with the korean bbq restaurant. thats the only  thing stopping this from being a 5 star cafe. still one of the best places to study in the city and one of my favorite spots to be working from home! 

also: highly recommended for cute study dates :)
author: Thach N.

description: This place is a very relaxing hang out. I overheard someone say that "man this is comfortable,it is like going home".  I agree but the service was a little slow.
author: Brandon T.

description: I love YakiniQ - the drinks are excellent, the selection of pastries is awesome and those onigiri (rice-balls) are the biggest ones I have ever seen!  Very relaxing atmosphere with many small tables for working or studying (I teach ESL there), but also a large game table, and many wonderful games provided.  There is also a large, comfortable sofa for lounging around. Very friendly and knowledgable staff.  By far the best cafe in Japantown.  Highly recommended.
author: Steve S.

description: I've been to Japantown for quite a number of times, i wasn't aware of this cafe until recently. The interior is spacey and neatly decorated. Known for their sweet potato drinks and macaroons.However, their drinks didn't quite meet the expectations. Nice place to cram studying though!
author: Rose G.

description: I really like the passion fruit macarons here but they're pricey even more than chantel guillon. $2.25 for each cookie. I won't be going back, unless my mom is with me and feeling in a very generous mood.
author: Le T.

description:
Excellent, friendly service. Very good coffee. Tasty desserts. Clean, bright, open atmosphere. Good music. Free wifi. Independent. Local. Nice bathrooms. 

Love this place.

...giving this cafe a 3 star review for not being able to "taste the soy in your soy latte" seems a little brutal. Just sayin'.
author: K G.

description: Decent place, great clean minimalist environment. Regular coffee was average to above average, not good enough for the price. Though I much preferred Jane's coffee, maybe a half mile away on Fillmore. Smallish selection of pastries; chocolate macaroon was good but not great.
author: David L.

description: I'll be coming here more often! The sweet potato latte with a shot of espresso was delicious. I stayed for many hours to use the WiFi for studying. I got hungry and ordered a bun mee sandwich with an iced jujube tea. Both were pretty good. It felt clean and the service was pleasant.
author: Alyssa K.

description: $5 for a scoop or two of ice cream?  What irked us was when we paid, they wouldn't take our credit card for the $5.xx order saying minimum was $10.  We said we only have $5 on us and would have to get the in the garage.  I understand there are rules but it's not like we did that on purpose.  So I walked all the way back to the garage to get $1.  Anyway we won't be coming back.
author: Pierre L.

description: In my opinion, this is one of the best cafes in town. Although it is a bit pricey, you get what you pay for in terms of quality - the macaroons are really tasty and rich, and the beverages are so yummy and original (I had never tasted sweet potato latte before I came here!). The atmosphere is good, and the people who work there are super nice. The only drawback is that it can get crowded, the wifi can be slow when many guests are on their laptops at the same time and there are very limited power outlets, so charge your device before you go :) Overall I do not feel like those negatives are enough to remove any stars. San Francisco needs more places like this!
author: Vilde E.

description:
I came here looking for a quick bite before waiting in the ridiculously long line at the Chinese consulate. 

Loved the interior, very large open space with lots of light, felt very homey and comforting. I came mid-week in the late morning, so it was pretty empty. Still, it took quite some time to get my order done. The girl was by herself and just really slow. She was super sweet though. 

They didn't have much in terms of lunch options, so I settled on a bagel with nutella and bananas. Nothing special, although I should have asked for some bagel with the nutella, since I think she put the whole jar on it. 

Most of the stars goes towards the ambience. It was very peaceful there and I would go back just to get some work done.
author: Ai S.

description:
Ambience: Perfect for chatting, reading or even studying. Tables are generally big enough to spread out all my stuff
Drinks: I got the iced matcha latte, strong matcha flavor, but nothing too exciting. It's unsweetened, so you'll need to add sweeteners if you like your drinks sweet.
Food: Got the Napoleon cake. It looks and tastes decent, but it's a mess to eat.
Price: For both items, it came up to $12+. Really. I think it is waaaaay overpriced for the rather mediocre drinks and pastry.
Staff: Pleasantly polite. Though my order for iced matcha latte was heard as iced peppermint latte. 
Wi-fi: This was my biggest grouse. I asked for the Wi-fi password so I could do some work, and tried logging on. The first attempt failed. I thought, hey, maybe I heard the password wrong, let me go check and confirm. Yep, double checked the network name and password, it was what I was trying to log on with before. Several attempts to log on ensued with no positive outcome. Now, Mac has the most idiot-proof wi-fi connecting system, and I have used wi-fi in so many places with NO problems. I thought my Mac was being weird. But is it me if it says "Alert: No internet connectIon"?

Needless to say, I packed up my things and left.
author: Wendy P.

description: A PAIN IN THE ASS TO FIND PARKING. but the food and environment is worth it, a nice place to study and grab a snack. I got the sweet potato latte and some macaroons, the macaroons are a bit on the pricey side but good and the sweet potato latte i ended up ordering seconds and thirds. Lighting is on the poorer side toward the back fo the cafe.
author: Phill E.

description:
Very cute space, I feel like I am in one of those cafe magazines you find at the Kinokuniya.  I love the eclectic chair / table combinations.  Easy to find seats on an early Saturday afternoon.

I had a nice little carrot cupcake.  My husband had the most delicious hazelnut cream meringue cake...so delicious I tell you.  

Next time I'll try the drinks -- matcha latte or the sweet potato latte, both look very interesting.
author: Mia G.

description: This is a great casual spot to hang out or work with good coffee/tea, pastries and a really cool atmosphere.
author: Benjamin W.

description:
This has to be the most peaceful coffee shop I've ever sat down and worked at for a bit. Very quiet with old timey music playing softly. The guy who came in with his phone ringing and then was yelling into it elicited looks of horror. Awesome.

My tea was tasty and inexpensive. I didn't try the food but the snacks, although pretty pricey, looked good.
author: A Z.

description:
The sign advertising sweet potato lattes was too enticing to pass up. I'm a super big fan of sweet potato and taro--especially when they're turned into yummy creations!

I got it served warm and it was actually not too bad, but it was still a bit too sweet for me even though the barista made it a point to make it less sweet. You can really taste the sweet potato flavor and sweet potato pieces.

It was $3.80 after tax ($10 minimum to pay by card), which is not horribly expensive for a unique creation served in a small coffee cup (think Starbucks' tall size).

Worth a try.
author: mimi k.

description: Pricey. A hot tea is three dollars. It is just a regular mighty tea bag! And cakes are all over $6. That is B patisserie price.
author: Esther L.

description: Staff was very snooty and not friendly. The macaroons did not taste fresh. The staff overlooked me and didn't even want to say hello.. My money spends just as well as anyone else's I will not be coming back..
author: Eyliss L.

description:
Aside form being lovely inside, this cafe is run by a friendly staff, plays pleasant music, and serves very tasty hot chocolate; so thumbs up!

I used to live in Japantown so I would come here after work on my way home. I discovered free WiFi and outlets for my Macbook. "YakiniQ" is a play on the Japanese "yaki niku", meaning grilled meat. The meat is served next door, though, and the cafe is more of a Korean hang-out spot than a Japanese one.

The cafe has several small tables against the walls, in addition to a longer table in the middle, and a couch area. It tends to draw crowds of friends that like to meet and socialize, as well as a few solo-studiers. I observed one date take place as well. I've seen people bring outside food but I wasn't able to get away with it. The staff is nice though and I've missed them since moving downtown, especially the girl that always knew what I wanted and would get it for me. Shout out to her and a guy named John Lee.
author: Colin D.

description:
What an awesome little coffee shop tucked into Japantown.  We popped in here after brunch for some coffee and a salted carmel torte. 

Clean, Bright, and friendly. Amazing little nibbles.  Good coffee, and such a big open space.   Love it!  Look forward to making my way back down here and popping in again.
author: Samanta V.

description: Nice and trendy cafe, but the blond hair male staff had a really bad attitude. To make it worst he had no clue what he was doing wrong and refuse to acknowledge his poor manner and personal conducts.from other reviews I read, there has been multiple complaints regarding this particular male employee. Even though its not fair to the owner and rest of the staff that I rate this business establishment at such low rating, I believe that in any business environment any type of unprofessional behaviors are and should not be allowed. I would not recommend a visit to this cafe because I do not enjoy the idea of accommodating another unpleasurable experience.
author: S W.

description: I love this place -- I've yet to discover a cuter cafe. Awesome interior designing (super cute lantern/lights hanging from the ceiling & interesting artwork on the walls), plentiful seating, friendly service, and an expansive menu to satisfy your coffee, tea, and/or sweet tooth needs. When I came by the other night, there were lots of people studying with laptops, reading, and just chatting with friends.
author: I. L.

description: This is the first time I ever tried Yuzu. It's a mix between a mandarin and another fruit. Yuzu tea is amazing, a must try for sure. During finals week, I was there all week just studying.
author: Kay S.

description:
Great place that we just found. A block from the house. So it makes for a really nice place to land. So far have only been here in the mornings, but I love it here. The morning/day staff during the week is super awesome and very nice! Good choice of music. And a lot of studying going on. Pure Coffee House Culture. 

Wish it was open before 11 though...
author: John X.

description: I love this place because of its ambiance, it's one of those hidden gems in the city that I don't really want to write about for fear that it will get over crowded one day. This place is a quiet and spacious and is a perfect place to study or to get work done. This cafe has a lot of character with all of its mismatch chairs and wall art, but what I really love is the selection of games on the shelves provided for customers that have a little more free time on their hands. The drink and food selection is fair, but nothing outstanding, which includes the sweet potato latte. My biggest knock for this place are the high prices. If you're ever there long enough for closing the owner likes to close shop by enlightening his visitors with an excerpt from a book he enjoyed.
author: Limuel G.

description:
I'm going to have to disagree that it is a good place for quiet study as there is music playing at a level that would make studying difficult. On the flip side a good set of headphones can solve that issue. 

It is however very well lit and clean. The iced Yuzu Tea and honey that I had however was superb with just enough bitterness. I'll definitely continue to frequent this place whenever I'm in SF. Down the street from my favorite ramen place in SF which is a big plus. 

The wifi was more than adequate for me to VPN into my office and get some work done. I definitely hope that this place sticks round and does well.

Remember to bring CASH. They have a $10 minimum for credit cards.
author: Quan P.

description:
Feel the Feng Shui in here? I do.
Well spaced, plenty of light, good drinks and sweets, modern with nice art and with a wireless that works, nuff said.
The couch is a plus :)
Love it!
author: Dario B.

description: Fantastic restaurant and food... I got shaved ice for breakfast, and it was great!  Spacious, warm and well decorated decor and place.  Must visit!!!
author: Joshua L.

description: This cafe was overall really cute. It had an extremely Korean feel and vibe to it, which I enjoyed. Sat on the comfy couches and sifted through the drawing books they left for customers to draw/doodle/write in while eating my patbingsoo (Korean shaved ice). It's pretty interesting to look through other people's artwork and random writings! They leave crayons and pens for customers to add their own creativity. Most of the other customers there were either studying or doing work.
author: Grace C.

description:
Best cafe ever! This is my cafe and I love it so much! XD
whoever like Korean Drama, this is the place u should go, it look like Korean-drama setting cafe! XD So going back there also, the coffee is interesting- Sweet-potato Latte! What the heck!?! But u know what is the bomb,plus the dessert not too sweet which mostly I love..Anyhow u should go there and check it out for urself!
author: jiopkly Y.

description: I just discovered this nice cafe on street level under the YakiniQ restaurant (formerly the older Korea House, with the newer one still open just up the street).  They have your usual cafe drinks and some pastries. The sign says they provide Internet access, but appears you need to ask them for the password. The servers were very friendly also during my visit.
author: H K.

description: I ordered an ice vanilla latte.  I didn't taste the coffee or the vanilla syrup.  All I tasted was milk when I mentioned this to the person behind the counter they said it would cost extra for for syrup.  Shouldn't a latte taste like a latte?
author: Josie L.

description: I just love this place!!! So cosy! Pastries are delicious (try the pink lady, you will not be disappointed) and their drinks selection is awesome. They have free wifi, free magazines, free board games... They are very nice and the service is great. Perfect place for a meeting.
author: Elsa T.

description:
It's got amazing interior for a coffee shop. If you are anywhere from continental Europe, you'll feel home here.
Get a Napoleon cake and an espresso and enjoy the afternoon. 
They have other tasty cakes,  but it's their coffee and atmosphere which keep brings me here.
author: Tino B.

description: Standard mom n pop cafes seem to come a dime a dozen, and there is definitely nothing exceptional about this one.  However, if you want to be treated like crap...then you should definitely go here!
author: Julian H.

description: I like their ambiance, and their service is okay--nothing to write home about.  I tried their sweet potato latte (for what reason, I don't know.  I'm not a fan of sweet potatoes.), and that too was...okay.  Next time, I'll just stick to the Korean food upstairs and have dessert elsewhere.
author: Kai C.

description:
Nice place, bad business ideas. I used to come here to enjoy a nice drink, and do some work with 1-2 friends. They've recently decided to cover up all of their outlets along the left wall in order to increase turnover. This was a poor decision, as I will not be back because of it. I think the main issue is that one customer would come, order one thing, and sit at a large table. All they had to do was ask that he share the table, or move to a smaller table.

When we came the place was totally empty too, so it would've been nice if the folks behind the counter were more understanding. Especially considering we spent close to $30 for a light lunch and tea for two people.

Two action items for the owners:
- Unblock the outlets, and consider adding even more easily accessible outlets
- Remove the $10 minimum credit card charge
- Take some pointers from Starbucks, and create a welcoming environment where people will want to stay.

Unfortunately this is not a good place to work on a laptop anymore, head to one of the many more accommodating cafes down Fillmore st.
author: Kevin G.

description: When the owner recognizes you after you haven't been patronizing a place for over a year, it makes you feel pretty good.  Thanks Christy.  I'll stop by more often when I'm up here.  When I used to live in SF I would come here pretty often.  The best drink here is the potato latte. The others are only okay.  The vibe this place provides is very nice.  The lighting is very smooth and music is very mellow.  There are lots of hot girls studying here.  I should talk to them but I don't.  I usually come here to chill with my work computer and work.  Don't expect to get good wifi here.  Wifi is very unstable. I bring my own hotspot.
author: Byron L.

description: We ate at the YakiniQ Cafe this past weekend while visiting SF and staying, coincidentally, across the street at the Kabuki Hotel.  What a pleasant coincidence!  Our sandwiches were excellent and their apple pie was the best I've ever had - period - and apple pie has always been my favorite dessert.  Even my wife, who's a so-so apple pie eater, couldn't put her fork down after she tried a bite.  Fortunately, the pieces are huge!
author: Jonathan B.

description: Like many of my fellow Yelpers here, I'm an absolute fan of their Sweet Potato Latte. After several visits, I still have yet to try any other specialty beverages. However, the selection of eats are worth a try! I really enjoy their Onigiri. For $4.50, you get a hearty sized rice ball wrapped in nori with avocado, tuna, mayo, and some kick! They also have a terrific assortment of pastries. This is not your fast counter style of cafes. The ambiance is old-fashioned with a "make yourself at home" kind of feel. This is a spot to unwind after a long walk around J-Town. Looking forward to the next visit... which will most likely involve another Sweet Potato Latte.
author: Leroid D.

description: I am a huge fan of this cafe and have been coming here about half a year ago when I discovered its uniqueness and quaint atmosphere. I would definitely give it a 5 star and feel like the 4 star is already because I just love coming here though I live across the city and have to drive 30 minutes plus find parking for another 15 min (or worse). Nonetheless, I really hope the owner of this cafe would hire more friendly staff. I sat down for about 30 minutes and this petite, short hair, rude lady stomped (literally) over to my table and demanded that I need to purchase a drink before I start using their wifi.  Usually, I like to settle in and start work, and then order something to eat or drink. The problem isn't not ordering. It is her ATTITUDE and rudeness. When I walked over to pay, she scolded and stared at me and said loudly that we only accept cash for orders under $6. Again, she could tone down her attitude and rudeness! Quality of food, the atmosphere is important, but customer service is key. This was definitely a huge disappointment and I wouldn't want it to be the reason why I would stop coming because I truly think it's a unique gem in the heart of San Francisco.
author: Sophie L.

description: I can work in peace while munching on light fare and delicious pastries. Free wifi..really nice place. Very quiet.
author: N H.

description: Great place to study or work (decent lighting and table space, free wifi, jacks for plugging in your laptop on the right side of the room). Also pretty solid for satisfying your sweet tooth (salted caramel brownie and chocolate chip walnut cookie were pretty perfect). Plus, the decor is really cute! (I'm loving the bright teal colander with lemons in it--sitting right by the complimentary water stand.) Yes, I'm a girly girl. But guys come here to work too, so they must appreciate some of these li'l details. ;)
author: Amy Y.

description: My boyfriend found out that they have macarons here so he brought me there to get some for my birthday.  When I went, they had 9 flavors: chocolate, earl grey tea, pistachio, lemon, rose, lavender, espresso, strawberry, and passion fruit.  I found out that they actually don't make the macarons in house but they get them from Patisserie Philippe.  I was a little disappointed by this fact but not really, since the macarons at Patisserie Phillipe are my favorite in the city.  It's definitely a lot easier for me to get macarons at J-town than trekking all the way to Townsend so I'm happy =)
author: Katelynn L.

description:
came in for the stereotypical sweet potato latte and was not disappointed. interesting taste!

very relaxed vibe to the place; it is not hustle and bustle. kind of place you could sit down for a while and read/work/play board games. 

the food/treats are a bit overpriced. Macaroons looked delish but I don't want to pay over $2 just for a single one.
author: Dave L.

description: The crowd is a bit too hipster for my standards but the sweet potato latte is tasty when done right. I went on a Tuesday night and the two girls working there were really friendly and suggested that if I wanted the sweet potato latte with two extra shots then adding a bit of extra simple syrup would make it really good. I loved it so much I went back on Saturday. For some reason, the person working made it and it just didn't taste the same. It tasted burnt and I could hardly taste the sweet potato this time. I'll probably try again, but I can't promise that I'll get it again if it's a fail again. I hope though, that it's good because the first one I had was really good. If the next one is good, I will definitely change my stars for this review.
author: Christina L.

description:
This place is the cutest little coffee house. It reminds me of all the nice coffee houses in Korea and Japan. 
I wish we had more of these in the Bay Area. But this place will have to do for now! Oh and you have to try the macaroons, delish! The pistachio is my favorite*
author: Ivy B.

description: Fantastic little coffee shop in Japantown. Plus spam masubi!
author: Jason A.

description: Awesome place to sit relax read and study. Spacious and clean. With outlets too! I wish I had brought my phone charger so I could stay here forever ..
author: Terry B.

description: Potato latte sucks balls - but maybe its just me, but everything else is good. 5 stars.
author: Yelperrr M.

description: Charming hang out place in Japantown serving traditional European desserts as well as Asian desserts.  The quality is great with comfortable sofas, table, board games and WIFI.  Great place to study, write a book or place to enjoy some Japanese shaved ice.
author: Laurence H.

description: A little expensive, so minus one star, but relaxing young vibe.  Super friendly staff. Good place to unwind and relax in Japantown
author: David S.

description: love their macha short bread cookie. good service, and the place is definitely quiet enough for studying.  I usually go there on the regular.
author: Sabrina W.

description: Was looking at an apartment 2 blocks away and came here to sit and check out the tenancy agreement. Had one of the best lattes I've had since moving to SF and signed the agreement. Now I live round the corner I've become a regular - Good coffee, nice atmosphere, cool decor.
author: Mark T.

description: Love the potato latte, must try!!!  It's a nice and peaceful haven tucked away if you want a brief escape from everyday chaos.
author: Sydney L.

description: The coffee and baked goods are quite good. They have a large area for sitting and many people browse computers with free wifi while there. There is an interior couch area with board games and books for relaxing. It's a unique cafe. One of the signature drinks is the pumpkin latte cafe which I heard is good. I don't drink flavored coffee but if you do, this seems like a nice option. But the short balding guy (manager?) with the glasses can be quite rude and condescending. I observed a female customer ask a question, "is there a restroom?" which elicited a very weird exasperated exhale before stating "just a moment". He waited until three customers completed ordering and paying before responding to the customer, "restroom is in back". And why he couldn't have stated this earlier while the customer was waiting is beyond me. Oh well.... Otherwise, the rest of staff are always awesome and helpful.
author: Kimo S.

description: Awesome quite place to do some work, study, chat and drink some good drinks. Will definitely come back
author: Amir Z.

description: I love the overall ambiance at YakiniQ. It has ample seating, cute decor, option of food and baked goods, and nice relaxing music. I would give them 5 stars if it was actually in my neighborhood. :( Other than that, YakiniQ meets my expectations of a good study cafe.
author: j t.

description: My favorite cafe in the city. Beautifully crafted espresso drinks, fine pastries, LOVE the green tea/red bean shaved ice dessert. The ambience is adorable (though there could be more lighting for reading) with tables, chairs, couches and coffee tables.
author: Amy M.

description: I love the ambiance, the macarons and all their beverages. They have a shelf full of board games, they have free wifi and they open until late ! Even on Sunday !
author: Coralie T.

description:
only been here once, but I plan on coming back. repeatedly. with book in tow.

a delightful surprise; an elegant and chic cafe with the same urban modern feel as coffeehouses in tokyo. a great selection of (somewhat pricey) baked goods. the sign outside indicated they had a sweet potato latte, and i fell into the foam. the counterlady indicated it was sweet potato puree, mixed with milk and foamed. no caffeine. it was a little too sweet, but delightfully fluffy and flavorful. with an earl grey macaron, it was the perfect little break.

the tables are nicely spaced out, and the ambiance is super nice. i wish there were more coffee/tea houses like this...
author: Jade L.

description: I came down with a head cold after Outside Lands, and my cousin brought me here when we were wandering around Japantown my last day in San Francisco. I got the hot yuzu tea with honey, and it was soooooo yummy! It was really great for my sore throat, and was exactly what I needed. Also got the yuzu & tea macaron, it was a nice treat. I will definitely come here again the next time I'm in the Bay Area!
author: Erin B.

description: This is THE dessert place to go with friends visiting from other cities. I always treat them strawberry yuzu. It tastes somewhat like strawberry lemonade but a bit more tangy & citrus-y. I tried the napoleon cake the other day and it was good, too. There is covered parking ($1 after 6pm) in the Japan Center Garage and also free street parking in the residential area if you go up one more block. Recently it is Japan week or something so it's been crowded... hard to find free parking. But yah nice little stop after my sushi in Tenroku and I love the Korean design & beverage selections.
author: JY H.

description:
I love to pop in here for a  cup of tea and a sweet treat with my daughter when we are on our monthly field trip to Japantown. It seems to be quite busy every time we are there, with loads of folks on their computers nursing a coffee/tea.  We often have to perch on a bench while sipping tea and said little girl likes to count how many computers are out on the tables compared to how many ipads. For the sake of the owner I certainly hope all those people who's bums are parked there for what looks like a couple of hours, that they are ordering more than just drinks!

In any case, there is a lovely atmosphere that is very relaxed and mellow and very charming. I have always had good service with lovely people behind the counter. The pastries and treats are very tasty and though the tea they provide is in tea bags in mugs, I do not mind too much. When perching on a bench it is probably easier than having a pot and cup etc... 

I would love to come in with a load of paper work and my computer and stake out a table for a few hours ( and order breakfast, lunch and tea!) it seems that it would be a happy place to pay bills etc... but alas... the tables may all be taken by the time I get there!

A lovely little cafe, a bit of a hidden gem!
author: Amy D.

description: Great atmosphere. Plenty of tables and seating. Sandwiches, salads, sweets, and espresso.
author: Chris P.

description: This is a lovely Korean style coffee shop. tired their sweet potato latte.. kind of get hooked.. made two orders.. and their coconut macaroon was okay, little bit too sweet, but i do like the texture. unlike other macaroon with only almond meal and egg white  of which the texture tends to be loose and more crunchy, theirs are little bit chewy. In general, thumb up!
author: Yann M.

description: My favorite cafe in SF! It's a Korean-styled cafe, something that you'd see the in the Hongdae area of Seoul. I absolutely love it here! I almost didn't want to write a review because I don't want it to be too crowded! I usually get the hot sweet potato latte and a rose macaroon. The yuzu tea is great either, hot or cold. If you get the iced matcha green latte, ask them to sweeten it because they originally don't. BUT the iced sweet potato latte is rather gross. Haha. It's a bit pricey, but the decor, ambiance, free wifi, and great service is what keeps me coming back. After I eat at YakiniQ upstairs, my friends and I usually relax at YakiniQ cafe below. :)
author: Chanel P.

description: Sort of cool. I liked the open space layout. It reminds me of a reading room in a library with comfortable seating and well coffee :) I would come again. They are open decently late have tasty snacks (the sweet potato latte, sounds weird, but is actually quite good. At least worth a try) including some ice cream which is not a bad way to end any night.
author: Greg G.

description: Came here for my thursday Tea date with my beloved. We found a very clean cafe with a lovely and odd eclectic collection of tables and chairs...utilitarian and visually pleasing. Lots of wood.  Mixed lighting, well lit for the most part. A comfy coach, but sitting in the dim middle. Clean wood floors. Clean bathroom. Lots of plugs, but not every table has access. No vermin. Soft innocuous music. Somewhat loud conversations, but most in Japanese so at least not understandably distracting. Friendly service. Great pastries and edibles, good selection of teas and cold drinks.
author: Herschell L.

description: Slow service, barista didn't move like he was working, more like he was leisurely making coffee at home. waited 10 - 15 minutes for a mocha and latte. kinda pricey for what u get, came out to $5 each.  Flavor....not very mocha like.  The pumpkin latte did have good flavor.  I don't think i'll be coming back here.
author: Susan Z.

description: Great chai tea latte, and my favorite place to study. It's cozy and quiet. They also have really good pastries. The staff has always been very sweet.
author: Monique Q.

description:
I used to really like this place until they blocked all the outlets on the side where the 4-seater tables were. The other side of the room where the 2-seater tables are have, I think, 2 outlets shared between 4-5 tables and if you're trying to get 2 people on laptops on those tables it'll be a little tight.

This is a cute and comfortable place for a quick (but pricey) snack or meeting of the minds, but if you want to get some serious work done look elsewhere.
author: Cheryll D.

description: Great place to study, tons of places to plug in my laptop...but the sweet potato- its good- not great
author: Jackie H.

description: My friends introduced me to this cute cafe that recently opened in Jtown and I love it! The servers are friendly and the place is very clean with free wifi. The only thing I can be nit picky about is the price, about 3 dollars (2.50t+tax) for a ice coffee, but that's because they are located in Japantown and we are also paying for the nice atmosphere (quiet, clean and roomy). This is definitely one of my spots for studying in the future.
author: Annie T.

description: Tasty, if bread-y, sandwiches, and good coffee. Non-annoying wi-fi (there's a password, but it doesn't hijack webpages or time out) is a plus. But (and this is a big "but"), they just played James Blunt. Bring headphones!
author: Alan H.

description: Sweet potato latte and macaroon are good. However, the waitresses's attitude made me very uncomfortable. She heard us wrong but insisted not to give us back the correct drink, otherwise it is a nice place overall.
author: Lydia M.

description: Finally a Korean-style coffee shop in SF. Great place to meet a friend for conversation, decent coffee or tea, and  a nice dessert. Absolutely non-pretentious and cozy. Credit card $10 minimum is NOT cool though. I recommend they switch to Square and accept any credit card amount and save money on your merchant bill too.
author: Johnny O.

description: I like it. Clean, home feel cafe'. And they serve Tara's organic ice cream from the Eastbay which is GREAT! I really like the staff and unique pastries on top of the amazing beverages.
author: Christopher J.

description: I was looking for a cafe to go to with my friend who lives in SF and found this place on yelp... we were so pleased we decided to come here! It's clean and spacious but feels very peaceful and like home :) We both got a sweet potato latte (she got the hot one and I got mine cold) and it was as delicious and comforting as everyone says! My friend got hers with no sugar and it was still really good, I actually liked it better than mine (although the normal one isn't too sweet even with the sugar :) Next time I'll have to try one of the pastries (they carry pastries from Patisserie Philippe and then some from artisan bakeries) -- they look amazing!
author: C K.

description: Perfect cafe for studying.  Been here a few times, you dont see the loud chatting bunch here, which is good!  Decent coffee, excellent apple cider, very clean and spacious, chill music and vibe.  Service is really friendly.
author: Ethan L.

description: Just for the Sweet Potato Milk Shake that Jennie Introduced me to.  Also, a clean, quiet place to study with Macaroons =)
author: Nin J.

description: This is such a cute cafe. I got a caramel milk tea and it was perfectly made. It has such a calming atmosphere and I can see why people would want to spend hours there. Yes, it is a bit on the pricier side, but totally worth it IMO.
author: Keromi K.

description: Highly recommend this cafe in Japantown. Great tea from Harney & Sons / desserts are heavenly.
author: Gene A.

description: Great new place that was needed on this block! I was not sure about the sweet potato latte, and she was nice enough to actually make me a little sample to try...not many places that would do that, and free wifi, I think I've found a new hang out...gotta try the tuna nigiri!
author: Arlene C.

description: I stumbled upon this adorable coffee shop one evening and it brought back great memories of Korea.  Their sweet potato latte is amazing! Also seems to be a quiet place to study, I'm looking forward to returning.
author: Liz Y.

description: I've never spent more time in a cafe than it takes to order a double espresso, shoot it down and walk out, but leave it to J-Town to have a place that makes me think twice. They've got a great assortment of coffee and tea drinks as well as a great selection of sweets. Clean and spacious with very nice employees. A business that perfectly represents the neighborhood.
author: Corey V.

description: sweet potato latte!  i love you!
author: Sharon A.

description: I tried an earl grey macaron, but I don't know why since I don't particularly like earl grey. The macaron was okay. The lavender was way too strong and it was like eating perfume. Gross. The hazelnut one was perfect and I could have eaten ten more of those. I tried to savor it as much as I could, but they're so tiny. The chocolate one was also delicious. I had a Nutella latte, but it was nothing amazing. I think it's because Nutella is difficult to incorporate so it was basically Nutella unmelted at the bottom of the cup with steamed milk.  Yum. The lady at the register was grumpy, but the dude who made my drink was super nice. The place is pretty spacious, though not very well lit if you're planning on doing work. I'd probably go back and eat more of those macarons.
author: k h.

description:
Best chocolate mousse crunch so far :))))
Very chocolatety, very creamy, good looking and just right portion
One thing I don't like about is the price :(, $7.25 for one single piece of cake...
But I will definitely come again, because they have the best chocolate mousse crunch...


Overall I like this place very very much, comfort chairs, nice music, nice decorations, I love.this place! Don't know about the coffee cuz I am not a coffee person. but the tea was okay, and the sandwiches are great too:D 

Definitely a decent place to have a little chat with your friends or read;)
author: Christy Y.

description: The staff is very nice, the decor is cool, the snacks are delicious, and the location is perfect, because the neighborhood really needed this type of cafe.
author: Kevin R.

description: Love the ambiance, people, and the food here. Big open space, bright colors, nice wood tables and a slightly eclectic collection of chairs that makes it fun to pick a place to sit. I've only been once so far so I haven't been able to sample many of the eats and drinks, but the cappuccino and dessert I had the first time were pretty darn tasty. And for those computer users out there who are wondering, yes, there's free wifi and there seem to be an ample number of outlets. But what I really like is the friendly atmosphere...
author: Dave M.

description: Great coffee shop. Super clean. I tried a sandwich and a carrot cake muffin and they were both delicious. The staff was also very nice
author: Mike B.

description: Sweet Potato Latte brought us through the doors, but the cute/cozy ambiance, great service, and killer desserts kept us in our seats.
author: kelly e.

description:
Love their latte and au lait, and their cakes are yummy. It reminds me of cafes in Japan and Korea. 

The great thing about this place is that you can stay there forever. The flip side of it is it's hard to find a spot if you go at a wrong time.
author: Judy D.

description: I love this place, strawberries and rose ice cream, and it's quiet for a saturday evening! =)
author: Tiff W.

description: 3.5* for the macaroons but I'll round up to a 4 since the behind the counter lady was so nice and helpful.
author: Miko L.

description:
just have to echo everyone's wonderful reviews of this place!

GREAT place to study if you don't need the wifi all the time

WONDERFUL staff that are super friendly and don't mind if you stay a while

CHARMING decor, really just adorable

fantastic for students
author: S A.

description:
**Update from prior visits: recently discovered that they blocked all of the outlets on the side of the cafe with larger tables (the ones that accommodate 4).  Not cool.  3.5 stars.**

Peaceful ambiance, delicious desserts, spacious, kind service, and free wifi--great establishment I will continue to support.

My friend and I came here on a Saturday afternoon to hit the books.  There were definitely periods where the noise level became higher than ideal, but it is open to the public and was a Saturday.  Nonetheless, I am proud to say I completed a good chunk of work that day and the food we ordered kept me adequately energized.  We had regular hot tea, coffee, Banh Mee, and 4 macaroons (mango, passion fruit, coconut, and blackberry).  The first two kinds of macaroons were good, not great.  The latter two, very tasty without being too sweet.  The Banh Mee contained Thai chicken satay, coleslaw, Dijon, and mayo with a side salad.  It was good, but certainly not $9 and change good...could've gotten 2.5 Saigon sandwiches, but I was hungry and didn't want to leave yet.  The "coleslaw" was just fresh cabbage and the chicken was not as flavorful as I'd expected, seeing as Thai food has lots of spices and any satay has a smokey flavor.

That leads me to my next point--bang for your buck.  Unfortunately, for the more substantial food items, there was no bang to be found.  Maybe a "pew-pew," but don't expect to be blown away.  My friend and I conjectured that their high prices probably make up for the myriad of chair styles they have.  I dunno, I would prefer uniformity over having spent almost $30 for what few items we ordered.  In spite of the prices, the environment tickles me enough to want to return.
author: Dwigt K. S.

description: Delicious drinks and a friendly, quiet atmosphere make a for great cafe. The Japantown garage is your only hope for parking, FYI.
author: Janet R.

description:
i like coming here because it's quiet and cute.  some items are overpriced and, let's be real, you can get better food quality at a lower price.  but y'know, it's a fun meeting place.
service...ok, the ladies are sweet as pie so i hope that whenever you're there, you get one of the ladies.  however, avoid the fake blond male server/cashier.  he does exist and looks like a legit creeper.  and yes, he is rude and makes you feel like you want to blow chunks at him.  he's a downer.  yakiniq, please replace him and perhaps i'll change my rating.
author: s t.

description: perfect spot for the hybrid study crammer/easily amused type personality. i first walked in with the notion to get work done but i noticed several childhood board games. thus, i ended my "get work done" mode and played a game of chess with my friend. as for the food, you can't go wrong with any of the sandwiches but the drinks are average. bottom line, i'd come back for the atmosphere but not the food.
author: Jen C.

description: Great hidden cafe in Japantown! I'm so glad that I found this place. Delicious coffee, cool vibe and free wifi.
author: Matt S.

description:
I liked the first impression of this place so much that i'm yelping it as i'm sitting here. The kind young woman at the counter informed me that it's only 4 months old. I got some tea and pastries, so i can't review their coffee.. although it seems people like it so i'll try it next time.

Ambience: relaxed, and very clean. The decor wasn't too obnoxious or loud. Everything went well together from the furniture to the art to the glasses they serve beverages in. The music was a mix of korean, classical, and japanese. It wasn't playing too loudly which made for a great studying environment. 

Tea's tea, and the madeleines were delicious. enough said.

Wi fi is free.. and it's a damn fast one too. 

I would come back here more often if i lived closer. Too bad i live in the sunset, and while it's not that far away, it is a 30 min ride out to japantown. But since i'm getting annoyed by the cafes on 9th.. maybe i'll come here once a week or so.
author: Jim Y.

description: Love this café to work. Big, spacious, quiet and very cute. Many japanese people, which makes it even better
author: Carlos G.

description: ah such a cute establishment, but terrible food and drink.  definitely was misguided by yelp. and the guidebooks on this one.  hard to find the great asian cafes without someone to show you the ropes
author: Eric L.

description: YakiniQ has been one of my favorite cafes in the city. It's a very pleasant, nice, comfortable cafe which is perfect for studying and working. Pluses for me have always been that it's a) not as noisy and b) not too dim. Fantastic team, and good audience normally (though it can get quite packed).
author: Jens M.

description:
Very cute cafe, with plenty of room! I'm so used to cramping in small crowded cafes, but this has cute matching tables and is well lit. True that it's very fobby, so it fits well in Japantown. The ambiance inside is very nice, not ridiculously loud like Starbucks or other cafes, but you can definitely carry on a conversation. Perfect for working, catching up with friends, or dates.

Great unique ice cream flavors. My favorite is the Strawberry Rose. The lady chimed in that they use real roses. Had the Genmai Cha, which was pretty good too. Only complaint that the texture wasn't too smooth.

Also had cute desserts, too many to choose from! 

Make sure to bring cash, as you can only use your card if you spend over $10. I would definitely plan on going regularly if I lived close enough 

One awkward moment: they called me from my table to pick up the glass tea pot and two tea cups (which normally is fine with me, although it was a little difficult without a platter), but the couple next to us got it served to them.....guess I didn't tip enough?
author: Maiyer V.

description: I like this place. its so nice and pretty and clean. Bathroom isnt the case tho, i think its cus they share it with the bbq place next door. Lol. nice place to study i guess.. they also have games
author: Cindy L.

description: Becoming one of my favorite coffee shops with free internet, clean white open spaces, and yummy green tea lattes. Seriously found this on yelp and I go to japantown a lot.  Usually filled with people but not overly crowded. Great to sit with your laptop or I've seen college kids doing group work or people hanging out. Oh and their macaroons are pretty good esp the earl grey although I keep getting my favorite passion fruit. I like that they usually have open tables also.
author: SF Diner A.

description: This cafe is very charming! The staff is really welcoming and always friendly. This baristas brings your drinks and desserts even when they are very busy. They have a very good selection of desserts (the macaroons are killer)! This is a great place to study or grab a quick snack.
author: Paige J.

description:
I've been here twice already since it opened up two months ago. The service is friendly and prompt. I haven't tried their food, but everything behind display looks really good. The coffee is not too strong, but looks great in its proper cup and setting. The music in the background sometimes repeats but that's because I've been sitting there for a while. Nobody hurries you to leave. It's not too crowded, but you won't be there by yourself because there is a constant revolving foot traffic. 

Overall, the cafe is really cute. Everyone should go and vist at least once! Try the Sweet Potato Latte. Pretty interesting!
author: Soy Sugar Y.

description: Expensive but nice, plus they play jazz. Espresso is better than reasonable.
author: P K.

description: Came in after eating in J-town one evening and craving shaved ice. They had 45 minutes before closing and the cashier said, they don't make it so close to closing. Really? So I said forget it but the two people w/ me wanted to try their apple pie. It was ok. But after 10 minutes of sitting there waiting for them to warm up the pie, the cashier said if I still wanted the shaved ice, the owner said ok but he'll put it in a togo cup. Ok, half an hour before closing and you don't think I can finish a container of shaved ice. Having experienced another place that did a to go shaved ice where they didn't give me a lot of ice cause they had to fit it in a coffee cup, I declined. Then they tried to convince me to do it. I refused. Never coming back here again. I came here specifically for their shaved ice because it was after dinner and I was craving it. I yelped it, saw the good reviews but after they way I was treated, I'm never coming back.
author: Lizzie B.

description: I simply love the ambiance and feeling of this place. The semi-dim lighting and cute, spacious place is great to get some work done. I've never been here when it's crowded, but its very peaceful and comfy. One of my favorite escapes when I'm looking for a nook to hide away in. I do enjoy their Sweet Potato Latte...the workers were extremely nice when I was there. Plus WiFi!
author: K. M.

description: Yelpers were right again. Cute little place with a studious crowd. The sweet potato latte was good. The 2 people up front were kind and down-to-earth. It felt local, chill, and relaxing. The only gripe, which is not their fault, is the parking. I wish I had a place like this closer to home.
author: Olivia A.

description: just to emphasize how awesome his place is, i've come here every day since my first visit, i've already tried all but one of the macaron flavors and some of employees now recognize/know my name. im also probably going to be broke soon...but that's a minor detail.
author: Stephanie C.

description: Good food, good drinks. Overpriced. But I really like their macarons and the way the place is decorated.
author: Samantha M.

description: This is absolutely my favorite place in the city to come for a coffee or a tea to relax, do some work or read. It's a very spacious coffee shop that offers a wide range of goodies and espresso drinks. Im mainly a tea drinker and they offer a wide range. Its not a tea house like Samovar, so don't  expect fancy teas. Nonetheless, the choices they offer are good. The deserts are also quite something...visually impressive and mouth watering. The staff is also very friendly and remember you by name. There are also board games to play with your friends or books that you can choose from in the back wall. One of the delights is the eclectic music that plays in the background. One minute you can be listening to old music from the 40s and then suddenly be surprised with cool chill trance. Overall, the ambience and vibe is quite energetic and stimulating, yet mellow. And it's in the heart of Japantown  where you can then do a bit of shopping or go eat at one of the many yummy restaurants or watch a film at the Kabuki theater or the cool and trendy Film Society.
author: Hope C.

description: nice staff , very quite spot with tons of sweedish designed furniture, macaroons, and apple pie a la mode. havent tried there sweet potato latte yet , nice place to relax and chit chat with friends or study i suppose but who wants to do that?
author: Wei W.

description: came to this place to get a quick coffee before i went upstairs to stuff my face without any high expectations but they have some pretty good drinks here and it looks like a nice place to chill..
author: Will C.

description: I've tried their overpriced tiny desserts, and since I'm picky about good stuff, I tend to stick to coffee when I'm there, as in regular coffee. If the stuff there made your eyes close, and made your heart skip a beat, then I'd give a list of stuff that you had to try, but I don't have a list. The last fancy drink I tried, was their root beer float which I had to stop midway. They should probably stick to A & W, and not be so fancy. I'm not sure what there deal is with sweet potato, but it's not a hot commodity like chicken feet to sell, and I don't dig finding anything gritty in my lattes.  It's a cool place to chill and unwind from a long day of hanging out in Japan Town, or a great meeting spot to try to figure out what else to do. While others may choose this spot to study, or surf the net, I like to pick up and play their Scrabble and Jenga games, occasionally bringing my own deck of UNO cards. I give it three stars because it's quite cozy, and there's a lot of places to sit and hangout, occasionally I'll give in to their desserts, sometimes it rocks.
author: Bonene G.

description: After coming in from a rain storm, it was such a relief stepping into this bright, open, and cheerful environment.  The nice tables and comfortable looking couch seating looked very inviting, and immediately I felt glad to be inside.  I attended a birthday party here, and we tried out some of the nice choice of cafe drinks that matched well with the the terrific assortment of quality desserts.  In addition to the miniature fruit tarts,  napoleon type cakes, cookies, and great french style Laduree macaroons, this cafe also had an some interesting Asian style desserts too like paat bing soo (fruit, with sweet red beans, ice cream and shaved ice). Even the shaved ice was very high quality in that the shaving was very fine and made eating this dessert great toppings very enjoyable.  I also noticed that they had a great sound system for light music, and I'd definitely think of this place to take a break from all the hectic activity in SF and have a nice refreshing drink.  I appreciated that there was thought put into this cafe to include free Wi-Fi and would definitely hang out here again with my iphone.
author: Jean S.

description: I have literally been on a study cafe hunt for a long long time and I think I found my spot. This plus is roomy, not crowded, good food/drinks, and lots of good lighting. It isn't perfect with its spotty (but free) wifi and slightly overpriced food but hey, i can't ask for too much right? Besides, the food (especially the desserts) is delicious!
author: Minh-Chi T.

description: This is a great place to hang out with friends and get some yummy desserts. It's very cute and comfortable inside. The yuzu tea is a good decaf alternative. The hot chocolate is rich and not too sweet. The salted chocolate carametl tart and blueberry mint ice creams are my favorite.
author: L C.

description: Went to this cafe last night.  Laid-back, great pastries.  I love how the place is decorated.  Everyone is really friendly.  Had a delicious raspberry macaroon and a yummy hazelnut latte.  I wish there were places like this in Los Angeles!
author: Amanda L.

description: NEW AMAZING FIND! I have been going here a few months now for a quiet study spot. Never TOO crowded, great coffee/tea/sweets and free internet. Unique stuff too, like shaved ice and sweet potato latte. Great ambience and the people are so nice. Only lacking the 5th star because I think a few more "savory" items on the menu would be a great addition! I sit there for hours sometimes and get HUNGRY!
author: Lauren Q.

description: Finally a place in San Franc that serve real hot chocolate- not from a bag, but the real deal hot milk from the machine and real chocolate. the place has very relaxing music playing in the background - which is what I need after long day working at the bank with customers. the entire staff is friendly and the girls here very cute and polite....I did like the cakes display with couple of fresh cakes from cheese cakes to almost any cakes you can think about. I did notice many students here reading books or just writing on the laptop.
author: Dave M.
